body.div:
The following is the translation of the Japanese text, with the XML markup retained as requested:
```xml
1. The Tale of the Heike, Volume One
1.1. Gion Shōja
[1.1.1] The sound of the bell of the **Jetavana Monastery** (Gion Shōja) echoes the impermanence of all things. The color of the blossoms of the **twin sāla trees** reveals the truth that the prosperous must inevitably decline. The arrogant do not last long, but are merely like a dream on a **spring night**. The mighty, too, are finally overthrown, being no more than **dust before the wind**. Looking far back to **foreign lands**, **Zhao Gao of Qin**, **Wang Mang of Han**, **Zhou Yi of Liang**, and **Lushan of Tang**—these were all men who disregarded the government of their former masters and previous emperors, indulged in extreme pleasures, took no heed of warnings, failed to recognize that the realm would fall into disorder, and were ignorant of the people's suffering, and thus were soon overthrown and perished. Looking closely at **our own country**, the careers of **Masakado of Jōhei**, **Sumitomo of Tengyō**, **Yoshichika of Kōwa**, and **Nobuyori of Heiji** were all diverse in their arrogance and might, but the state of the man known as the **Priest of Rokuhara**, the **former Grand Minister of State**, **Taira no Ason Kiyomori**, is one about which the mind and tongue cannot convey what we have heard passed down.
[1.1.2] Searching for his **ancestors**, he is the **heir** of **Tadamori no Ason**, **Minister of the Bureau of Punishments**, the **grandson** of **Masamori**, **Governor of Sanuki**, the **ninth-generation descendant** of **Prince Kazurawara**, **First-Rank Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs**, the **fifth imperial prince** of **Emperor Kanmu**. The Prince's son, **Prince Taka**, died **without office or rank**. It was during the time of his son, **Prince Takamochi**, that he first received the **surname Taira** and was appointed **Vice Governor of Kazusa**, suddenly **leaving the imperial family** to **join the ranks of the subjects**. His son, **Yoshishige**, **Commander of the Pacification Headquarters**, was later **renamed Kunika**. From **Kunika** up to **Masamori**, for **six generations** they were **Provincial Governors** (Zuryō) of various provinces, but they had not yet been **granted entry to the Palace's inner circle**.
1.2. Ambush in the Palace
[1.2.1] When **Tadamori** was **Governor of Bizen**, he **constructed the Chōshō-in Temple** at the **request of Emperor Toba**, building a **hall of thirty-three bays** and **enshrining one thousand and one Buddha statues**. The **dedication ceremony** was on the **thirteenth day of the third month of Tenshō 1** (1131). He was told that he would be **granted a vacant province as a reward**. He was given the province of **Tajima**, which was **vacant** at the time. Out of **great admiration**, the **Retired Emperor** permitted him to **ascend to the Palace's inner apartments** (Shōden). **Tadamori** was **thirty-six** when he first **gained admission to the Palace**. The **courtiers** (Kumoi no Hito) **envied** this, and on the **night of the Festival of the Five Annual Ceremonies** (Gosechi Toyo no Akari no Sekchi), the **twenty-third day of the eleventh month of the same year**, they **planned to ambush and kill Tadamori**. **Tadamori** heard of this and said, "**I am not a person of letters**, but was born into a **house of military valor**. To suffer such **unexpected disgrace** would be **unfortunate for my family and for myself**. The maxim states: 'In performing an action, **preserve your body and serve your lord**.' " Therefore, he **made preparations** beforehand. From the start of his entry to the Palace, he carried a **large, sheathed sword** (Sayamaki), wearing it **carelessly under his court attire** (Sokutai), and facing the **dim light of the fire**, he **softly drew this sword** and **held it to his temples**, whereupon it seemed to them like **ice**. Everyone **strained their eyes** to see. Furthermore, one of Tadamori's retainers, **Iesada**, **Vice Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards**, son of **Shin no Saburō Tayū Iefusa**, grandson of **Ki no Suke Tadamitsu** (who was formerly of the same family), was there. He wore a **light-blue court robe** (Hitōtori) over a **lime-green laced cuirass** (Moegi Odoshi no Haramaki), and with a **sheathed great sword** (Tachi) tucked at his side, he **sat humbly** in the **small courtyard of the Palace's inner apartments** (Tenjō no Koniwa). The **Chief Courtier** (Kanshu) and others wondered, saying, "**Who is that person** in a **plain robe** (Hōi) sitting **inside the covered corridor** (Utsubo Bashira) and **near the bell cord** (Suzu no Tsuna no Hen)? This is **disorderly**. **Leave immediately**." When a **Sixth-Rank Official** told him this, **Iesada** replied, "**I heard that my hereditary lord, the Governor of Bizen, is to be ambushed tonight**, so I am **waiting here to see what happens**. I **cannot possibly leave**." Since he **remained humbly seated**, they perhaps judged this to be **unwise**, and so the **ambush that night did not take place**.
[1.2.2] When **Tadamori** was called before the **Imperial Presence** (Gyozen), the people changed the rhythm of their songs and jeered, saying, "**The Taira of Ise** (Ise Heishi) **is cross-eyed**." Although these people were, respectfully speaking, the descendants of **Emperor Kashiwabara**, they had been **estranged from the capital's residence** for a time, behaving only as **lower-ranking officials** (Jige) and living deeply rooted in **Ise Province**, so they were called the **Taira of Ise** (Ise Heishi), using the name of the province as a metaphor for their character. Moreover, since **Tadamori** was **cross-eyed**, they **ridiculed** him in this manner. Finding no proper course of action, he **secretly withdrew** before the **imperial concert** (Gyoyū) had ended, and he **entrusted the sword** that was worn at his waist to the **Palace Stewards** (Tonomori Tsukasa) **behind the Shishin-den Hall**, in a place where the **other courtiers could see**. **Iesada** awaited his return and asked, "**Well, how was it?**" Although Tadamori **wished to tell him everything**, he felt that if he did, Iesada would likely **attempt to force his way into the Palace's inner apartments** (Tenjō) as well, so he replied, "**Nothing happened**."
[1.2.3] During the **Five Annual Ceremonies** (Gosechi), people would sing delightfully about things like "**white thin paper** (Shirausu'yō)," "**small patterned paper** (Kozemuji no Kami)," "**rolled-up writing brushes** (Makiage no Fude)," and "**brush handles painted with a quiver design** (Tomoe Egaitaru Fude no Jiku)," but in those days there was a man named **Dazai no Gon no Sochi Suekata no Kyō**. Because he was **extremely dark-skinned**, people called him the "**Dark Governor-General** (Kuro Sochi)." When this man, who was then the **Head Chamberlain** (Kurōdo no Tō), came forward at the Five Annual Ceremonies, they changed the rhythm and mocked him, saying, "**Oh, how black, how black is his head!** **What kind of person** has **lacquered** it?" Also, when **Kazan'in**, **former Grand Minister of State Tadamasa no Kō**, was only **ten years old**, he lost his father, **Middle Counselor Tadamune no Kyō**, and was an orphan. **Middle Counselor Fujiwara no Ienari** of the **former Nakamikado household**, who was then **Governor of Harima**, took him as his **son-in-law** and treated him with great favor, so at the Five Annual Ceremonies, people jeered at him, saying, "**Harima rice**, does it **sharpen** like *tokusa* (horsetail), or is it a **mulberry leaf**? It **polishes** a person's **luster**." In **ancient times**, such things happened, but **no harm came of it**. People said they wondered **what would happen in later ages**.
[1.2.4] As expected, when the Five Annual Ceremonies were over, all the **courtiers** made a submission, saying, "**For one to wear a great sword and attend a public banquet, and for one to be granted military weapons and pass in and out of the Palace, these are all imperial commands based on precedents that uphold the rules of decorum**. However, **Tadamori no Ason** either summoned a soldier in a **plain robe** (Hōi), calling him a **hereditary retainer**, and kept him waiting in the **small courtyard of the Palace's inner apartments**, or wore a **sword at his waist** while attending the **banquet**. These **two points** are **unprecedented acts of violence**. The **offense is compounded**. He can **certainly not escape punishment** for the crime. He should **immediately have his commission revoked** and be **suspended from his post**." When they all **petitioned** this, the **Retired Emperor** was **greatly surprised** and **summoned Tadamori** to **question** him. He **explained**, saying, "I was **completely unaware** that a **retainer** was present in the **small courtyard**. However, since people have been **plotting** lately for a reason unknown to me, my **long-time retainer** must have **heard of it** and **secretly** came to guard me to **prevent my disgrace**, without my knowledge; this is a situation beyond my control. If there is **still a fault**, should I not **summon that man** and **present him**? Next, regarding the matter of the sword, I **entrusted it to the Palace Stewards** (Tonomori Tsukasa). If it is summoned and examined, a judgment regarding the **nature of the sword** should determine the fault." He said this, and since it seemed reasonable, the sword was **summoned** and **inspected by the Emperor** (Eiran). Although the **outside** was a **black-lacquered sheath** (Sayamaki), the **inside** was a **wooden sword** (Bokutō) **overlaid with silver foil**. The Emperor said, "Although he **claims to carry a sword to avoid immediate disgrace**, his **foresight in carrying a wooden sword**, knowing that he would be **accused later**, is truly **admirable**. The **strategy** of a man involved in **warfare** should indeed be like this. Furthermore, the fact that a **retainer** was in the **small courtyard** is also simply the **custom of a warrior's retainer**. It is **not Tadamori's fault**." Thus, he was instead **greatly impressed** and **no judgment of guilt** was made.
1.3. The Sea Bass
[1.3.1] When **Tadamori's sons** became **Vice Commanders of the Inner Palace Guards** (Shōe no Sa), and **gained admission to the Palace**, the **courtiers** could **no longer shun their company**.
[1.3.2] About that time, **Tadamori** came up to the capital from **Bizen Province**, and **Emperor Toba** asked him, "**How is Akashi Bay?**" Tadamori replied:
あり明の月もあかしのうら風に、浪ばかりこそよると見えしか。
[1.3.3] He replied, "**The moon in the dawn sky also makes Akashi Bay clear** (akashi), **and only the waves seemed to approach at night on the wind**." The Emperor was **greatly impressed**. This poem was **included in the Kinyōshū** (Anthology of Golden Leaves).
[1.3.4] **Tadamori** also had a relationship with the **Retired Emperor's most beloved court lady** (Nyōbō) and used to visit her at the **Palace**. One time, he **forgot a fan** on which a **moon was painted** at the end of the ribs, in that **lady's apartment**. The other ladies laughed, saying, "**Where does this moonlight** (Tsukikage) **come from?** Its **origin is uncertain**." The lady replied with a poem:
雲井よりたゞもりきたる月なれば、おぼろげにてはいはじとぞ思ふ。
[1.3.5] She composed, "**Since it is the moon** (Tsuki) **that has simply come** (tada mori kitaru) **from the clouds**, I believe it **should not be spoken of lightly**." Tadamori was **all the more impressed**. She was the **mother of Tadanori**, **Governor of Satsuma**. As Tadamori was also **refined** in the manner of "making friends with likeness," that lady was also **elegant**. Thus, **Tadamori** became the **Minister of the Bureau of Punishments** (Gyōbukyō) and **passed away** on the **fifteenth day of the first month of Ninpei 3** (1153), at the **age of fifty-eight**. **Kiyomori**, being the **eldest legitimate son**, **succeeded him**.
[1.3.6] In the **seventh month of Hōgen 1** (1156), when the **Vice Minister of the Left** (Safu Dai) at Uji caused trouble, **Kiyomori**, as **Governor of Aki**, performed **meritorious service** on the **Emperor's side**, so he was promoted to **Governor of Harima** and then became the **Deputy Governor-General of Dazaifu** (Dazai no Daini) in the **third year of Hōgen** (1158). Next, in the **twelfth month of Heiji 1** (1159), during **Lord Nobuyori's rebellion**, he was on the **Emperor's side**, **subdued the rebels**, and his **meritorious services** were **numerous**. Since the **reward** was considered **heavy**, he was **appointed to Senior Third Rank** the following year, and subsequently rose to **Counsellor** (Saishō), **Head of the Imperial Guard** (Efu no Kami), **Chief of the Police and Judicial Commissioner** (Kebii-shi Bettō), **Middle Counselor** (Chūnagon), and **Major Counselor** (Dainagon), finally reaching the **rank of Chief Minister** (Jōshō), ascending from **Inner Minister** (Naidaijin) to **Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin) of the **Junior First Rank** (Ju-ichii) **without passing through the positions of Minister of the Left or Right**. Even though he was not a **General**, he was **granted military weapons** and was accompanied by **imperial guards** (Zuishin). He received the **Imperial Edict to use the ox-drawn carriage and palanquin** (Gyūsha Rensha no Senji), and would **pass in and out of the Palace while riding**. He was entirely like a **Minister in Power** (Shisshō no Shin). It is said, "**The Grand Minister of State** is a **role model for one person** and an **example for the four seas**. He governs the country, discusses the Way, and harmonizes and orders the yin and yang. If the right person is not found, then the office should be **vacant**." Therefore, the office is also called the **Office of Vacancy** (Soku-ketsu no Kan). Although it is an office that **should not be polluted by anyone other than the suitable person**, since he held the **entire realm in the palm of his hand**, there was **no reason to question it**.
[1.3.7] It is said that the **Taira clan's prosperity** was due to the **divine favor of the Kumano Gongen** (incarnation of Buddha). The reason is that in the past, when **Kiyomori** was still **Governor of Aki**, he was **sailing by ship** from the **Ise Sea** to **Kumano**, when a **large sea bass** (Suzuki) **leapt into the boat**. The **pilgrimage guide** said, "**This is the divine favor of the Gongen**. You should **hurry and proceed**." **Kiyomori** said, "**In ancient times, a white fish leapt into the boat of King Wu of Zhou**. This is a **good omen**." Although the custom for a pilgrim required keeping the **Ten Precepts** (Jikkai) and **abstaining from meat** (Shōjin Kessai), he had it **cooked** and **shared it with his family and retainers** (Samurai). Perhaps because of this, **good fortune followed one after another**, and he **reached the highest rank of Grand Minister of State**. The promotions of his **children and grandchildren** were even **swifter than a dragon ascending to the clouds**. It is indeed **admirable** that he **surpassed the path of nine generations of ancestors**.
1.4. The Shaven-Headed Boys
[1.4.1] Thus, in the **eleventh month of Nin'an 3** (1168), **Kiyomori** was **afflicted by illness** at the **age of fifty-one** and immediately **renounced the world and became a priest** (Shukke Nyūdō) to prolong his life. His **dharma name** was **Jōkai**. As a result, his **long-standing illness instantly healed**, and he **lived out his natural lifespan**. The people who **followed him** were like **wind blowing the grass and trees to submission**. The way the **world revered him** was like **rain soaking the earth**.
[1.4.2] Since he was the **head of the Rokuhara family** (Rokuhara-dono no Goikka no Kimidachi), neither **noble families** (Kazoku) nor **heroes** (Eiyū) could **face him or stand beside him**. Therefore, the **Priest-Chancellor**'s brother-in-law, **Major Counselor Taira no Tokitada**, said, "**Any person who is not part of this family must be considered a non-human** (Hinin)." Consequently, **everyone**, no matter who they were, tried to **associate with his connections**. Everything, from the **style of clothes** to the **fashion of the court hat** (Eboshi), was called the **Rokuhara style** (Rokuhara-sama), and **everyone in the realm** imitated it.
[1.4.3] Furthermore, even the **government of wise emperors and sagely lords**, or the **judgments of Regents and Chancellors**, were usually criticized and belittled by **idle persons** out of the public ear, but during the **Priest-Chancellor's time of prosperity**, **no one** spoke even a **single word of complaint**. The reason was that the **Priest-Chancellor** gathered **three hundred youths** aged **fourteen, fifteen, and sixteen**, **cut their hair short** (Kaburo ni Kirimawashi), dressed them in **red hitatare robes**, and used them as his messengers. They **filled the capital**, passing back and forth. If anyone spoke ill of the Taira clan, **one of them would not fail to hear it**, and they would call in their **associates**, **force their way** into the house, **confiscate their goods and chattels**, **apprehend the person**, and **take them to Rokuhara**. Therefore, even if people **saw** and **knew** things, **no one spoke openly**. When people spoke of the **Shaven-Headed Boys of Rokuhara** (Rokuhara-dono no Kaburo), **ox-drawn carriages** would **stop and wait** for them to pass. Even though they **passed in and out of the Forbidden Gate** (Kinmon), they were **not questioned about their names**. It seemed that the **chief officials of the capital** (Kyōshi no Chōri) **looked away from them** because of this.
1.5. Our Family's Prosperity
[1.5.1] Not only did **Kiyomori** achieve the **pinnacle of his own glory**, but his **whole family prospered**. His **eldest son**, **Shigemori**, was the **Inner Minister** (Naidaijin) and **Major General of the Left** (Sadaishō); his **second son**, **Munemori**, was the **Middle Counselor** (Chūnagon) and **Major General of the Right** (Udaishō); his **third son**, **Tomomori**, was a **Third-Rank Middle Captain** (Sanmi Chūjō); his **eldest grandson**, **Koremori**, was a **Fourth-Rank Minor Captain** (Shii Shōshō). In total, there were **sixteen court nobles** (Kugyō) and **over thirty officials of the inner apartments** (Tenjōbito) from the family, and the sum of **Provincial Governors** (Zuryō), **Imperial Guard Officials** (Efu), and **various functionaries** (Shoshiki) was **over sixty**. It seemed as if there was **no other family** in the world.
[1.5.2] In the past, during the reign of **Emperor Nara**, in **Jinki 5** (728), the **Central Imperial Guard** (Chūe no Taishō) was first established in the court. After it was **changed to the Inner Palace Guards** (Konoe) in **Daidō 4** (809), there were only **three or four instances** where **brothers held the positions of Major General of the Left and Right simultaneously**. During the reign of **Emperor Montoku**, there was **Yoshifusa**, **Minister of the Right and Major General of the Left**, and **Yoshiyasu**, **Major Counselor and Major General of the Right**, who were the sons of **Fuyutsugu**, **Minister of the Left of Kan'in**. During the reign of **Emperor Suzaku**, there was **Saneyori**, the **Ono no Miya Lord**, on the left, and **Morosuke**, the **Kujō Lord**, on the right, who were the sons of **Teishin Kō**. During the reign of **Emperor Reizei**, there was **Norimichi**, the **Dainijō Lord**, on the left, and **Yorimune**, the **Horikawa Lord**, on the right, who were the sons of the **Mi-Dō Chancellor**. During the reign of **Emperor Nijō**, there was **Motofusa**, the **Matsudono Lord**, on the left, and **Kanemi**, the **Tsukinowa Lord**, on the right, who were the sons of the **Hōshōji Lord**. These were all **sons of the Ministers** (Sesshō) **and Chancellors** (Kampaku) and had **no parallel among common people**. For the **descendants of a person** who was **even shunned** from the **Palace's inner circle**, to be **granted colored robes** (Kinshoku) and **different robes** (Zappō), to **wear embroidered brocade and silk gauze** (Ayarō Kinshū), and to become **Ministers and Major Generals**, with **brothers simultaneously holding the positions of Major General of the Left and Right**, was truly an **unprecedented marvel**, even for these **latter ages**.
[1.5.3] Moreover, he had **eight daughters**. They all **married auspiciously** in various ways. One was **intended to be the wife** (Kitano Kata) of **Middle Counselor Shigenori of Sakuramachi**, but the **engagement was broken off** when she was **eight years old** due to the **Heiji Rebellion**. She became the **Chief Lady** (Midaidokoro) of the **Minister of the Left of Kazan'in** and had **many children**.
[1.5.4] Incidentally, this **Lord Shigenori** was called the **Middle Counselor of Sakuramachi** (Sakuramachi no Chūnagon) because he was an **exceptionally elegant person** and, always longing for **Mount Yoshino**, he **planted cherry trees** (Sakura) along the street, built his **residence** among them, and lived there, so people called the place **Sakuramachi** (Cherry Blossom Town) every spring. The **cherry blossoms** usually fall after **seven days** (nanoka), but he **lamented their parting** and **prayed to Amaterasu Ōmikami** (Sun Goddess), so they **lingered for three seven-day periods** (mi nanoka) (twenty-one days). Since the **Lord** was also a **wise man**, the **Gods also shone their divine virtue**, and since the **flowers** also had a **heart**, they **retained their life for twenty days**.
[1.5.5] One daughter became the **Empress** (Kōgō). She **gave birth to an Imperial Prince** who was **established as the Crown Prince** and then **ascended the throne**. She was **granted the title of Empress Dowager** (In-gō) and was called **Kenreimon'in**. Since she was the **daughter of the Priest-Chancellor** and the **mother of the Emperor** (Kokubo) of the realm, there is **nothing more to say**. One daughter became the **Chief Wife** (Kitano Mandokoro) of the **Regent of Rokujō** (Rokujō no Sesshō-dono). When **Emperor Takakura** was on the throne, she was **granted the Imperial Edict of Quasi-Empress** (Jun Sangō no Senji) as a **substitute for the Empress Mother** (Haha Dai) and was a person of great importance, called the **Shirakawa Lady** (Shirakawa-dono). One daughter became the **Chief Wife** of the **Fugenji Lord** (Fugenji-dono). One daughter was the **wife** of **Major Counselor Reizei no Takafusa no Kyō**. One daughter was **married** to **Major of the Western Military Guard of Shichijō** (Shichijō Shuri no Daibu Nobutaka no Kyō). Also, one daughter by the **Court Lady of Itsukushima** (Itsukushima no Naishi) in **Aki Province** was **sent to the Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa** and was treated like an **Imperial Consort** (Nyōgo). Furthermore, one daughter by **Tokiwa**, a **servant of the Kujō Palace** (Kujō-in), was there. She was a **Senior Court Lady** (Jōrō Nyōbō) at the **Kazan'in Palace** and was called the **Rō no Onkata** (Lady of the Corridor).
[1.5.6] The **Japanese Archipelago** (Nihon Akitsu-shima) consists of only **sixty-six provinces**, but the **Taira clan governed over thirty provinces**, **more than half the country**. In addition, the **number of their estates and fields** (Shōen Ta-hatake) was **beyond count**. **Glittering silk** (Kira) **filled the place**, and the **inner apartments of the Palace** (Dōjō) were like **flowers**. **Mounted attendants** (Kiki) **gathered in crowds**, making the **gateways like a marketplace**. **Yangzhou gold**, **Jingzhou pearls**, **Wujun silk gauze** (Aya), and **Shujang brocade** (Nishiki)—**not one of the seven treasures or myriad valuables** was missing. The foundation of the **singing halls and dancing pavilions** (Kadō Bukaku), and the **toys of the fish-dragons and bird-horses** (Gyoryū Jyakuba) seemed to **surpass even the Imperial Palace** (Teiketsu) **and the Retired Emperor's Palace** (Sentō).
1.6. Giō
[1.6.1] Because the **Priest-Chancellor** held the **entire realm in the palm of his hand**, he **paid no heed to the world's criticism** and **cared nothing for people's mockery**, doing only **unusual things**. For example, there were two sisters, **Giō and Gijo**, famous **Shirahōshi dancers** in the capital at that time, and they were the daughters of a dancer named **Toji**. Since the **Priest-Chancellor loved Giō**, the **elder sister**, people in the world also **treated Gijo**, the **younger sister**, **exceptionally well**. He also **built a fine residence** for their mother, **Toji**, and gave it to her, and sent them **one hundred koku of rice and one hundred kan of coins every month**, so their **household was rich and happy** beyond measure.
[1.6.2] Incidentally, the **origin of the Shirahōshi dance in our country** was in the past, during the reign of **Emperor Toba**, when **Shima no Chitose and Waka no Mae** first danced it. At first, they wore a **Suikan** (a kind of silk jacket), a **Tate-Eboshi** (a tall court hat), and a **white sheathed sword** (Shirasayamaki) at their waist, so it was called the **Otoko Mai** (Man's Dance). Later, the **hat and sword were removed**, and they only wore the **Suikan**, and thus it was named **Shirahōshi** (White Priestess).
[1.6.3] When the **Shirahōshi dancers in the capital** heard of **Giō's wonderful good fortune**, some **envied** her and some **were jealous** of her. Those who **envied** her said, "**Oh, how wonderful is Lady Giō's fortune!** If we are all entertainers, we all want to be like that. Surely, it is because she has the **character 'Gi'** in her name that she is so fortunate. Let us also adopt it." So some took names like **Gi-ichi** (Gi-one) and **Gi-ni** (Gi-two), or **Gifuku** and **Gitoku**. Those who were **jealous** said, "**Why should one's fortune depend on a name or a character?** Fortune comes only from one's **karma in a previous life**." So there were many who did not take such a name.
[1.6.4] After **three years**, another **talented Shirahōshi dancer** appeared in the capital. She was from **Kaga Province**. Her name was **Hotoke** (Buddha). She was said to be **sixteen years old**. People said, "**Many Shirahōshi have existed since ancient times**, but we have **never seen such a dance**." The **high and low** in the capital **treated her exceptionally well**. **Lady Hotoke** said, "Although I am famous in the realm, I have **not been summoned to the palace of the Priest Grand Minister of State of the Taira clan**, who is so fortunate and prosperous, and this is my **only regret** (Hon'i). For an entertainer, what harm could there be? I will **go uninvited and see him**." So, one day she **went to Nishihachijō**. A messenger came and said, "**Lady Hotoke**, who is currently famous in the capital, has come." The **Priest-Chancellor** said, "**Why, such entertainers come only when summoned by someone**. How dare she come **uninvited**? To the place where **Giō is**, no matter if it is a **God** or a **Buddha**, it **cannot compete**. **Send her away immediately**." **Lady Hotoke** was **harshly dismissed** and was about to leave, but **Giō** pleaded with the Priest-Chancellor, saying, "**It is the custom for entertainers to come uninvited**. Moreover, she is still **young**. If she is **harshly dismissed** and **sent away** after having **taken the trouble to come**, it would be **pitiable**. She must be **so embarrassed** and **shamed**. Since I have **experienced that path**, it does not feel like another person's fate. Even if you do **not watch her dance** or **listen to her sing**, if you **meet her just once** and then **let her return**, it would be a **great kindness**. Please **swallow your pride, summon her back, and meet her**." The Priest-Chancellor said, "**Well, well**, since you are so insistent, I will **see her and send her away**." So he **sent a messenger** to summon her. **Lady Hotoke**, who had been **harshly dismissed** and was already in her carriage, was **summoned back and returned**. The Priest-Chancellor **met her** and said, "Today's meeting was **not meant to happen**, but because **Giō** urged me so much, I have **met you in this way**. If I meet you, how can I **not hear your voice**? **Sing one Imayō** (popular song)." **Lady Hotoke** said, "**I will**," and **sang one Imayō**.
君をはじめて見るをりは、千代も歴ぬべし姫小松、
御前の池なる龜岡に、鶴こそ群れ居て遊ぶめれ。
[1.6.5] She **sang it three times over**, and all the people who **saw and heard** were **astonished**. The **Priest-Chancellor** was also **pleased** and said, "**You are very skilled at Imayō**. By this standard, your **dance** must also be **good**. I would like to **see one dance**. **Summon the drum player**." So he summoned him. She **danced one piece** to the drumming.
[1.6.6] Since **Lady Hotoke** was **beautiful** in **hair and figure**, had a **good voice**, and was **skilled in music**, how could her **dance** be inferior? She **danced beyond expectation**, and the **Priest-Chancellor was charmed by the dance** and **turned his affection to Hotoke**. **Lady Hotoke** said, "**What is this?** Since I was originally an **uninvited person** who was **sent away**, and was only **summoned back** because of **Lady Giō's petition**, if I am **kept here like this**, I will be **ashamed in the heart of Lady Giō**. Please **grant me leave** and **allow me to depart immediately**." The **Priest-Chancellor** said, "**That cannot be**. Are you perhaps **hesitating because of Giō**? If that is the case, I will **send Giō away**." **Lady Hotoke** said, "**How can that happen?** It would be **unpleasant** enough if we were **kept here together**, but if **Lady Giō is sent away** and **I alone am kept here**, I will be **ashamed in the heart of Lady Giō**. If you **don't forget me later**, I will come again if summoned, but for today, **please grant me leave**." The **Priest-Chancellor** said, "**That is impossible**. **Giō, leave immediately**." He **sent this messenger repeatedly, up to three times**. Although **Giō** had been **prepared for this** (Omori Mōketaru Michi), she had **not expected it to happen so suddenly**. Since he **insisted that she leave immediately**, she **swept and cleaned**, **tidied up the unsightly objects**, and **decided to depart**. Even meeting and parting **under the shade of a single tree** (Ichiju no Kage) or **drinking from the same stream** (Onaji Nagare) is a **sad custom**. Furthermore, since this was the place where she had **lived for three years**, she **regretted leaving** and was **sad**, and **uncontrollable tears** fell. Since she **could not stay**, **Giō** was about to leave, saying, "Now it has come to this," but perhaps she thought of it as a **keepsake for the place she was leaving**, and **weeping**, she **wrote a poem on the sliding door** (Shōji).
萠出るも枯るゝも同じ野邊の草、何れか秋にあはではつべき。
[1.6.7] She then **rode in a carriage** back to her residence, **collapsed behind the sliding door**, and did **nothing but weep**. Her **mother and sister** saw this and asked, "**What is wrong?**" But she **could not answer a single word**. They learned what had happened by **asking the lady who accompanied her**. Meanwhile, the **one hundred koku and one hundred kan** that used to be sent every month were **now stopped**, and those **connected to Lady Hotoke** began to **rejoice and prosper**. The **high and low** in the capital said, "**Giō** has been **dismissed by the Priest-Chancellor** and has left. Let us go and **visit her** (Misan) and **enjoy ourselves**." Some **sent letters**, and others **sent messengers**. However, **Giō** was **not in a state to meet people** and **enjoy herself** now, so she **did not even accept the letters**, and **certainly did not meet the messengers**. Because of this, she was **even sadder** and **sank only into tears**.
[1.6.8] Thus, the **year ended**. Around the **following spring**, the **Priest-Chancellor sent a messenger** to **Giō's residence** and said, "**How have you been since then?** **Lady Hotoke** looks **too lonely**, so come and **sing an Imayō** or **dance** to **amuse Hotoke**." **Giō** **could not reply** one way or another. The Priest-Chancellor said, "**Why does Giō not reply?** Is she **not coming**? If she is **not coming, tell me so**. I, **Jōkai**, have **my own plan**." Her mother, **Toji**, was sad to hear this, and since she **did not know what to do**, she **weeping**ly **admonished** her, saying, "**Lady Giō, please send some kind of reply**, rather than being **chastised like this**." **Giō** said, "**If I intended to go, I would immediately say I was going**. Since I am **not going**, I **don't know how to reply**. When he says, '**If you do not come when summoned this time, I have my own plan,**' it can only be one of two things: either **being expelled from the capital** or **having my life taken**. Even if I am **expelled from the capital**, I should **not grieve**. And even if my **life is taken**, is this body of mine **so precious**? I cannot **face him a second time** after having been **regarded as a worthless person** once." As she still **did not reply**, her mother, **Toji**, **admonished** her again, saying, "**As long as you live under the heavens**, you **must not disobey the Priest-Chancellor's command**. The **bond between a man and a woman** is due to **karma** and does **not begin in this life**. Even if they swear to be together for a **thousand or ten thousand years**, there are those who **quickly separate**. Even if they think it is a **passing fancy**, there are those who **stay together for a long time**. The thing in the world that is **most uncertain** is the **custom between a man and a woman**. Furthermore, since you have been **loved for these three years**, it is a **great kindness**. It is **unlikely that your life will be taken** just because you **don't come when summoned**. You will **probably only be expelled from the capital**. Even if you are **expelled from the capital**, since you are **still young**, it will be **easy for you to live in any mountainous terrain or wooded area**. But your **old and frail mother** will **surely be expelled from the capital**. I am **sad just thinking** about living in an **unfamiliar distant place**. Please **let me live out my days in the capital**. I will consider that as your **filial piety** in **this life and the next**." Since her mother spoke thus, **Giō**, although she found the path **difficult**, **weeping**, she **set out again**, not wishing to **disobey her parent's command**. Her **inner feelings** were truly **piteous**. Thinking it would be **too lonely** to go alone, she **took her sister, Gijo**, with her. In addition, two other Shirahōshi were with them, so **four people rode in one carriage** to **Nishihachijō**. She was **not admitted to the place** where she had been **previously summoned**, but was **seated far below** in a **prepared room**. **Giō** thought, "**What is this?** I have done **nothing wrong**, and yet I have been **abandoned**, and now to be **seated even lower** is **distressing**. What should I do?" Tears flowed in abundance, even from under the sleeve she pressed to stop them from showing. **Lady Hotoke** saw this and felt such **pity** that she said, "**What is this?** If this were a place you had **not been summoned to before**, it would be one thing. Please **summon her here**. If not, **grant me leave**. I will go out and **meet her**." The Priest-Chancellor said, "**That is absolutely not to happen**," so she **could not go out**. Afterward, the **Priest-Chancellor**, not knowing **Giō's inner feelings**, said, "**How have you been since then?** **Lady Hotoke** looks **too lonely**, so **sing an Imayō**." Since **Giō** thought that as long as she had come when summoned, she **must not disobey the Priest-Chancellor's command** in any way, she **held back her flowing tears** and **sang one Imayō**.
佛も昔は凡夫なり、我等も遂には佛なり、
何も佛性具せる身を、隔つるのみこそ悲しけれ。
[1.6.9] She **weeping**ly **sang it two times**, and the **court nobles, officials of the inner apartments, high-ranking officials** (Sotō no Morodaibu), and even the **retainers** (Samurai) of the **Taira family** who were seated there all **shed tears of emotion**. The **Priest-Chancellor** was also **impressed** and said, "That was **very profound** for the occasion. I would like to **see you dance**, but I have an **urgent matter today**. From now on, **even without being summoned**, you should **always come**, **sing Imayō**, and **dance** to **amuse Hotoke**." **Giō** **did not reply one way or another**, and **holding back her tears**, she **departed**.
[1.6.10] She said, "**I obeyed my mother's command** and went to a **difficult place** (Tsuraki Michi) to **suffer a second painful experience** (Uki Me). How **distressing**! If I **remain in this world** (Kono Yo), I will **suffer more painful experiences**. Now I only think of **throwing myself away** (Mi o Nagen)." Her sister, **Gijo**, said, "**If my sister throws herself away, I will throw myself away with you**." Their mother, **Toji**, was sad to hear this and **did not know what to do**. **Weeping**, she **admonished** them again, saying, "**Indeed, your resentment is reasonable**. How **distressing** it is that I **admonished you to go**, not knowing such a thing would happen. But if you **throw yourselves away**, your sister says she will **throw herself away with you**. If I **lose both my daughters**, what is the **purpose of my old and frail life**? Therefore, I also **intend to throw myself away with you**. To **cause a parent to throw away their life** before their **time of death** has come is perhaps the **Five Cardinal Sins** (Gogyaku Zai). This world is a **temporary dwelling**. No matter how much we **lament**, it changes nothing. Only the **eternal darkness of the next world** (Nagaki Yo no Yami) is **distressing**. We can bear this life. But how sad it would be to **fall into the evil realms** (Akudō) **even in the next life**." As she **weeping**ly and insistently spoke this, **Giō** held back her tears and said, "**Indeed, if that were to happen, the Five Cardinal Sins would be undeniable**. In that case, I will **give up the thought of suicide**. If I **remain in the capital** (Miyako), I will **suffer another painful experience**. Now I will **leave the capital**." Thus, **Giō**, at the age of **twenty-one**, **became a nun** and **built a thatched hut** (Shiba no Iori) in the **mountain village deep in Sagano**, where she **recited the Nenbutsu** (Name of Amida Buddha). Her sister, **Gijo**, said, "**My sister and I vowed to throw ourselves away together**, so who should be left behind in **renouncing the world** (Yo o Itowan)?**" Thus, at **nineteen**, she **changed her appearance** and **lived in seclusion with her sister**, seeking salvation in the **next life** (Gose) with **pity**. Their mother, **Toji**, seeing this, said, "**If my young daughters change their appearance, what is the purpose of this old and frail mother remaining with white hair?**" So she **shaved her head** at **forty-five**, and the **three of them**, mother and daughters, devoted themselves solely to **reciting the Nenbutsu**, earnestly praying for **salvation in the next life**.
[1.6.11] Thus, the **spring passed** and the **summer waned**. When the **first autumn wind** blew, they **gazed at the star-meeting sky** (Hoshiai no Sora), thinking of the **Tanabata festival** (Kaji no Ha) and their **wishes**. When they saw the **shadow of the setting sun** (Yūhi no Kage) **sinking behind the western mountains**, they thought, "**The place where the sun sets** must be the **Western Paradise** (Saihō Jōdo). When will we also **be reborn there** and **live without sorrow**?" Thinking of these things, they continuously recalled the **sorrowful events of the past**, and their **tears were endless**. When the **evening twilight** had passed, they **closed the bamboo gate** (Take no Amido), **lit a faint lamp** (Tomoshibi), and the **three of them, mother and daughters**, were sitting and **reciting the Nenbutsu**, when someone **tapped softly** (Hoto-hoto) on the **bamboo gate**. The nuns were frightened and said, "**Alas, this must be a demon** (Maen) **come to obstruct** our **recitation of the Nenbutsu**, which is **worthless** (Ihikainaki). Since this is a **mountain village's thatched hut** (Shiba no Iori) where **no one visits even during the day**, who would **seek us out deep in the night**? Since it is only a **small bamboo gate**, it would be **easy to break it open** even if we **don't open it**. I think we should **simply open it and let them in**. If we **don't resist** and our **lives are taken**, we must **strongly believe in the original vow of Amida** (Mida no Hongan), whom we have **relied on for years**, and **recite the Name** (Myōgō) **without ceasing**. If it is a **welcoming host of saints** (Shōjū no Raigō) who come in response to our voice, how could they **not guide us** (Inji)? **Do not neglect the Nenbutsu**." They **encouraged each other** in this way, and when they **opened the bamboo gate**, it was **not a demon**; **Lady Hotoke** had come. **Giō** said, "**What is this?** Do I **see Lady Hotoke**? Is this a **dream or reality**?" **Lady Hotoke** held back her tears and said, "It may seem like a **strange thing to say**, but if I **don't say it**, I will be thought of as **ignorant**, so I will **speak from the beginning**. I was originally an **uninvited person** who was **sent away**, and was only **summoned back** because of **Lady Giō's petition**. Although it was a **shameful thing** for a woman, I was **forced to stay against my will**, which was **distressing**. I was also **moved** by the **Imayō** you sang when you were **summoned again** recently. When I think that it will **happen to me someday**, I **feel no joy** at all. The handwriting you left on the sliding door, 'Which of the grass on the field will not meet the autumn?', indeed, I **felt the truth of that**. Afterward, I **didn't know where you lived**. Since then, I heard that you **changed your appearance** and were **living together**, and I was so **envious** that I repeatedly **asked for leave**, but the **Priest-Chancellor absolutely refused**. Thinking deeply, the **glory of this world** (Shaba no Eiga) is a **dream within a dream**; **what is the use of rejoicing and prospering**? It is **difficult to be born as a human**, and **difficult to encounter the teachings of the Buddha**. If I **sink into hell** (Deiri) this time, it will be **difficult to rise again**, even if it takes **many births and vast kalpas** (Tashō Kōgō). I **must not rely on my youth**. In this **realm of uncertain lifespan** (Rōshō Fujō), I **cannot even wait for the next breath** (Izuru Iki no Iru o Matsu). It is **more fleeting** than a **heat haze** (Kagerō) or a **lightning flash** (Inazuma). I was **sad** that I was **boasting in temporary pleasure** and **ignoring the next life** (Gose), so I **slipped away this morning** and **came here like this**." She threw off the **robe she was wearing** (Katsugitaru Koromo), and they saw that she had **become a nun** (Ama) and had come. She said, "**Since I have changed my appearance and come here, please forgive the offenses of the past days**. If you **forgive me**, we will **recite the Nenbutsu together** and become **one on a single lotus** (Ichiren no Mi). If you are **still reluctant**, I will **wander off from here to wherever**, **collapse in some moss-covered hut** (Koke no Seki) or **under a pine root** (Matsu ga Ne), and **recite the Nenbutsu** for as long as I live, to **achieve my long-cherished desire for rebirth** (Ōjō no Sohhai)." As she **weeping**ly and insistently pleaded, **Giō** held back her tears and said, "**Truly, I never even dreamed that you felt this way**. Because of the **nature of this sorrowful world**, I should only **consider my own sorrow**, but I was so quick to **resent you** (Wagoze no Koto nomi Urameshikute) that I thought I **would not be able to achieve my long-cherished desire for rebirth** (Ōjō no Sohhai), and I felt that I had **failed** in **this life and the next**. Since you have **changed your appearance and come like this**, the **offenses of the past days** are **gone without a trace of dust**. Now, there is **no doubt about our rebirth** (Ōjō). How **happy I am** to **achieve my long-cherished desire** this time. When we became nuns, people said it was an **unprecedented event**, and I also thought so. But we **changed our appearance** out of **resentment of the world** (Yo o Urami) and **resentment of ourselves** (Mi o Uramite), so it was **reasonable**. Compared to your **renunciation of the world**, ours was **not even worth mentioning**. You have **no resentment** and **no grief**. For a person who is **only seventeen this year** to **reject this defiled land** (Edo) and **wish for the Pure Land** (Jōdo) with such **deep thought** is what I believe is the **true Great Aspiration** (Daidōshin). What a **joyful good spiritual friend** (Zen Chishiki) you are! Come, let us **pray together**." Thus, the **four of them lived together in seclusion**, offering **flowers and incense** before the Buddha every morning and evening, and **praying single-mindedly**. Although it happened **sooner or later**, it is said that the **four nuns all achieved their long-cherished desire for rebirth**. Therefore, in the **past record of the Chōkōdō Temple** (Chōkōdō no Kakochō) of the **Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa**, the **venerable spirits of Giō, Gijo, Hotoke, and Toji** are all **entered together**. These were indeed **pitiable events**.

1.7. Two Empresses
[1.7.1] From **ancient times until now**, when the **Minamoto and Taira clans** were **employed by the Imperial Court** and a person was found to be **disobeying the Emperor's authority** (Ōke) and **disrespecting the Imperial Power** (Chōken), they would impose a **warning on both sides**, so there was **no disorder in the generations**. However, after **Tameyoshi was executed in Hōgen** and **Yoshitomo was punished in Heiji**, the **remaining Minamoto** were either **exiled or killed**, and now **only the Taira family prospered**, with **no one to challenge them**. It seemed that there would be **nothing to worry about** even in the **latest ages**. Nevertheless, after the **demise of Emperor Toba**, **warfare continued**, and **executions, exiles, revocation of commissions, and suspension from posts** (Shizai, Rukkei, Kekkwan, Teinin) were **constantly carried out**, and the **realm was not peaceful**. The **world was also unsettled**. Especially from around the time of **Eiryaku and Ōhō**, the **Close Attendants of the Retired Emperor** (In no Kinjūsha) were **warned by the Emperor's side** (Uchi Yori), and the **Close Attendants of the Emperor** (Uchi no Kinjūsha) were **warned by the Retired Emperor's side** (In Yori), so the **high and low were fearful and trembling**, and had **no peace of mind**. It was exactly like **gazing into a deep abyss** and **treading on thin ice**. Although there should be **no estrangement** between the **Emperor and the Retired Emperor**, who are **father and son**, there were **unexpected events**. This was also because the **world reached the latter ages** (Kōki), and people **prioritized cruelty and evil**. Among the times when the **Emperor would constantly refuse the Retired Emperor's command**, there was one event that **shocked people's eyes and ears** and **greatly disturbed the world**.
[1.7.2] The **Empress of the late Emperor Konoe** (Kōgo, Tai-kōtaigō no Miya) was the **daughter of Major Minister Ōinomikado Kiminori no Kō**. After the **death of the former Emperor**, she moved and lived in the **Ōinomikado Kawara Palace** (Ōinomikado Kawara no Gyozo) **outside the Palace** (Kokoe no Soto). She was the **former Empress** (Mae no Kōgo no Miya) and lived a **retired life**. Around the time of **Eiryaku**, she was perhaps **twenty-two or twenty-three years old**, and had **just passed her prime**. However, since she was renowned as the **most beautiful woman in the realm**, the **Emperor**, whose heart was **only intent on love**, secretly ordered a **high-ranking official** (Kōriki-shi) to **seek her out at the Palace outside the capital** (Ge-gū), and **sent a passionate letter** to the Empress. The Empress **absolutely refused to listen to him**. Therefore, the Emperor **suddenly openly declared** that the **Empress should enter the Palace** (Nyūdai) and **sent an Imperial Edict** (Senji) to the **Major Minister's house**. Since this matter was **unusual** in the realm, the **court nobles** (Kugyō) held a **conference** and all **stated their opinions**. They said, "First, looking at the **precedents in foreign lands** (Ishō), **Empress Wu Zetian** (Sokuten Kōgō) of **Shintan** (China) was the **Empress of Emperor Taizong of Tang** (Taisō) and the **stepmother of Emperor Gaozong** (Kōsō). It happened that she **became Empress of Gaozong** after the **death of Taizong**. That was a **precedent in a foreign land** and a **separate matter**. However, in **our country**, from **Emperor Jinmu** to the **seventieth-plus generation of human emperors**, we have **never heard of an example** of an **Empress serving two generations** (Nidai no Kōgo)." The **Ministers** (Shokyō) all said the **same thing**. The **Retired Emperor** also **advised** that it **should not happen**. However, the **Emperor** declared, "**The Son of Heaven has no parents**. I **maintain the great throne** (Banshō no Hōi) through the **merit of the Ten Good Precepts** (Jūzen no Kaikō). Why should such a thing **not be carried out according to the imperial will** (Eiryō)?" Since the **Imperial Order** (Senji) for the **date of entry** was **immediately issued**, they **could not resist**.
[1.7.3] When the **Empress heard this**, she was **sunken in tears**. She **lamented** that if she had **disappeared like the dew on the same field** (Onaji Nohara no Tsuyu to Kie), **left her home, and escaped the world** (Yo o Nogare) since the **beginning of the autumn of Kyūju** (1150) when she **lost the former Emperor**, she **would not have heard such painful news**. Her father, the **Major Minister**, advised her, saying, "**Not complying with the world is considered madness**. An **Imperial Order has already been issued**. It is **pointless to object**. You must **immediately enter the Palace**. Perhaps this is a **good omen** that an **Imperial Prince will be born**, and you will be called the **Mother of the Emperor** (Kokubo), and this old man will be revered as the **Imperial Grandfather** (Gaiso). This is entirely your **extreme filial piety** (Kōkō no Itari) to **help this old man**." Although he advised her, she **did not reply**. At that time, the Empress, after writing some **calligraphy** (Ote Narai), composed:
うきふしにしづみもやらで河竹の、世にためしなき名をやながさん。
[1.7.4] The poem was somehow **leaked to the world**, and people all said it was an **example of pathetic elegance**.
[1.7.5] When the **day of her entry to the Palace arrived**, her father, the **Major Minister**, **specially prepared the ceremony** of the **accompanying court nobles** (Kumon no Kandachime) and the **carriage procession** (Iri Guruma no Gishiki). Since the Empress was **reluctant to depart** (Monouki Oidachi), she **did not set out immediately**. The time was late, and it was **after midnight** when she was finally **put into the carriage**. After her entry, she **resided in the Reikeiden Hall**. Her manner of residence was one of **constant admonishment for the Imperial Government** (Chōsei). On the **sliding doors of the Shishin-den Hall**, there are **paintings of the Sages and Wise Men** (Kensei no Shōji). There are **paintings of Yi Yin, Di Wulun, Yu Shinan, Taigong Wang, Rokuri Sensei, Li Ji, Sima, the Long-Armed and Long-Legged Ones** (Te-naga, Ashi-naga), the **Horse-Shaped barrier**, and the **Ogre Room** (Oni no Ma), and a painting that **faithfully reproduces the figure of General Li** (Ri Shōgun). The calligraphy of **Ono no Michikaze**, Governor of Owari, who wrote **Seven Sages and Wise Men on a Sliding Door** (Shichikai Kensei no Shōji), also seemed significant. On the **painted sliding doors of the Seiryōden Hall**, there is said to be a painting by **Kanaoka** of the **moon in the dawn sky over distant mountains**. When the **late Retired Emperor** was a young child, he once playfully **scribbled** on it. When she saw the painting which was **exactly as it had been**, she perhaps **felt a nostalgic longing** for the **time of the former Emperor**.
思ひきや憂き身ながらにめぐり來て、おなじ雲井の月を見むとは。
[1.7.6] The **passage of her days** in between was **indescribably piteous and elegant**.
[1.7.7] Meanwhile, from around the **spring of Eiman 1** (1165), the **Emperor** was rumored to be **unwell**, and by the **beginning of summer**, his **illness worsened considerably**. Because of this, it was said that the **First Imperial Prince**, who was **two years old** and the son of the **daughter of Ōkura no Taifu Ikiji Kanemori**, would be **established as Crown Prince**. However, on the **twenty-fifth day of the sixth month of the same year**, an **Imperial Edict appointing him as a Prince** (Shinnō no Senji) was suddenly issued, and the **abdication** (Juzen) took place **that very night**, causing **great turmoil** in the realm. The court scholars of the time consulted and said, "Looking for examples of a **Child Emperor** (Dōtei) in our country, **Emperor Seiwa** abdicated from **Emperor Montoku** at the **age of nine**. That was compared to **Zhou Gong Dan** acting as regent for **King Cheng** and governing the state from the southern face for a single day, and the **Imperial Grandfather Tadayoshi no Kō** supported the **young Emperor**. This was the **beginning of the Regent's office** (Sesshō). **Emperor Toba** ascended the throne at **five years old**, and **Emperor Konoe** at **three years old**. Those were considered to be **early**, but this one is **two years old**. There is **no precedent**. The **commotion** was **more than words can express**.
1.8. Name-Plaque Dispute
[1.8.1] Meanwhile, on the **twenty-seventh day of the seventh month** of the same year, the **Retired Emperor finally passed away**. He was **twenty-three years old**. He was like a **blooming flower that scattered**. The people behind the **jeweled blinds and brocade curtains** were all **choked with tears**. He was immediately **interred** that night at **Fun'aoka** (Boat Hill), **northeast of Kōryūji Temple**, in the **back of Rendai-no** (Lotus Pedestal Field). During the **Imperial Funeral** (Gosōsō), the **monks of Enryaku-ji and Kōfuku-ji Temples** started a **dispute over the name plaques** (Gaku Uchi Ron), leading to a **violent confrontation** between them. The **custom** during the procession to the Imperial Mausoleum after the death of the sovereign of the realm is for the **monks of the two capitals** (Nanboku Ni-kyō no Taishu) to **all accompany the procession** and **erect the name plaques of their temples** around the mausoleum. First, since the **Tōdai-ji Temple** was founded at the **wish of Emperor Shōmu**, there could be **no dispute**, and its **plaque was erected**. Next, the **Kōfuku-ji Temple**, founded at the **wish of Tanka Kō** (Fujiwara no Fuhito), had its **plaque erected**. In the **Northern Capital** (Hokkyō), the **Enryaku-ji Temple's plaque** was erected, facing the **Kōfuku-ji Temple**. Next, the **Onjō-ji Temple** (Mii-dera), founded at the **wish of Emperor Tenmu** by the **priests Gyōtai and Chishō Daishi**, had its **plaque erected**. However, the **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu) perhaps had a plan, and **disregarding precedent**, they **erected the Enryaku-ji plaque** **after Tōdai-ji's** and **above Kōfuku-ji's**. While the **monks of the Southern Capital** (Nanto no Taishu) were **discussing what to do**, **two infamous wicked monks** (Daiaku Sō), **Kannon Bō and Seishi Bō**, of the **Saikon-dō Hall of Kōfuku-ji Temple**, appeared. **Kannon Bō**, wearing a **black-laced cuirass** (Kuro Ito Odoshi no Haramaki) and holding a **shortened long sword** (Naginata) with a **white handle**, and **Seishi Bō**, wearing a **lime-green laced cuirass** (Moegi Odoshi no Haramaki) and holding a **great sword** (Ōdachi) with a **black-lacquered sheath**, both **ran out** and **struck down and smashed the Enryaku-ji plaque**, shouting and cheering, "**Rejoice! The water of the waterfall is not flowing now** (Ureshiya Mizu Naru wa Taki no Mizu), **but sing that it will never cease** (Hi wa Teru to mo Taezu to Utae)!" and then **re-entered the throng of Southern Capital monks**.
1.9. Kiyomizu-dera Temple Burns
[1.9.1] The **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu), where they should have offered resistance, perhaps had a **deep-seated plan** in mind. They **did not utter a single word**. Because of the **outrageous disturbance** following the **death of the sovereign of the realm**, the **high and low** were **terrified and dispersed** in all directions. Around the **hour of the Horse** (Uma no Koku) on the **twenty-ninth day of the same month**, it was reported that the **monks of Mount Hiei** were **descending to the capital** (Raku) in a **large number**. Although the **warriors** (Bushi) and **police and judicial officials** (Kebii-shi) **raced to the Western Sakamoto** (Nishi Sakamoto) to **defend it**, the monks **easily broke through and forced their way in**. It was reported that someone had made a submission, and the **Retired Emperor** (Ichi-in) had **ordered the monks of Mount Hiei to launch a punitive expedition against the Taira clan**. The **warriors entered the Palace** and **guarded the four camps** (Shihō no Jintō). The **Taira family** all **raced to Rokuhara** to gather. The **Retired Emperor** also **hurried to the Rokuhara Palace** (Rokuhara e Go-kō naru). **Kiyomori**, who was then still a **Major Counselor** (Dainagon), was **greatly alarmed and disturbed**. **Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori) calmed him, saying, "**Why should such a thing happen right now?**" But the **noise and shouting** of the **high and low** were **immense**. The **monks of Mount Hiei** did **not attack Rokuhara**, but instead **attacked the innocent Kiyomizu-dera Temple** and **burned down every single Buddha hall and monk's quarter**. It was said that this was to **avenge the shame** of the **disgraceful defeat at the Imperial Funeral** (Gosōsō) the other night. This was because **Kiyomizu-dera Temple** was a **branch temple of Kōfuku-ji Temple**. On the morning after **Kiyomizu-dera burned**, someone, perhaps intentionally, **wrote on a plaque** erected in front of the main gate, "**What happens when the fire pit turns into a pond for Kannon?**" The **next day**, someone else put up a **return plaque** that read, "**The power of the inconceivable vow cannot reach across kalpas** (Rekigō Fushigi Riki Oyobazu)."
[1.9.2] When the **monks returned to Mount Hiei**, the **Retired Emperor returned to the Palace** (Go-on-gyo) from **Rokuhara**. Only **Lord Shigemori** (Komatsu-dono) **accompanied him**. His father, the **Minister** (Dainagon), **did not accompany him**. It was said that this was for **extra precaution**. When **Lord Shigemori returned** from accompanying the Emperor, his father, the **Major Counselor**, said, "**The Imperial Visit to Rokuhara** is **greatly alarming**. It must be that the Emperor has had a **plan** (Omoshi-meshi Yori) and has given an **order** (Ōse Raru ru Mune), so this is what is being said. Even so, you **must not be careless**." **Lord Shigemori** replied, "**This matter is nothing to worry about**. If we are **deceived by Minamoto men** like **Yorimasa and Mitsumoto**, that would truly be a **disgrace to the family**. If you do **not go against the imperial will** and **show compassion to others**, the **Gods and Three Treasures** (Shinmei Sanpō) will **protect you**. If things turn out badly, I will **not be afraid for my life**." When he **stood up and left**, his father, the Minister, said, "**Lord Shigemori** is indeed a **solemn and generous man**."
[1.9.3] After the **Retired Emperor returned to the Palace**, he had **many close attendants** (Kinjūsha) in his presence and said, "**That person who brought up that strange matter!** I had **no idea of it** (Tsuyu mo Oboshi Meshi Yoranu Mono o)." Among the Retired Emperor's inner circle was a sharp-witted priest named **Saikō Hōshi**. He was in the presence of the Retired Emperor at the time and said, "**Heaven has no mouth, so it speaks through man**. Perhaps this is **Heaven's will**, as the **Taira clan has become excessively powerful** (Kabun ni Sōrō)." Everyone said, "**This is unwise**. **Walls have ears**. **Frightening, frightening**!"
1.10. Crown Prince Established
[1.10.1] Meanwhile, since that year was a **period of mourning** (Ryōan), the **Imperial Ablutions** (Misogi) and the **Great Thanksgiving Festival** (Daijōe) were **not performed**. On the **twenty-fourth day of the twelfth month** of the same year, the **Prince** who was the son of **Kenshunmon'in**, who was then called the **Higashi no Onkata** (Eastern Lady), was **granted the Imperial Edict appointing him as a Prince**.
[1.10.2] When the year changed, the **era name was changed to Nin'an**. On the **eighth day of the tenth month** of the same year, the **Prince** who had been granted the **Imperial Edict of Prince** the previous year was **established as Crown Prince** (Haru no Miya) at the **Higashi Sanjō Palace**. The **Crown Prince** was the **Emperor's uncle** at **six years old**, and the **Emperor** was the **Crown Prince's nephew** at **three years old**, so **neither one was in accordance with the established order of succession** (Shōboku). However, in **Kanna 2** (986), **Emperor Ichijō** ascended the throne at **seven years old**. **Emperor Sanjō** was established as **Crown Prince** at **eleven years old**. So, it was **not entirely without precedent**. The **Emperor** had **abdicated** at the **age of two**, and when the **Crown Prince** ascended the throne on the **nineteenth day of the second month** when he was **only five years old**, the former Emperor was **dethroned** and was called the **New Retired Emperor** (Shin'in). He was **granted the title of Retired Emperor** (Daijō Tennō no Songō) **before his coming of age** (Genpuku). Was this the **first time in Chinese or Japanese history** (Kanka Honchō)?
[1.10.3] On the **twentieth day of the third month of Nin'an 3** (1168), the **New Emperor** was **enthroned** at the **Daigokuden Hall**. The **ascension of this sovereign** seemed to be the **increasing glory of the Taira clan**. The **Emperor's mother**, **Kenshunmon'in**, was a **member of the Taira family**, and moreover, she was the **sister of the Priest-Chancellor's wife**, the **Niidono** (Second Lady). Also, **Major Counselor Taira no Tokitada** was the **Empress Dowager's older brother**, making him the **Emperor's maternal relative** (Gaisōku). He was considered a **Minister in Power** (Shisshō no Shin) **both inside and outside the Palace**. The **Appointments and Removals** (Joi Jimoku) were **entirely according to the will of this Lord Tokitada**. It was like the **prosperity of Yang Guozhong** (Yō Kokuchū) when **Yang Guifei** (Yō Kihi) was favored. His **reputation in the world** and **favor of the time** were **wonderful**. Since the **Priest-Chancellor** was the one who **decided all important matters in the realm**, people of the time called him the **Taira Regent** (Taira Kanpaku).
1.11. Collision with the Regent
[1.11.1] Meanwhile, on the **sixteenth day of the seventh month of Kaō 1** (1169), the **Retired Emperor entered the priesthood** (Goshukke). Even after his renunciation, he **managed all matters of government**, so there was **no one who dared to question him** in the Retired Emperor's Palace. The **court nobles and officials** (Kugyō Tenjōbito) who served near the Retired Emperor's Palace, and even the **Northern Retainers** (Hokumen) of the **high and low**, all had **more rank and stipend** than they could handle. However, as it is the **nature of the human heart**, they were **still not satisfied** and would whisper amongst close friends, saying, "**Alas, if that person dies, that province will be vacant**, and **if that person is gone, I will become that official**." The **Retired Emperor** also said privately, "**Many people have suppressed the enemies of the court throughout the generations**, but **nothing like this has ever happened**. When **Sadamori and Hidesato defeated Masakado**, or when **Yoriyoshi overthrew Sadatō and Munetō**, or when **Yoshiie attacked Takehira and Iehira**, the **rewards** they received **did not exceed the rank of Provincial Governor** (Zuryō). It is truly **unreasonable** that **Kiyomori acts so arbitrarily**. This is also because the **world has reached the latter age**, and the **Imperial Law** (Ōhō) **has come to an end**." However, since there was **no opportunity**, he did **not impose a warning**. Also, the **Taira clan** had **no particular grievance** against the court, but the **root of the world's disorder** began on the **sixteenth day of the tenth month of Kaō 2** (1170), when **Lord Komatsu's second son, Minor Middle Captain Sukemori** (Shinsammi Chūjō Sukemori no Kyō), who was then the **Governor of Echizen** and **thirteen years old**, had gone out. The **snow was falling lightly**. Since the **view of the desolate fields** (Kareno no Keshiki) was truly delightful, he **took about thirty young retainers** with him and went out to **Rendai-no**, **Murasaki-no**, and the **Ukon Baba** (Right Imperial Stable Field), where he **set many hawks to hunt quails and larks** until it was **almost night**, when he **returned to Rokuhara**. The **Regent** (Sesshō) at that time was the **Matsudono Lord** (Fujiwara no Motofusa), who was **returning to the Palace** (Go-sannai) from his **Nakamikado Higashi no Tōin Palace**. He was supposed to **enter through the Ikuhōmon Gate**, so he proceeded **south on Higashi no Tōin** and **west on Ōinomikado**. **Sukemori no Ason** **encountered the Regent's procession head-on** at **Ōinomikado Inokuma**. The **attendants** said, "**Who is that? That is disorderly!** **The Regent is passing; dismount immediately!**" But Sukemori was **too arrogant and bold**, **not caring about the world**, and the **retainers** accompanying him were all **young men under twenty years old**, with **not one person** who understood **proper etiquette and manners**. They did **not acknowledge the Regent's procession** and **did not perform the etiquette of dismounting**, trying to **force their way through**. Since it was **dark**, they **did not recognize** that he was the **Priest-Chancellor's grandson**. And even if some recognized him a little, they **did not hesitate**. They **pulled Sukemori no Ason and his retainers off their horses** and **subjected them to considerable disgrace**. **Sukemori no Ason** **crawled back to Rokuhara** and **reported the situation to his grandfather**, the **Priest-Chancellor** (Shōkoku Zenmon). The Priest-Chancellor was **greatly enraged** and said, "**Even the Regent should be considerate of Jōkai's** (Kiyomori's dharma name) **position**, so the fact that he inflicted **disgrace** on my **young grandson** without hesitation is **truly regrettable**. Because of things like this, people **scorn us**. I **cannot let this matter go unnoticed**. I will **take revenge** on the Regent." **Lord Shigemori** (Komatsu-dono) replied, "**This is nothing to worry about at all**. If we had been **deceived by Minamoto men** like **Yorimasa and Mitsumoto**, that would truly be a **disgrace to the family**. But for a person who is **my son** to **encounter the Regent's procession** and **not dismount** is **shameful**." He **summoned the retainers** who were involved in the incident at the time and said, "**From now on, all of you must be very careful**. I almost want to **apologize to the Regent for your rudeness**." He **departed** in this way.
[1.11.2] Afterward, the **Priest-Chancellor** (Nyūdō Shōkoku) **did not consult Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori), but instead **summoned about sixty country warriors** (Inaka no Samurai) like **Nanba** and **Imōto**, who were **fierce** and thought **nothing was more frightening than the Priest-Chancellor's command**, saying, "On the **twenty-first of this month**, the **Regent** (Denka) will be **making a procession** for the **Emperor's Coming-of-Age ceremony** (Go-Genpuku). **Wait for him somewhere**, **cut off the topknots** (Motodori) of his **outriders and guards** (Zenkuguizuishin), and **avenge Sukemori's disgrace**." The **Regent** (Denka) **had no idea** of this. Since the **Emperor's Coming-of-Age ceremony, crowning** (Kakkan), and **appointment to office** (Baikan) were set for the following year, the Regent was to be **temporarily present at the Emperor's residence** (Chokuro). The procession was **more elaborate than usual**. This time, he was to **enter through the Taikenmon Gate**, so he proceeded **west on Nakamikado**. Near **Inokuma-Horikawa**, the **Rokuhara warriors**, about **three hundred armored horsemen**, **surrounded the Regent** (Denka), and **shouted a war-cry** (Toki) from **front and back all at once**. They **chased and cornered** the **outriders and guards**, who were **dressed in their best attire** for the day, **pulled them off their horses**, **greatly insulted them**, and **cut off their topknots one by one**. Among the ten guards, the **topknot of Suke Mototake**, **Secretary of the Right Bureau of Gate Guards**, was **also cut**. Among them, when they **cut off the topknot of Fujiwara no Takanori**, **Great Controller of the Left**, they warned him, saying, "**Do not think this is your topknot; think it is your lord's topknot**." Afterward, they **pushed the end of a bow** (Yumi no Hazu) into the carriage, **tore off the blinds**, **cut the cow's crupper and chest strap** (Ushi no Shizuo, Munegake), **caused great destruction**, and **cheering triumphantly**, they **returned to Rokuhara**. The Priest-Chancellor said, "**Admirable!**" The **deputy driver** of the carriage, a **young man** named **Toba no Kunihisamaru**, the **envoy of Inaba**, who was of **low rank** but a **kind-hearted person**, **weeping**ly **escorted the carriage** and **returned the Regent to the Nakamikado Palace**. The **Regent** (Denka), with the **sleeve of his court attire** (Sokutai) **soaked with tears**, made his return in a way that was **too piteous for words**. The example of **Ōshokkan** (Fujiwara no Kamatari) and **Tanka Kō** (Fujiwara no Fuhito) is **not even necessary to mention**, but **never** since **Tadayoshi Kō** (Fujiwara no Tadahira) and **Shōzen Kō** (Fujiwara no Morosuke) has a **Regent or Chancellor** suffered such an outrage. This was indeed the **beginning of the Taira clan's evil deeds**.
[1.11.3] **Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori) was **greatly alarmed** (Sawa-garekeri). The **retainers** who had been involved were **all condemned**. He said, "Even if the Priest-Chancellor gives such a strange order, **why didn't you inform Shigemori**? **Sukemori is generally outrageous**. It is said that the **sandalwood is fragrant from the second leaf** (Sen'dan wa Futa-ba Yori Kōbashi to Koso Mietare). A boy who is already **twelve or thirteen years old** should now **behave with propriety**, but to **display such rudeness** and **bring a bad name to the Priest-Chancellor** is the **height of unfilial conduct**, and the **fault lies only with you**." So he was **temporarily exiled to Ise Province**. Therefore, this **General** (Shigemori) was **admired by both the Emperor and the subjects**.
1.12. Shishigatani
[1.12.1] Because of this, the **Emperor's Coming-of-Age ceremony** (Go-Genpuku no Osadame) was **postponed on that day**. On the **twenty-fifth of the same month**, the **Coming-of-Age ceremony** was held in the **Retired Emperor's Palace** (In no Tenjō nite). Since the **Regent** (Sesshō-dono) could not remain as he was, on the **ninth day of the twelfth month**, he was **granted the Imperial Edict for Concurrent Appointment** (Ken-Senji) and on the **fourteenth**, he **ascended to Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin). The **congratulatory ceremony** (Keimōshi) was held on the **seventeenth of the same month**, but the world seemed **bitter**.
[1.12.2] Meanwhile, this **year also ended**. When the new year came, the **Emperor's Coming-of-Age ceremony** was held on the **fifth day of the first month of Kaō 3** (1171). On the **thirteenth of the same month**, the **Imperial Visit for the New Year's Audience** (Chōkin no Gyōkō) was held. The **Retired Emperor and the Empress Dowager** awaited him, and they must have found the **adornment of his first crown** (Hatsukan no Oyosooi) **incredibly lovely**. The **Priest-Chancellor's daughter** was **sent to the Palace** as an **Imperial Consort** (Nyōgo). She was **fifteen years old**. She was the **adopted daughter of the Retired Emperor**.
[1.12.3] About that time, the **Grand Minister of State** of the **Myōon'in Palace** (Fujiwara no Motozane), who was then the **Inner Minister and Major General of the Left**, requested to **resign his Major General position**. It was rumored that **Major Counselor Tokudaiji Sanesada no Kyō** was the **most suitable person** for the post. Also, **Middle Counselor Kazan'in Kanemasa no Kyō** **desired the position**. Furthermore, **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō**, the **third son of the late Middle Counselor Fujiwara no Ienari of Nakamikado**, also **earnestly requested it**. Since the **Retired Emperor seemed favorable**, they **began various prayers**. First, while **one hundred monks** were **secluded at Hachiman Shrine** (Iwashimizu Hachiman-gū) and **reciting the Great Hannya Sutra** (Shindoku no Dai-Hannya) for **seven days**, **three mountain doves** (Yama Bato) flew from **Mount Otoko** and **died** while **fighting** on the **Tachibana tree** in front of the **Kōra Dai-myōjin Shrine** (the main shrine of Hachiman). The **dove** is the **foremost messenger of Hachiman Dai-bosatsu**. Since such a **strange thing** had **never happened** at the Shrine, **Kanshō Hōin**, the **Shrine Administrator** (Kengyō) at the time, **reported it to the Throne**. The **Bureau of Divination** (Jingi-kan) performed a **divination**. The divination predicted **trouble in the realm**. It said, "**The caution is not for the sovereign**, but for the **subjects** (Shin'ka no Tsutsumi)." **New Major Counselor Narichika** was **not afraid** of this, and since it was **crowded during the day**, he **walked** every night from his **residence at Nakamikado-Karasuma** to the **Upper Kamo Shrine** (Kamo no Kami no Yashiro) for **seven nights continuously**. On the **seventh night**, he **returned to his residence**, lay down due to **tiredness**, and **fell into a light sleep**. In his dream, he felt as if he had **visited the Upper Kamo Shrine**, **pushed open the door of the main hall** (Gohōden), and a **very noble voice** said:
櫻花賀茂の川かぜうらむなよ、散るをばえこそとゞめざりけれ。
[1.12.4] The **New Major Counselor** was **still not afraid**. He hired a **priest** (Hijiri) to **seclude himself** in the **Upper Kamo Shrine**, where he **built an altar** (Dan) in the **hollow of the great cedar tree** behind the **main hall** (Gohōden) and **performed the Dakini ritual** (Dakini no Hō) for **one hundred days**. During this time, a **thunderbolt struck the great cedar**, and the **thunderfire burned fiercely**. The **Palace was in imminent danger**. **Many palace officials** (Miyabito) **rushed to put it out**. When they tried to **expel the priest** who was **performing the forbidden ritual** (Gehō), he said, "**I have a great vow to be secluded in this Shrine for one hundred days**. Today is the **seventy-fifth day**. I **will not leave**." When the **Shrine officials** (Shake) **reported this to the Inner Palace** (Dairi), an **Imperial Edict** was issued, saying, "**Just expel him according to the law**." At that time, the **Shrine priests** (Jinin) **struck the back of the priest's neck with a white stick**, **drove him out onto Ichijō Avenue**, and **chased him south**. It is said that the **Gods do not accept disrespect**. Perhaps because this Major Counselor **prayed for the position of General** (Taishō) in an **unreasonable manner**, such a **strange event** occurred.
[1.12.5] The **Appointments and Removals** (Joi Jimoku) at that time were **not handled by the Retired Emperor's Palace**, nor by the **Regent or Chancellor**, but were **entirely according to the will of the Taira clan**. Therefore, **Tokudaiji and Kazan'in did not receive the position**. Instead, **Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori), the **Priest-Chancellor's eldest son**, who was the **Major General of the Right**, **moved to the Left**, and his **second son**, **Munemori**, who was a **Middle Counselor**, **skipped many senior officials** (Sūhai no Jōrō) and was **appointed to the Right**. This was **beyond words**. In particular, **Lord Tokudaiji** (Sanesada) was a **Major Counselor**, a member of a **noble family**, a **hero**, a man of **great talent**, and the **heir of his family**, so his being **skipped** was **regrettable**. People whispered that he would **surely enter the priesthood**, but he **resigned his Major Counselor post** and **remained in seclusion**, saying he would **wait and see what happened to the world**.
[1.12.6] **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** said, "**Being surpassed by Tokudaiji and Kazan'in** would be understandable, but being **surpassed by the Taira clan's second son** is **unacceptable**. This is entirely the **doing of that arbitrary man**. I will **destroy the Taira clan** by any means and **fulfill my long-cherished desire** (Honmō)." His words were **frightening**. His father had only reached the rank of **Middle Counselor**. This **youngest son** reached the rank of **Junior Second Rank** and **Major Counselor**, was **granted many large provinces**, and his **sons, retainers, and the favors of the court** were a **source of pride**. What was his **shortcoming** that led him to **have such a thought**? This seemed entirely the **work of the Heavenly Demon** (Tenma). In the **Heiji Rebellion**, he was with **Lord Nobuyori** (Nobuyori no Kyō), called **Middle Captain Echigo** (Echigo Chūjō), and was **about to be executed**, but **Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori) pleaded for him and **saved his life**. Yet, he **forgot that kindness**, **prepared weapons** in a secluded place, **gathered warriors**, and devoted himself **only to this conspiracy**.
[1.12.7] The place called **Shishigatani** (Deer Valley) at the **foot of Higashiyama** (Eastern Mountain) was a **strong fortress** (Yuyushiki Jōkaku) connected to **Mii-dera Temple** in the back. **Shunkan Sōzu** (a high-ranking priest) had his **mountain villa** there. They **often gathered** there and **plotted the destruction of the Taira clan**. One time, the **Retired Emperor** (Hōō) also **visited** (Go-kō). **Jōken Hōin**, the **son of the late Minor Counselor Priest Shinzei**, accompanied him. During the **banquet that night**, when the **Retired Emperor mentioned the plot to Jōken Hōin**, he was **greatly alarmed** and said, "**Alas, how dreadful! Many people are listening**. If this is **leaked**, it will **lead to a great disaster**."
