The **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) **changed his expression**, **stood up abruptly**, **hooked his hunting robe** (Kariginu no Sode) on a **sake bottle** (Heishi) in front of the Retired Emperor, and **knocked it over**. When the **Retired Emperor** asked, "**What is that?**" the Major Counselor **returned** and said, "**The Taira are overthrown** (Heishi Taore Sōrō)." The **Retired Emperor smiled** and said, "**Someone, come and perform Sarugaku** (comic performance)." **Taira no Hangan Yasuyori** came forward and said, "**Ah, there are too many Taira** (Heiji no Ōu Sōrai); I am **drunk**." **Shunkan Sōzu** asked, "**Well, what should be done with it?**" **Saikō Hōshi** replied, "**Nothing is better than cutting off the head** (Kuberi o Toru ni wa Shikaji)," and **cut off the neck of the sake bottle** and **entered the room**. **Jōken Hōin** was so **shocked** that he **could not say a word**. These were **truly frightening events**. Who were the **associates** (Yoriki no Yarai)? There were **Middle Captain Ōmi no Nyūdō Renjō** (Secular name Masanari), **Shunkan Sōzu**, **Executive Monk of Hōsshoji Temple**, **Motokane**, **Governor of Yamashiro**, **Masatsuna**, **Major Official of the Ministry of Ceremonial** (Shikibu Daibu), **Taira no Hangan Yasuyori**, **Mune no Hangan Nobufusa**, **New Taira Hangan Sukeyuki**, and **Minamoto no Yukitsuna**, **Court Clerk of Tada** in **Settsu Province**, and **many Northern Retainers** (Hokumen no Yarai) also **associated with the conspiracy**.
1.13. Ukawa Battle
[1.13.1] This **Executive Monk of Hōsshoji Temple** (Shunkan) was the **grandson of Major Counselor Minamoto no Masatoshi of Kyōgoku** (Kyōgoku no Minamoto Dainagon Masatoshi no Kyō) and the **son of Hōin Kangai of Ki-dera**. His **grandfather**, the **Major Counselor**, was **not a family of warriors**, but he was a man of **terrible temper** (Hara Ashiki Hito) and would **not easily allow people to pass** in front of his **residence at Sanjō Bōmon Kyōgoku**, and would constantly **stand in the middle gate**, **gritting his teeth** and **furious**. Perhaps because he was the **grandson of such a man**, this **Shunkan**, although a **priest**, was also a **fierce and arrogant man** (Kokoro mo Takeku Ogoreru Hito) and **associated with the wicked conspiracy**. **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** **called Tada Kurōdo Yukitsuna** and said, "**I rely on you as a General of one wing** (Ippō no Taishō). If this matter is successful, you can **request any province or estate** (Kuni o mo Shō o mo). First, for the **cost of the quiver bag** (Yumi Bukuro no Ryō ni)," and **sent fifty bolts of white cloth**.
[1.13.2] On the **fifth day of the third month of Angen 3** (1177), in exchange for the **Myōon'in Lord** (Motozane) **transferring to Grand Minister of State**, **Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori) was **promoted to Inner Minister** (Naidaijin), **skipping Major Counselor Sadafusa no Kyō**. The **Minister's** (Shigemori's) **General position** (Taishō) was **wonderful**. Immediately, the **great banquet** (Dai-kyō) was held. **Major Minister Ōinomikado Tsunemune no Kō** was the **honored guest** (Sonja). The **highest position** (Ichi no Kami) should have been the **first** (Sendo), but the **example of the wicked Vice Minister of the Left of Uji** (Uji no Aku Safu) was a **hindrance**.
[1.13.3] The **Northern Retainers** (Hokumen) did **not exist in ancient times**. After they were **first established** during the reign of **Retired Emperor Shirakawa**, **many Imperial Guard Officials** (Efu-domo) served there. **Tamesue, Morishige**, and the **young men Chōsenmaru and Inumaru** were all **sharp-witted** (Kirimono). Even during the reign of **Retired Emperor Toba**, it was rumored that **Suekazu and his son Sueyori** both served the court and sometimes acted as **Imperial Messengers** (Denzō), but they all **behaved according to their rank**. The **Northern Retainers** at this time, however, were **excessively privileged**, **disregarding court nobles and officials** (Kugyō Tenjōbito), and had **no etiquette or propriety**. Some **moved up** from the **Lower Northern Retainers** (Shimo Hokumen) to the **Upper Northern Retainers** (Kami Hokumen), and some were **allowed into the Palace's inner circle** (Tenjō no Majiwari). Since this was the norm, they also became **arrogant** and **associated with the wicked conspiracy**. Among them were **Moromitsu and Nariaki**, who were **retainers of the late Minor Counselor Priest Shinzei**. **Moromitsu** was a **local official** (Zaichō) of **Awa Province**, and **Nariaki** was a **low-ranking person of the capital** (Kyō no Mono). They were **employed** as **strong, clever boys or diligent workers**, and because they were **wise**, **Moromitsu** became the **Vice Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards** (Saemon no Jō) and **Nariaki** became the **Vice Lieutenant of the Right Gate Guards** (Uemon no Jō), and they both became **Vice Lieutenants of the Inner Palace Guards** (Yugei no Jō) at the same time. When the incident involving **Shinzei** occurred, both men **entered the priesthood** (Shukke) and became **Saemon Nyūdō Saikō** and **Uemon Nyūdō Seikei**. Even after becoming priests, they served as **Imperial Treasury Keepers** (Okura Azukari) at the Retired Emperor's Palace.
[1.13.4] **Saikō** (Moromitsu) had a son named **Morotaka**. He was also a **sharp-witted man** who rose through the ranks to **Police and Judicial Official of the Fifth Rank** (Kebii-shi Goi Jō) and was **appointed Governor of Kaga** (Kaga no Kami) in the **Appointments and Removals** (Tsui Na no Jimoku) on the **twenty-ninth day of the twelfth month of Angen 1** (1175). While performing his **provincial duties** (Kokumu), he **carried out illegal and improper acts**, **confiscating the estates and territories** (Shōryō) of **shrines, temples, influential families, and powerful clans** (Kengon Seika), and causing **widespread chaos**. Even if he wished to **surpass the example of the legendary Governor** (Sei Kō), he should have **governed properly**. Instead, he **acted arbitrarily**. Around the **summer of Angen 2** (1176), **Kondō Hangan Morotsune**, the **younger brother of Governor Morotaka**, was **appointed Deputy Governor of Kaga** (Kaga no Mokudai). At the beginning of his **arrival in the province**, there was a **mountain temple** (Yamadera) called **Ukawa** near the **Provincial Office** (Kōfu no Hen). The **temple monks** (Tera Sō-domo) were **boiling water to bathe** at the time, but he **forced his way in** and **drove them out**, **bathed himself**, and then let his **servants** (Zatsunin-domo) **wash the horses**. The **temple monks** were **enraged** and said, "**Since ancient times**, the **local people** (Kunigata no Mono) have **not entered this place**. **Immediately stop this obstruction** (Ōbō) of entry, in **accordance with precedent**." The Deputy Governor said, "**The former Deputy Governors** were **disgraced because they were foolish**. This Deputy Governor **will not allow that**. Just **act according to the law**." At that moment, the **temple monks** tried to **expel the local people**. The **local people** tried to **force their way in** in turn. While they were **fighting and struggling**, they **broke the leg of the horse** that the **Deputy Governor treasured**. After that, they both **armed themselves with bows and arrows and military weapons**, and **shot and cut each other** for **several hours**. The **Deputy Governor**, perhaps thinking he **could not win**, **withdrew at night**. He then **gathered the local officials** (Zaichō-domo) of the province, and with a **force of over a thousand horsemen**, he **attacked Ukawa** and **burned down every single monk's quarter** (Bōsha). **Ukawa** was a **branch temple of Hakusan** (Mount Haku). Which of the **elder monks** went to **petition about this matter**? **Chishaku, Gakumyō, Hōtai Bō, Shōchi, Gakuon, and Tosa Ajari** came forward. The **monks of Hakusan Sansha** (Three Shrines of Hakusan) and **Hachin-in** (Eight Monasteries) all **rose up together**, and their **total force of over two thousand people** **advanced near the Deputy Governor Morotsune's mansion** on the **evening of the ninth day of the seventh month of the same year**. Since the **day was ending**, they **decided to fight the next day** and **rested**. The **autumn wind** (Akikaze) that **blew and condensed the dew** (Tsuyu Fuki Musubu) **billowed their sleeves** (Sode o Hirugaeshi) on the side facing the enemy, and the **lightning** (Inazuma) that **shone in the clouds** **gleamed on the stars of their helmets** (Kabuto no Hoshi o Kagayakasu). The **Deputy Governor**, perhaps thinking he **could not win**, **fled in the night** and **returned to the capital**. They **attacked** around the **Hour of the Rabbit** (U no Koku) the next morning and **shouted a war-cry**. There was **no sound inside the fortress**. When they **sent people to investigate**, they reported that **everyone had fled**. The **monks** (Taishu) **could not succeed** and **withdrew**. Therefore, they **decided to appeal to Mount Hiei** (Sanmon), **adorned the sacred palanquin** (Mikoshi) of the **Hakusan Chūgū Shrine** (Hakusan Inner Shrine), and **carried it up to Mount Hiei**. Around the **Hour of the Horse** on the **twelfth day of the eighth month** of the same year, the **sacred palanquin of Hakusan** was reported to have **reached the Eastern Sakamoto of Mount Hiei**. **Thunder** (Kaminari) rumbled **loudly** from the **northern provinces** (Hokkoku no Hō) and **roared up toward the capital**. **White snow** (Shirayuki) fell and **covered the ground**. The **mountain top** (Sanjō) and the **capital** (Rakuchū) were **all covered in white**, even the **treetops of the evergreen mountains**.
1.14. The Vow Made
[1.14.1] The **sacred palanquin** (Mikoshi) was **placed in the Palace of the Honored Guest** (Kyakujin no Miya). The **Honored Guest** (Kyakujin) is the **Hakusan Myōri Gongen** (Incarnation of Hakusan). He is said to be the **son of Sannō** (Hie Shrine Deity). Regardless of the **outcome of the petition**, this was the **only joy in their life**. It was **greater** than **Urashima's son meeting his seventh-generation grandson**, and it **surpassed** the **child in the womb seeing his father in the Vulture Peak** (Ryōzen). **Three thousand monks followed close behind**, and the **priests of the seven shrines lined up their sleeves**. The **Buddhist alms and prayers** (Hōse, Kinen) offered **every moment** were **beyond words**.
[1.14.2] The **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu) **petitioned the throne** (Sōmon) that **Morotaka, Governor of Kaga**, should be **exiled** and **Kondō Hangan Morotsune**, the **Deputy Governor**, should be **imprisoned**. Since the **Imperial Judgment** (Go-Saidan) was **delayed**, the **court nobles and officials** (Kugyō Tenjōbito) who were knowledgeable said, "**Alas, an Imperial Judgment should be given quickly!** The **petition of Mount Hiei** has been **different from others since ancient times**. **Ōkura-kyō Tamefusa and Dazai no Gon no Sochi Suekata** were **important ministers of the court**, but they were **exiled due to Mount Hiei's petition**. Moreover, a person like **Morotaka** is **not worth mentioning**, so why **should there be any hesitation**?" But, as the saying goes, "**Ministers value their stipends and do not offer warnings, and junior officials fear punishment and do not speak**," they all **closed their mouths**. **Retired Emperor Shirakawa** (Shirakawa-in) is said to have said, "**The water of the Kamo River, the dice of the Sugoroku game, and the mountain monks** (Yama Hōshi) **are the only things that do not follow my will**." During the reign of **Retired Emperor Toba**, when **Heisen-ji Temple** in **Echizen** was to be **attached to Mount Hiei**, because of the **Emperor's deep devotion** to Mount Hiei, he issued an **Imperial Edict** (Inzen) saying, "**Accept the unreasonable as reasonable**." When **Gō no Sochi Kōfusa no Kyō** said, "**If the sacred palanquin is carried to the military camp to petition, how will the sovereign decide?**" The Emperor said, "**Indeed, the petition of Mount Hiei is difficult to ignore**."
[1.14.3] On the **second day of the third month of Kahō 2** (1095), **Minamoto no Yoshitsuna no Ason**, **Governor of Mino**, **confiscated a newly established estate** (Shinzō no Shō) in the province and **killed En'ō**, a **long-time resident of the mountain**. Because of this, **thirty or more Shrine officials of Hiyoshi** (Hiyoshi no Shashi) and **Temple officials of Enryaku-ji** (Enryaku-ji no Jikan) **came to the military camp** (Jintō) with a **petition** (Mōshibumi). The **Chancellor of Gonijō** (Gonijō Kanpaku-dono) ordered **Yoriharu**, **Vice Minor Counselor of the Ministry of Central Affairs of the Yamato Minamoto clan** (Yamato Genji Nakatsukasa Gon no Shōyū), to **defend it**. **Yoriharu's retainers shot arrows**. **Eight people were immediately shot dead**, and **over ten were wounded**. The **Shrine officials and Temple officials scattered** in all directions. When it was reported that the **high-ranking monks of Mount Hiei** were **descending to the capital to petition the throne**, the **warriors** and **police and judicial officials** **raced to the Western Sakamoto** and **drove them all back**.
[1.14.4] Since the **Imperial Judgment was delayed** at **Mount Hiei**, they **carried the sacred palanquins of the seven shrines** to the **Konpon Chūdō** (Main Hall), and in front of them, they **recited the Great Hannya Sutra** (Shindoku no Dai-Hannya) for **seven days to curse the Chancellor**. **Chūin Hōin**, who was then **Chūin no Gubu**, was the **officiating monk** (Dōshi) for the **final day** (Kechigan). He ascended the **high seat**, **struck the bell**, and in his **invocation** (Hyōhaku no Kotoba), he said, "**Listen carefully, all beings! The Gods who have grown up from the second leaf of the sandalwood**, please **shoot a whistling arrow** (Kaburaya Hitotsu Hanachi Ate Tamai) at the **Chancellor of Gonijō!** **Hachi Ōji Gongen** (Eight Princes Incarnation)." A **strange event** happened **that night**. It was said that people had a dream of the **sound of a whistling arrow** (Kaburaya no Koe) **coming from the Palace of the Eight Princes** (Hachi Ōji no Goten) and **flying toward the Imperial Palace** (Ōjō). The next morning, when the **sliding door of the Chancellor's residence was opened**, a **sakaki branch** (Shikimi) **wet with dew**, as if it had **just arrived from the mountain**, was **standing there**. This was **frightening**. Immediately, the **Chancellor of Gonijō** was **afflicted with a severe illness** (Omoki Gobyō) due to the **curse of Sannō**. His mother, the **Chief Wife of the Great Lord** (Ōtono no Kitano Mandokoro), **grieved greatly**, changed her appearance, and **behaved like a low-ranking person**, **secluding herself at Hiyoshi Shrine** (Hiyoshi no Yashiro) and **praying for seven days and nights**. For the **public prayer** (Arawarete no Oinori), she offered **one hundred Sarugaku performances from Shibata**, **one hundred Enbutsu dances**, **one hundred horse races** (Keiba), **one hundred archery competitions** (Yabusame), **one hundred sumo matches**, **one hundred Niō-kō Sutra recitations**, **one hundred Yakushi-kō Sutra recitations**, **one hundred small Yakushi statues with one leg**, and **one life-size statue of Yakushi**, as well as **statues of Shaka and Amida**, which were **all constructed and dedicated**. She also made **three secret vows** (Go-Ritsugan) in her heart. Since they were **in her heart**, how could anyone know them? The **strange thing** that happened was that on the **seventh night**, among the many **worshipers** (San'nin-domo) at the **Palace of the Eight Princes**, a **child medium** (Dō Jinko) who had come all the way from **Mutsu Province** suddenly **fell unconscious** around midnight. When they carried him out and prayed for him, he **soon recovered**, **stood up, danced**, and **spoke a divine oracle** (Kanazu). People were **astonished** and watched. After dancing for about **half an hour**, **Sannō descended** (Sannō Ori Sase Tamō) and gave a **divine oracle** that was truly **frightening**. He said, "**Listen carefully, all you beings!** The **Chief Wife of the Great Lord** has been **secluded in My Palace for seven days today**. She has **three vows**. One is, if I **save the Chancellor's life this time**, she will **join the low-ranking women in the lower hall** (Shimo-dono ni Sōrō Morokata-ōdo ni Majiwaete) and **serve in the Palace every morning and evening** for **one thousand days**. The **Chief Wife of the Great Lord** (Ōtono no Kitano Mandokoro), who lives without caring about the world, has **forgotten her troubles** because she is **confused by her love for her son**, and she vows to **join the unseemly low-ranking women** and **serve in the Palace every morning and evening** for **one thousand days**. This is indeed **piteous**. Two is, she will **build a covered corridor** (Kwairō) from the **Hatozunō of the Great Palace** (Ōmiya no Hatozunō) to the **Palace of the Eight Princes**. It is **tiresome** for the **three thousand monks** to visit the shrine in **rain or sunshine**, so how **wonderful** it would be if a **covered corridor** were built. Three is, if I **save the Chancellor's life this time**, a **Hokke Mondō-kō Sutra recitation** (Hokke Discussion and Recitation) will be held **every day without fail** at the **Palace of the Eight Princes**. None of these are insignificant, but the **first two can be set aside**. The **daily Hokke Mondō-kō Sutra recitation** is indeed what I **wish to have**. However, the **petition this time** was a **very simple matter**, but because there was **no Imperial Judgment**, the **Shrine priests and officials** (Jinin Miyazukai) were **shot and killed** or **wounded**, and their **weeping petitions** were **too distressing** to be **forgotten even after many generations**. Moreover, the **arrows** that struck them were all **striking My own sacred body** (Wako Suijaku no O-hada). **See if this is true or false**." He **threw off his outer robe** (Kata Nuidaru), and they saw a **large wound** (Ōnaru Kawarake no Kuchi Bakari) **open on his left armpit**. He continued, "**Because this is too distressing**, no matter how much you plead, the **entire matter cannot be granted**. If the **Hokke Mondō-kō Sutra recitation is certain**, I will **extend his life by three years** (San Nen ga Inochi o Nobete Tamawarun). If you are **not satisfied with that**, then I can **do no more**." Then **Sannō ascended** (Sannō Agarase Tamai). Since the mother had **not told anyone about her vows**, she **did not doubt** who had leaked them. Since the divine oracle had **accurately revealed the contents of her heart**, she was **especially revered** and **weeping**ly said, "**Even if it were only for a single day or a moment, it would be a great kindness, but to extend his life by three years** is **more than I could ask for**." She **weeping**ly **descended from the mountain**. She **hurried back to the capital** and **permanently donated the Tanaka Estate** (Tanaka no Shō) in **Kii Province**, which was the **Chancellor's territory**, to the **Palace of the Eight Princes**. Since then, it is said that the **Hokke Mondō-kō Sutra recitation has been held every day without fail** up to the **present age**.
[1.14.5] Meanwhile, the **Chancellor of Gonijō's illness lessened**, and he **returned to his former health**. While the **high and low rejoiced**, the **three years passed like a dream**, and the year **Eichō 2** (1107) arrived. On the **twenty-first day of the sixth month**, the **Chancellor of Gonijō** again **developed a bad sore** (Ashiki Okasade Tamai) near his **hairline** and **fell ill**. On the **twenty-seventh of the same month**, he **finally passed away** at the **age of thirty-eight**. Although he was a **solemn person** (Yuyushiki Hito) with a **fierce will** and **strong reasoning**, when the **matter became truly urgent**, he **clung to his life**. It was **truly regrettable**. It is sad that he **passed away before his father**, the **Great Lord** (Ōtono), even though he had **not yet reached forty**. Although there is **no absolute rule** that the father must precede the son in death, it is a **custom of the principles of life and death** (Shōji no Okite) that even the **World-Honored One** (Mandoku Enman no Seson), who is complete in ten thousand virtues, and the **Great Bodhisattvas** (Jisshi Kuyō no Daishi), who have reached the tenth stage of enlightenment, **cannot overcome**. Since **Sannō**, who is complete in compassion and benevolence, is a **means of benefiting beings** (Rimotsu no Hōben), it is **not surprising** that his **curse** was carried out.
1.15. The Sacred Palanquin Rages
[1.15.1] Meanwhile, the **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu) **petitioned the throne repeatedly** (Sōmon Tabidobori Oyobu) that **Morotaka, Governor of Kaga**, should be **exiled** and **Kondō Hangan Morotsune**, the **Deputy Governor**, should be **imprisoned**, but **no Imperial Judgment** was given. Therefore, they **canceled the Hiyoshi Festival** (Hiyoshi no Sairei) and on the **thirteenth day of the fourth month of Angen 3** (1177), at the **first point of the Hour of the Dragon** (Tatsu no Itten), they **adorned the sacred palanquins of the Three Shrines** (**Jūzenji, Kyakujin, Hachi Ōji**) and **carried them violently to the military camp** (Jintō e Furi Tate Matsuru). The **Lower Pine** (Shimo Matsu), **Cut Embankment** (Kire Tsutsumi), **Kamo Riverbed** (Kamo no Kawara), **Tadasu**, **Ume-tada**, **Yanagiwara**, and the area around **Tōhoku-in Temple** were **filled with unordained monks** (Shira Taishu), **Shrine priests** (Jinin), **Shrine officials** (Miyazukai), and **local representatives** (Sentō), in **numbers beyond count**. The **sacred palanquins** proceeded **west on Ichijō Avenue**. The **sacred treasures** (Go-shinpō) **shone in the heavens**, and people were startled, thinking the **sun and moon** (Nichigetsu) were **falling to the earth**. Because of this, the **Generals of the Minamoto and Taira clans** were **ordered** to **guard the four camps** (Shihō no Jintō) and **defend against the monks**. On the **Taira side**, **Inner Minister and Major General of the Left Komatsu no Shigemori no Kō**, with a **force of over three thousand horsemen**, **guarded the three gates** on the **Ōmiya side** (**Yōmei, Taiken, Ikuhō**). His brothers, **Munemori, Tomomori, and Shigehira**, and his uncles, **Yorimori, Norimori, and Tsunemori**, **guarded the southwestern camps**. On the **Minamoto side**, **Minamoto no Sanmi Yorimasa no Kyō**, **Guardian of the Inner Palace** (Ōuchi Shugo), primarily with the **Provincial Officials of Watanabe** (Watanabe no Shōju), with a **force of only about three hundred horsemen**, **guarded the northern gate** (Kita no Mon), the **Nuidono Camp** (Nuidono no Jin). The **area was wide** and the **force was small**, so they **looked scattered**.
[1.15.2] Since the **monks were outnumbered** (Buzai), they tried to **carry the sacred palanquin into the Palace** through the **northern gate, Nuidono Camp**. **Lord Yorimasa**, being the man he was, **dismounted, removed his helmet**, and **worshiped the sacred palanquin**. The **warriors all did the same**. He **sent a messenger** to the **monks** (Shūto-no Naka e) with a message. The messenger was a man named **Watanabe no Chōshichi Tonau**. **Tonau** was wearing a **formal silk robe** (Kichin no Hitatare) over a **cuirass of small cherry blossoms laced with yellow** (Kozakura o Ki ni Kaeta ru Yoroi), a **sword with a red-copper mounting** (Shakudō Zukuri no Tachi) at his waist, a **quiver of white-feathered arrows** (Shirahane no Ya) on his back, a **wisteria-wrapped bow** (Shigetō no Yumi) tucked at his side, and with his **helmet removed and hung on the long helmet cord** (Taka Himo ni Kake), he **knelt respectfully** (Oshikote Mōshikeru) before the **sacred palanquin** and said, "**Lord Minamoto no Sanmi** (Yorimasa) asked me to relay this message to the **monks**. The **petition of Mount Hiei** this time is **undeniably justified** (Rin Un no Jō Motsuron ni Sōrō). The **delay in the Imperial Judgment** is **regrettable** even to outsiders. Therefore, there is **no reason to object** to the **sacred palanquin entering the Palace**. However, **Yorimasa is outnumbered**. Moreover, if the palanquin enters through the **camp that is open and undefended** (Akeno Ire Tete), the **people of the capital** (Kyōwarawa) will say that the **monks of Mount Hiei** are only **brave where they can see an easy victory** (Me Tari ga Hoshikeri), which might lead to **future difficulties**. If I **allow the sacred palanquin to enter**, I would be **disobeying the Imperial Edict** (Senji). If I **defend against it**, my lifelong vow to **honor Iō** (Yakushi Nyorai) and **Sannō** (Hie Shrine Deity) will be **broken** from today, and I will be **separated from the Way of the Bow and Arrow** (Yumi Yano Michi). Both options seem **difficult to handle**. The **eastern camp** is **guarded by Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori) with a **large army**. Perhaps the palanquin should **enter through that camp**." The **Shrine priests and officials** were **stopped by Tonau's words** and **hesitated for a moment**.
[1.15.3] Many of the **younger monks** (Waka Taishu) said, "**What does that mean? Just carry the sacred palanquin into this camp!**" But among the **elder monks**, **Gōun**, a **sharp-witted monk** from **Settsu** who was considered the **most eloquent of the three pagoda groups** (Santō Ichi no Sengi-sha), came forward and said, "**That is quite right**. If we **carry the sacred palanquin forward** and **make our petition**, it would be **more renowned in later generations** if we **broke through a large army**. Moreover, this **Lord Yorimasa** is the **direct legitimate line of Minamoto no Rokuson'ō** (Emperor Seiwa's sixth son). He is a **warrior** (Yumi Ya o Torite) who has **never been known to make a mistake**. He is **skilled not only in military arts** but also in the **Way of Poetry** (Kadō). During the reign of **Emperor Konoe**, at an **imperial poetry gathering** (Tōza no Goue) where the theme was '**Deep Mountain Flower**' (Miyama Hana), everyone struggled to compose, but this **Lord Yorimasa** composed:
深山木のその梢とも見えざりし、櫻ははなにあらはれにけり。
[1.15.4] He composed this **famous poem** and was **admired by the Emperor**. **How could we be so unkind** as to **inflict disgrace** on such an **elegant man** at this time? Let us **turn the sacred palanquin back** (Kaki Kaeshi).**" When he suggested this, the **many thousands of monks**, from the **vanguard to the rearguard**, **all agreed** (Minna Mottomo tozo Onajikeru). Then they **carried the sacred palanquin forward** and tried to **enter through the eastern camp**, the **Taikenmon Gate**. Immediately, a **violent confrontation** (Ranzeki) broke out, and the **warriors shot at the sacred palanquin violently**. **Many arrows struck the sacred palanquin of Jūzenji**. The **Shrine priests and officials were shot and killed**, and **many monks were wounded**. The **screams and shouts** (Omeki Sakebu Koe) were so loud that they could be **heard in the Brahma Heaven** (Bonten), and it seemed that even the **Earth-Holding God** (Kenrō Jishin) was **startled**. The **monks abandoned the sacred palanquin** (Mikoshi o Jintō ni Furi Sutete) at the camp and **weeping**ly **returned to their main temple** (Hon-zan e Kaeri Agaru).
1.16. The Burning of the Imperial Palace
[1.16.1] The **Controller of the Left Bureau of the Imperial Bodyguards, Kanemitsu** (Kurōdo no Sa Shōben Kanemitsu), was **ordered to hold an immediate conference of court nobles** (Kugyō Sengi) in the Palace. When the **sacred palanquin entered the capital** (Nyūraku) in the **seventh month of Hōan 4** (1123), the **Head Abbot** (Zasu) was **ordered to place it in the Sekizan Shrine**. Also, when the **sacred palanquin entered the capital** in the **fourth month of Hōen 4** (1138), the **Superintendent of Gion** (Gion no Bettō) was **ordered to place it in the Gion Shrine**. This time, it was to **follow the Hōen precedent**, so the **Superintendent of Gion, Gon Dai Sōzu Chōken**, was **ordered to place it in the Gion Shrine** as it was **getting dark**. The **Shrine priests** (Jinin) were **ordered to remove the arrows** that had **struck the sacred palanquin**. The **monks of Mount Hiei** had **carried the sacred palanquin of Hiyoshi violently to the military camp** (Jintō e Furi Tate Matsuru) **six times** between **Eikyū** (1113) and **Jishō** (1177). Although they were **defended by summoned warriors** (Bushi o Meshite Koso Fusaga Re Kere) each time, this was the **first time that the sacred palanquin had been shot at**. People said, "**If the Divine Spirit** (Reishin) **is angered, disaster will fill the capital**. **Frightening, frightening**!"
[1.16.2] Around **midnight** on the **fourteenth day of the same month**, it was reported that the **monks of Mount Hiei** were **descending to the capital again**. The **Emperor rode in a palanquin** (Koshikuruma ni Meshite) and **moved to the Retired Emperor's Palace, Hōjūji-dono**. The **Empress** (Chūgū) was **carried in a carriage** and **proceeded to the Palace**. **Major Minister Komatsu** (Shigemori) **accompanied them** in a **formal robe** (Noshi) with a **quiver of arrows** (Ya Oi). His **eldest son, Vice Commander and Minor Captain Koremori** (Gon no Shōshō Koremori), **accompanied them** in **court attire** (Sokutai) with a **flat quiver** (Hira Oroku). The **court nobles** (Kugyō), from the **Regent** (Kanpaku-dono) down to the **Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin), and the **officials of the inner apartments** (Tenjōbito), all **raced to the Palace**. The **high and low** in the capital, and the **officials inside and outside the Palace**, were **shouting and making a great noise**. The **monks of Mount Hiei** decided that since the **sacred palanquin had been shot at**, the **Shrine priests and officials had been shot and killed**, and **many monks wounded**, they should **burn down all the halls** (**Ōmiya, Ninomiya**, Kōdō, Chūdō) and **live in the mountains and fields**. The **three thousand monks agreed** on this. Because of this, it was reported that the **monks' demands would be met**, so the **high-ranking monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Jōkō-tō) **climbed the mountain to inform the monks**, but the monks **refused to listen** and **drove them all back** from the **Western Sakamoto**.
[1.16.3] **Major Counselor Taira no Tokitada no Kyō**, who was then the **Superintendent of the Left Gate Guards** (Saemon no Kami), was the **chief official** (Shōkei). The **three pagoda groups** (Santō) **gathered in the courtyard of the Great Lecture Hall** (Daikōdō no Niwa) and tried to **seize the chief official** and **banish him**. They planned to "**tear off his ceremonial cap** (Oikakimono), **seize him**, and **drown him in the lake**." When it seemed that this was about to happen, **Lord Tokitada** said, "**Be calm for a moment. I have something to say to the monks**." He **took out a small inkstone and folded paper** (Kozusuri Tatamigami) from his bosom, **wrote a sentence**, and **sent it into the crowd of monks**. When they **opened and read it**, it said, "**The monks' reckless behavior** (Rambi o Nasu) is the **work of demons** (Maen no Shogyō), and **the Wise Emperor's suppression** (Myōō no Seishi o Kuwaeru) is the **protection of the Buddha** (Zenzei no Kago)." When they read this, they **did not banish him**, but all **agreed** (Minna Mottomo to Onajite) and **returned to their valleys and monks' quarters**. It was truly **remarkable** that **Lord Tokitada** could **calm the anger of the three thousand monks** (Santō Sanzen no Ikari) of the **three pagoda groups** and **avoid public and private disgrace** with **a single sheet of paper and a single sentence**. People also admired that the **monks of Mount Hiei**, whom they thought were only **loud when attacking** (Hokkō no Kamabisushiki), **understood reason**.
[1.16.4] On the **twentieth of the same month**, with **Middle Counselor Kazan'in Tadachika no Kyō** as the **chief official** (Shōkei), **Morotaka, Governor of Kaga**, was **finally deprived of his office** (Kekkan Serarete) and **exiled to Idota in Owari Province**. **Kondō Hangan Morotsune**, the **Deputy Governor**, was **imprisoned**. Also, the **six warriors** who had **shot at the sacred palanquin** on the **thirteenth day** were **sentenced to prison**. They were **Fujiwara no Saemon no Jō Masazumi**, **Uemon no Jō Masasue**, **Ōe no Saemon no Jō Iekane**, **Uemon no Jō Iekuni**, **Kiyohara no Sahyōe no Jō Yasuie**, and **Uhyōe no Jō Yasutomo**. They were **all retainers of Lord Komatsu** (Shigemori).
[1.16.5] Around the **Hour of the Boar** (I no Koku) on the **twenty-eighth day of the fourth month** of the same year, a **fire broke out from Higuchi-Tomikōji**. Since the **wind was blowing fiercely from the southeast** (Tatsumi no Kaze), a **large part of the capital was burned**. The **flames**, which were **as large as a cartwheel**, **leapt over three to five chō** and **burned diagonally toward the northwest**. It was **more than frightening**. Among the places burned were the **Chikusa-dono Palace of Imperial Prince Korehira**, the **Kōbai-dono Palace of Kitano Tenjin**, the **Haishō-dono Palace of Tachibana no Hayanari**, the **Oni-dono Palace**, the **Takamatsu-dono Palace**, the **Kamoi-dono Palace**, the **Higashi Sanjō Palace**, the **Kanzan-in Palace of Minister Fuyutsugu**, and the **Horikawa Palace of Shōzen Kō**, and **over thirty famous places, ancient and modern**, and **sixteen residences of court nobles** (Kugyō no Ie) **alone** were burned. Furthermore, the residences of **officials of the inner apartments** (Tenjōbito) and **high-ranking officials** (Morodaibu) are **too numerous to mention**. Finally, the fire **blew into the Imperial Palace** (Ōuchi), and the **Suzaku Gate, Ōten Gate, Kaishō Gate, Daigokuden Hall, Hōraku-in Hall, various government offices** (Shoshiki), **Eight Ministries** (Hasshō), and the **Imperial Court** (Chōsho) **all turned to ashes** (Kaijin no Chi) **at once**. The **diaries of the families**, the **documents of the generations**, and the **seven treasures and myriad valuables all became dust and ashes**. How **immense was the loss**? The number of people who **burned to death** was **several hundred**, and the number of **cattle and horses was countless**. This was **not an accident**. It was said that as a result of the **curse of Sannō**, **two or three thousand large monkeys** (Ōzaru-domo) **descended from Mount Hiei**, each **holding a torch** (Matsuhi o Tomoite), and **burned the capital**. The **Daigokuden Hall** first burned in **Jōkan 18** (876) during the reign of **Emperor Seiwa**. The **enthronement of Emperor Yōzei** (Yōzei-in) on the **third day of the first month of Jōkan 19** (877) was held at the **Hōraku-in Hall**. The **reconstruction** began on the **ninth day of the fourth month of Gangyō 1** (877) and was completed on the **eighth day of the tenth month of Gangyō 2** (878). It burned again on the **twenty-sixth day of the second month of Tenki 5** (1057) during the reign of **Emperor Goreizei**. The **reconstruction** began on the **fourteenth day of the eighth month of Jiryaku 4** (1068), but it was not completed before **Emperor Goreizei passed away**. The **reconstruction** was completed on the **fifteenth day of the fourth month of Enkyū 4** (1072) during the reign of **Emperor Gosanjō**. **Poets composed poems**, and **musicians played music** for the **Imperial Transfer** (Senkō). Now, since the **world has reached the latter age** (Yo Sue ni Nate), and the **power of the country has declined**, it has **not been reconstructed since then**.
2. The Tale of the Heike, Volume Two
2.1. Exile of the Tendai Head Abbot
[2.1.1] On the **fifth day of the fifth month of Jishō 1** (1177), **Myōun Dai Sōjō**, the **Tendai Head Abbot** (Tenzai Zasu), was **stripped of the right to petition the throne** (Kōshō o Teishi seraruru ue). Furthermore, an **Imperial Chamberlain** (Kurōdo) was sent as an **Imperial Messenger** (Go-tsukai) to **retrieve the sacred statue of Nyoirin Kannon** (Nyoirin no Go-honzon) and **dismiss his personal priests** (Go-jizō o Kaieki seraru). Then, a **messenger from the Kebii-shi headquarters** (Shishō no Tsukai o Tsukete) was sent to **summon the ringleaders** (Harimoto) among the **monks who had carried the sacred palanquin into the Palace**. The **Head Abbot** had an **estate** (Goryō) in **Kaga Province**. Since the **Provincial Governor** (Kokushi), **Morotaka**, had **abolished it**, the Head Abbot, due to this **personal grievance** (Shukui), **incited the monks** (Taishu o Katara-i) to file the **petition**. It was said that this had **led to a great crisis for the Imperial Court** (Chōka no Go-daiji). Through the **slander of Saikō Hōshi and his son**, the **Retired Emperor** (Hōō) was **greatly enraged** (Dai ni Gyokurin arikeri). It was rumored that a **severe punishment** (Jūka) would be enforced. Since **Myōun** had incurred the **Retired Emperor's displeasure**, he **returned his seal of office** (In'yaku o Kaeshi Tatema-tsurite) and **resigned as Head Abbot**. On the **eleventh of the same month**, **Imperial Prince Kakukai Hōshinnō**, the **Seventh Imperial Prince of Emperor Toba**, was appointed **Tendai Head Abbot**. He was a **disciple of Gyōgen**, **Dai Sōjō of Shōren-in Temple**. On the **twelfth of the same month**, the **former Head Abbot** was **stripped of his position**. Furthermore, **two police and judicial officials** (Kebii-shi) were attached to him, and they **covered his well** (I ni Futa o Shi) and **poured water on his fire** (Hi ni Mizu o Kake), thus **afflicting him with the punishment of water and fire** (Suika no Seme). Because of this, it was rumored that the **monks** (Taishu) would **again descend to the capital** (Sanraku), and the capital was **in commotion once more**.
[2.1.2] On the **eighteenth of the same month**, **thirteen court nobles** (Kugyō), including the **Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin), gathered at the Palace to **discuss the punishment** (Tsumi-ka no Koto Gijō ari) of the **former Head Abbot**. **Major Counselor Hachijō Nagakata no Kyō**, who was then the **Vice Major Controller of the Left and Counsellor** (Sa Daiben Saishō) and was seated at the **lowest seat** (Matsue), said, "Although the **official report of the jurists** (Hōka no Kanjō) states that the punishment should be **reduced from execution to exile** (Shizai Ittō o Genjite, Enru seraru beshi), **former Head Abbot Myōun Dai Sōjō** is a man who has **studied both esoteric and exoteric Buddhism** (Kenmitsu Ken-gaku shite), maintains a **pure practice and discipline** (Jōgyō Jiritu no Ue), **imparted the Lotus Sutra** (Daijō Myōgyō) to the **Emperor** (Kōke), and **administered the Pure Bodhisattva Precepts** (Bosatsu Jōkai) to the **Retired Emperor** (Hōō). For the **master of the sutras** (Go-kyō no Shi) and the **master of the precepts** (Go-kai no Shi) to be subjected to **severe punishment** (Jūka) is difficult to fathom by **divine providence** (Mei no Shōran Hakarigata-shi). The punishment of **return to secular life** (Genzoku) and **exile** should **be mitigated** (Yuraru-beki ka)." Since he spoke **without reservation**, the **court nobles present** all **agreed with Nagakata's opinion**. However, because the **Retired Emperor's rage was deep**, the punishment was **still decided as exile**. The **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Nyūdō) **visited the Retired Emperor** (In-san seraretari) intending to plead for this matter, but the **Retired Emperor refused to see him**, claiming **sickness** (Go-kaze no Ke). The Priest-Chancellor **withdrew disappointedly**. In accordance with the **custom of punishing priests**, his **certificate of ordination** (Do-en o Meshikaeshi) was revoked, and he was **returned to secular life** (Genzoku sesase tatema-tsuri). The **secular name** given to him was **Fujii Matsueda**, **Major Counselor** (Dainagon) and **Vice Minister** (Taifu). This **Myōun** was the **sixth-generation descendant** of **Imperial Prince Tomohira** (Tomohira Shinnō), the **seventh Imperial Prince of Emperor Murakami**, and the **son of Major Counselor Kuga Akimichi no Kyō**. He was truly a **peerless scholar** (Musō no Sekitoku) and the **foremost high priest** (Tenka Dai-ichi no Kōsō) in the realm, so both the **Emperor and subjects revered him**, and he held the **positions of Superintendent of Tennō-ji Temple and the Six Victorious Temples** (Rikushō-ji no Bettō). However, **Abe no Yasuchika**, the **Head of the Bureau of Yin and Yang** (Onmyō no Kami), criticized him, saying, "It is **incomprehensible** that a **wise man of such standing** should be named **Myōun** ('Bright Cloud')." He added, "**Above is the light of the sun and moon** (Tsuki-hi no Hikari), **but below is a cloud** (Kumo aru)." He was appointed **Tendai Head Abbot** on the **twentieth day of the second month of Nin'an 1** (1166). The **consecration ceremony** (Go-hai-dō) was held on the **fifteenth day of the third month**. When the **treasure house of the Main Hall** (Chūdō no Hōzō) was opened, among the various **precious treasures**, there was a **box one shaku** (about 30 cm) **square**. It was **wrapped in white cloth**. The **Head Abbot**, who vows **celibacy for life** (Isshō Fubon), **opened the box** and found a **scroll written on yellow paper**. **Dengyō Daishi** (Saichō) had **previously written the names** (Myōji o Kanete Shirushi Okaretari) of **future Head Abbots**. The custom was to **read only up to one's own name**, and **not read the rest of the scroll**, which was then **rolled back up and put away as before**. The **Sōjō** (Myōun) must have done the same. Although he was a **noble person**, he **could not escape the karma** (Shukugō) of his **previous life**. These were **piteous events**.
[2.1.3] On the **twenty-first of the same month**, the **place of exile** (Haisho) was determined to be **Izu Province**. Although people pleaded in various ways, he was punished in this manner due to the **slander of Saikō Hōshi and his son**. The **expulsion official** (Oidachi no Kannin) was immediately ordered to **drive him out of the capital that day** (Kyō Uchita Oihidasaru Beshi) and **escort him toward the Shirakawa Temple** (Shirakawa no Go-bō ni Mukōte Oi Tatematsuru). The **Sōjō**, **weeping**, left his temple and **entered the Betsu-sho** (detached residence) of **Issai-kyō** (All Sutras) near **Awata-guchi**. The **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon) judged that, in the end, **no one was a greater enemy to them than Saikō and his son**. They **wrote the names of the father and son** and **placed them under the left foot of Kumbhīra Taishō** (Konpira Taishō), one of the **Twelve Divine Generals** (Jūni Shinshō) seated in the **Konpon Chūdō** (Main Hall), praying, "May the **Twelve Divine Generals and the Seven Thousand Yakshas** (Shichisen Yasha) **take the lives of Saikō and his son** without delay!" Their **shouts and curses** (Wameki Sakebi Jusoshi Keru) were **frightening to hear**.
[2.1.4] On the **twenty-third of the same month**, he **departed from the Issai-kyō Betsu-sho** for the **place of exile**. It is **piteous to imagine the feelings** of a person of the **status of the Dai Sōjō of the Office of Ecclesiastical Affairs** (Hōmu no Dai Sōjō), **forced to follow behind the expulsion official** (Oidachi no Usshi), **leaving the capital that day** and **heading east of the barrier** (Seki no Higashi e Omomukare Ken). When he reached **Ōtsu, Uchide no Hama** (Uchide Beach), he saw the **eaves of the Monju-rō Pavilion** (Monju-rō no Nokiba) **glistening white**. He **could not bear to look at it** (Ni-moku tomo Mi Tamawazu), so he **pressed his sleeve to his face** and was **choked with tears**. Although there were **many veterans and eminent monks** (Shukurō Sekitoku) at **Mount Hiei**, **Jōken Hōin**, who was then still a **Sōzu**, so **deeply regretted the parting** that he **escorted him all the way to Awazu**. When he finally asked for leave to return, as it was improper to continue further, the **Sōjō**, moved by his **sincere devotion** (Kokorozashi no Kirinaru Koto o Kan-jite), **imparted the secret lineage of Ichinen San-kan** (Isshin San-kan no Chimyaku Sōjō) that he had **kept hidden in his heart for years**. This **doctrine** was entrusted by the **historical Buddha** (Shakuson no Fuzoku) to **Aśvaghoṣa Bhikṣu** (Memyō Biku) in **Vārāṇasī** (Haranagoku), and was **transmitted sequentially** from **Nāgārjuna Bodhisattva** (Ryūju Bosatsu) of **Southern India**. It was **imparted** now **due to this moment of sympathy**. Although our country is a **borderland of scattered millet** (Awazane Henchi no Sakai) and these are the **latter ages of the defiled world** (Dakuse Matsudai to Ii Nagara), **Jōken** was entrusted with this, and **wringing the sleeve of his priest's robe** (Hōe no Tamoto o Shibori-tsutsu), his **feelings as he returned to the capital** (Miyako e Kaeri Noborikeru Kokoro no Uchi) were indeed **venerable**. At **Mount Hiei** (Sanmon), the **monks** (Taishu) **rose up** and held a **conference**. They said, "Since **Gishin Washō** (Saichō's disciple) began the **Tendai Head Abbot** position, **no instance of exile has been heard of for fifty-five generations**. Pondering the **essence of the matter**, since the time of **Enryaku** (782–806), when the **Emperor established the Imperial Capital** (Teito o Tatete) and the **Great Master** (Daishi, Saichō) **climbed this mountain** (Tōzan ni Pan-jōte) to **propagate the teachings of Siming** (Shimyō no Kyōhō) here, **women with the five obstacles** (Goshō no Nyōnin) have **ceased to enter**, and **three thousand pure monks** (Sanzen no Jōryo) have **occupied the residence**. On the **peak**, the **recitation of the One Vehicle Sutra** (Ichijō Dokuju) has been performed for **many years**, and at the **foot**, the **divine favor of the Seven Shrines** (Shichisha no Reigen) is **ever new** (Hi Shinnari). The **divine mountain of Magadha** (Gesshi no Reizan) is the **great sage's secret cave** (Dai-sei no Yūkotsu) in the **northeast of the Imperial Capital**. This **sacred peak of Japan** (Nichiiki no Eigaku) also **stands in the demon's gate** (Kimonn) of the Imperial Capital and is a **holy site for the protection of the nation** (Gokoku no Reichi). **Successive wise kings and clever ministers** have chosen this place as the **site of the altar** (Danjō). Why should this mountain be **blemished** now that the **latter ages** have arrived? This is **distressing**." With **shouts and cries**, the **monks of the entire mountain** (Man-zan no Taishu) **all descended to the Eastern Sakamoto** (Higashi Sakamoto).
2.2. The Affair of the Monk Yiksing
[2.2.1] "We should **go to Awazu** and **take back and keep the Head Abbot** (Kanshū o Uba-i Todome Tatematsuru Beshi). However, since there are **expulsion and escort officials** (Oidachi no Usshi Ryō Sōshi), it will be **difficult to successfully seize him** (Jiko naku Shittoku Tatematsuran Koto Arigata-shi). We can only rely on the **divine power of Sannō and the Great Master** (Sannō Daishi no O-chikara no Hoka wa Tanomubekata Nashi). "If we are truly **to be able to take him back without incident**, **show us a sign** (Zuisō o Mise Shime Tamai) **here first**." The **elder monks** (Rōsō-domo) **smashed their livers and gall** (Kantan o Kudai-te) in **prayer**.
[2.2.2] At this time, a **boy** (Warabe) named **Tsurumaru**, the **disciple** (Warawa) of **Jōen Risshi**, a **priest of Mudō-ji Temple** (Mudō-ji no Hōshi), who was **eighteen years old**, tormented his **body and mind**, sweated from his **five limbs** (Go-tai ni Ase o Nagai-te), and suddenly **went mad** (Kuru-i Ideta-ri). He said, "**I am Jūzenji** (Tenfold Incarnations) **possessing him**. Even in the **latter age**, why should the **Head Abbot of My mountain** (Waga Yama no Kanshū o ba) be **transferred to another country** (Ta-koku e wa)? It is **distressing in this life and every life** to come. If that is the case, what is the use of me **remaining at the foot of this mountain** (Kono Fumoto ni Ato o Todomete mo)?" He **pressed his sleeves to his face** and **shed tears profusely**. The **monks** (Taishu) were astonished and said, "If this is truly the **divine oracle of Jūzenji Gongen**, we will **perform a test** (Warera Shirushi o Mairasen). **Without the slightest mistake**, **return the rosaries to their original owners**." Then **four or five hundred elder monks** (Rōsō) **threw up the rosaries** (Juzu-domo) they were holding **onto the great dais of Jūzenji**. This **mad person** (Mono-gurui) **ran around, collected them**, and **without a single mistake, returned them one by one to their original owners** (Moto no Aruji ni zo Fukeru). The **monks** (Taishu) were **moved to tears of joy and reverence** (Zuiki no Kanrui) by the **venerability of the renewed divine power** (Reigen Atarashiki Koto no Tōtosa). Someone said, "**If that is the case, go and take him back and keep him**." Thereupon, they **set out in great numbers**, like **clouds and mist**. Some of the **monks** traveled the **shore road of Shiga-Karasaki**. Others, the **monks of Yamada-Yabase**, **pushed their boats out onto the lake** (Kojō ni Fune Oshi Dasu). Seeing this, the **expulsion and escort officials**, who had seemed **so stern**, all **fled and scattered** in all directions.
[2.2.3] The **monks** (Taishu) proceeded to the **Kokubun-ji Temple** (Provincial Temple). The **former Head Abbot** (Saki Zasu) was **greatly surprised** and said, "It is said that a **person under Imperial reprimand** (Chokkan no Mono) **should not even be exposed to the light of the sun and moon**. How much more so now that an **Imperial Edict** (Inzen Senji no Naritaru ni) has been issued that I should be **quickly driven out of the capital**. I **must not linger even for a moment**. **Monks, return to the mountain immediately**." He came and sat close to the edge and said, "Since I **left the house of the three dais and the elm gate** (Sandai Kaimon no Ie o Idete) and **entered the window of Siming and Youxi** (Shimei Yūkei no Mado ni Irishi), I have **studied the teachings of the Enjō School** (Enshū no Kyōhō) extensively and **mastered both the exoteric and esoteric schools** (Kenmitsu Ryōshū). I have thought **only of the prosperity of My mountain**. Also, I have **earnestly prayed for the nation** (Kokke o Inori Tatematsuru Koto Orosoka Narazu). My **intention to nurture the monks** (Shūto o Hagukumu Kokorozashi) was also **deep**. The **two Sannō Shrines** (Ryōsho Sannō) must **surely know this** (Shōran Shi Tamau Ran). There is **no mistake on my part** (Waga Mi ni Ayamatsu Koto Nashi). Since I have received the **severe punishment of exile** for a **false accusation** (Mujitsu no Tsumi ni Yotte), I **do not resent the world, people, Gods, or Buddhas** (Urami Tatematsuru Koto Nashi). The **kindness of the monks** who have **come all this way to visit me** (Koko Made Toi Ki Tamō Shūto no Hōshi Koso) is **impossible to repay** (Hōji Tsukushi Gata-kere)." He **wept so profusely** that his **sleeve of madder-dyed robe** (Kōzome no O-koromo no Sode) was **soaked**, and the **monks** (Taishu) **all shed tears as well**. When they **brought his palanquin closer** and said, "**Please board immediately**," he replied, "In the **past**, I was the **Head Abbot of three thousand monks**, but now I have become an **exile** (Ryunin no Mi to Narite). **How can I be carried and ascend** (Kaki Tatematsurarete wa Noboru Beki) by **venerable practitioners** (Yagotōnaki Shūgakusha) and **wise monks** (Chie Fukaki Taishu-domo)? Even if I were to ascend, I should **tie on straw sandals** (Kutsu Nado Iu Mono o Shibari Haki) and **walk alongside you** (Dōyō ni Aymitsuzuite Koso Nobora-me)." He **refused to board**.
[2.2.4] At this moment, a **wicked monk** (Aku Sō) named **Yūkei**, **Ajāri of Kaijō-bō** (Kaijō-bō no Ajari), a **resident of the Western Pagoda** (Saitō no Jūryo), appeared. He was about **seven shaku tall** (about 2.1 meters) and wore a **black leather-laced armor** (Kurokawa Odoshi no Yoroi) with **large rough stitches and gold mixed in** (Ōarame ni Kane Mazetaru o), with the **skirt of the armor long** (Kusazuri Nagani Ki Narite). His **helmet was removed** and carried by his **attendant** (Hōshi Warawa), and he **leaned on a great white-handled long sword** (Shiraezuka no Ōnaginata) like a staff. He said, "**Make way!**" He **pushed through the crowd of monks** and **strode forward** to where the **former Head Abbot** was. He **glared with his large eyes** for a moment and said, "It is **because of your attitude** (Sono O-kokoro de Koso) that you **suffer such a fate** (Kakarur O-me ni mo Awase Tamae). **Board immediately!**" The **Head Abbot**, in **fear**, **hastily boarded**. The **monks**, **rejoicing at recovering him**, and not the **low-ranking monks** (Shizukihōshi-warawa) but the **venerable practitioners** (Yagotōnaki Shūgakusha-domo), **carried the palanquin** (Kaki Tatematsuri) and **ascended with shouts**. Although the **carriers changed**, **Yūkei** did **not change**. He **carried the front pole of the palanquin** (Mae Koshi Kaki) and **held the handle of his long sword and the palanquin poles** (Naginata no E mo Koshi no Nagao mo) as if they would break. The **steep Eastern Sakamoto** seemed like a **level road** to him. They **set the palanquin down** in the **courtyard of the Great Lecture Hall** (Daikōdō) and discussed, "We **went to Awazu** and **took back and kept the Head Abbot**. However, **how can we appoint a person who has received an Imperial reprimand and is under sentence of exile as Head Abbot**?" **Ajāri Yūkei of Kaijō-bō** again **came forward** as before and argued, "This mountain is a **peerless sacred site in Japan** (Nihon Musō no Reichi), a **place of practice for protecting the nation** (Chingokokka no Dōjō). The **divine prestige of Sannō** (Sannō no Go-ikō) is **flourishing**, and **Buddhism and Imperial Law** (Buppō Ōhō) are **like the horns of an ox** (Gyūkaku Narai). Therefore, even the **intentions of the monks** (Shūto no Ishu) are **unique**, and even the **low-ranking monks** (Shizuki Hōshi-warawa) are **not lightly esteemed by the world**. How much more so for a person of **high wisdom and nobility** (Chie Kōki nishite) who was the **Head Abbot of three thousand monks**. Now, due to his **eminent virtue**, he is the **Venerable Master of the whole mountain** (Ichi-zan no Washō). He **suffers punishment without guilt**. Is this not the **anger of the mountain and the capital** (Sanjō Rakuchū no Ikari) and the **mockery of Kōfuku-ji and Onjō-ji** (Kōfuku Onjō no Azake ni)? It would be **distressing** if the **many scholars** (Sūhai no Gakuryo) were to **neglect their efforts in their studies** (Keisetsu no Tsutome) by **losing the master of the exoteric and esoteric** (Kenmitsu no Aruji) at this time. In the end, even if **Yūkei** is designated the **ringleader** (Harimoto ni Shō serare), is **imprisoned, exiled**, and his **head is severed**, it will be a **source of honor in this life** (Konsō no Menboku) and a **memory in the next world** (Meido no Omoide naru Beshi)." As he spoke, **tears streamed profusely from his two eyes** (Sōgan Yori Namida o Hara-hara to Nagasu). The **monks** (Taishu) **all agreed** that he was **right**. From then on, **Yūkei** was called **Ika-me Bō** ("Fierce Monk"). His **disciple, Eikei Risshi**, was called **Ko Ika-me Bō** ("Little Fierce Monk") by the people of the time.
[2.2.5] The **monks** (Taishu) placed the **former Head Abbot** in **Myōkō-bō**, **South Valley of the Eastern Pagoda** (Tōtō no Minamidani). It seems that even a **person who is a manifestation of Buddha** (Gonge no Hito) **cannot escape worldly disaster** (Yoko no Wazawai). In the past, **Monk Yixing** (Igyō Ajari) of **Great Tang** (Dai Tō) was the **personal priest of Emperor Xuanzong** (Genzong Kōtei), but he was **slandered** and accused of having a **relationship with Empress Yang Guifei** (Yō Kihi ni Na o Tachi Tamai). In the **past and present**, in **large and small countries**, the **wickedness of human tongues** (Hito no Kuchi no Saganasa wa) can lead to **groundless accusations** (Ato Kata Naki Koto Narishi), but due to this suspicion, the Monk was **exiled to the country of Bhāra** (Kara Koku e Nagasare sase Tamau). There were **three paths** to that country. The **Rinchi Road** (Rinchi Dō) was the **Imperial Road** (Go-kō Dō), the **Yūchi Road** (Yūchi Dō) was the **path taken by common people** (Zatsunin no Kayō Michi), and the **Anketsu Road** (Anketsu Dō) was the **path for those with severe punishment**. Therefore, since **Monk Yixing** was a **great criminal** (Dai-bon no Hito), he was **sent via the Anketsu Road**. It was a **seven-day and seven-night journey** where he did **not see the light of the sun and moon**. It was **dark**, and there were **no people**. He **lost his way as he walked**, and the **mountains were deep and dark**. The only sound was the **cry of a bird in the mountain valley** (Tanigawa ni Tori no Hito-koe). **Heaven** pitied him for **suffering severe punishment of exile** due to a **false accusation**, and **manifested the form of the Nine Luminaries** (Kuyō no Katachi o Genji-tsutsu) to **protect Monk Yixing**. At that moment, **Yixing bit and cut his right index finger** and **transferred the form of the Nine Luminaries onto his left sleeve**. This is the **Nine Luminaries Mandala** (Kuyō no Man-dara), which is the **main deity of Shingon** in **both Japan and China** (Wakan Ryōchō ni Shingon no Honzon).
