2.3. Execution of Saikō
[2.3.1] When the **Retired Emperor** (Hōō) **heard** that the **monks** (Taishu) had **taken back and kept the former Head Abbot**, he was **even more uneasy**. **Saikō Hōshi** spoke, saying, "Although it is said that the **disorderly petitions of the Mount Hiei monks** are **not new**, this time, it is **unprecedentedly outrageous** (Hoka ni Oboesōrō). I have **never heard of such violence**. Please **admonish them thoroughly**." He spoke thus, **without regard for his own imminent destruction** and **without fear of Sannō and the Great Master's divine will** (Shinryo), thus **troubling the Imperial Heart** (Shin-kin o Nayamashi Tatematsuru). It is said that a **slanderous minister** (Zan-shin) **causes disorder in the nation**. It is true. "**The fragrant orchid** (Sōran) **wishes to flourish**, but the **autumn wind** (Aki no Kaze) **destroys it**. The **sovereign** (Ōja) **wishes to be enlightened**, but the **slanderous minister darkens it**." When the **Retired Emperor** **conferred with New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** and other **close attendants** (Kinjū no Hitobito) and it was rumored that the **mountain would be attacked** (Yama Semeraru Beshi), some of the **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu) felt that they **should not disobey the Imperial Edict** while living in the **Emperor's territory** (Ōchi ni Haramarete), and it was rumored that **some monks agreed** to **obey the Imperial Edict** internally. The **former Head Abbot Myōun Dai Sōjō**, who was in **Myōkō-bō**, **heard** that the monks were **divided** (Ni-shin Aru to Kiite) and said with **apprehension**, "**What will finally become of us?**" Nevertheless, there was **no decision for exile**.
[2.3.2] **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** temporarily **put aside his personal grievance** (Watakushi no Shukui o ba Shibara-ku Osamerare Keri) because of the **Mount Hiei disturbance**. Although the **internal preparations** (Naigi Shitaku) were various, it seemed that the **rebellion could not succeed** with **military strength alone** (Gisei Bakari Nite wa), and **Tada Kurōdo Yukitsuna**, who had been so **relied upon**, realized that **it was futile** (Mueki Nari to Omou Kokoro Tsukeni Keri). He had **tailored the cloth** that was sent for the cost of the quiver into **court robes** (Hitatare) and **unlined robes** (Katabira) and had his **family members and retainers** (Ieko Rōtō-domo) **wear them**. He was sitting there **blinking his eyes** (Me Uchi Shibatataite). Looking at the **flourishing state of the Taira clan**, he realized that they **could not be easily overthrown at this time**. He thought, "I have **joined a useless venture** (Yona-ki Koto ni Kumi Shite Keri). If this matter is **leaked**, **Yukitsuna will be the first to perish**." He decided to **pre-emptively betray the conspiracy** (Mawashi Chū shite), **before others leaked it**, and **save his life**.
[2.3.3] Late at night on the **twenty-ninth day of the fifth month** of the same year, **Tada Kurōdo Yukitsuna** went to the **Priest Grand Minister of State's residence** (Nyūdō Shōkoku no Nishi Hachijō no Tei) and said, "**Yukitsuna has come because there is something to report**." The Priest-Chancellor said, "**Why has a person who does not usually visit come?** Go and **listen to him**." He **sent out Mōrikuni**, **Hangan of the Bureau of Horse Administration** (Shume Hangan). Since Yukitsuna said, "**It is a matter that should not be told through others**," the Priest-Chancellor, saying, "If that's the case," **went out to the middle gate corridor** himself. He asked, "**The night is deep. What is the matter?**" Yukitsuna replied, "Since **it is crowded during the day**, I have come **under the cover of night**. What have you **heard** about the **people in the Retired Emperor's Palace** (In-chū no Hitobito) **preparing weapons** and **summoning warriors** (Gunpyō o Mesare Sōrō) these days?" The Priest-Chancellor replied **casually**, saying, "**I heard that the mountain will be attacked**." **Yukitsuna moved closer** and, in a **low voice**, said, "**That is not the case. I heard it is against your own family** (Go-ikka no O-ue to Koso Uketamawari Sōrae)." "And does the **Retired Emperor know of this**?" "There is **no question of that** (Shisai ni ya Oyobi Sōrō). The **Imperial Edict** (Inzen) is being used to **summon the warriors of Lord Narichika** (Narichika no Kyō no Gunpyō). **Shunkan is acting like this, Yasuyori is saying that, and Saikō is claiming this**." He then **told all the details of the plot from the beginning** and, asking for leave, **departed**. The Priest-Chancellor was **greatly astonished** and **shouted loudly** to **summon his retainers** (Samurai-domo). The noise was **immense to hear**. Yukitsuna, in **fear** of being made a **witness** for revealing this matter, felt as if a **fire had been set in the field** and, though **unpursued**, he **tripped on his long hunting trousers** (Hittōshite) and **hurriedly fled outside the gate**. The Priest-Chancellor first **summoned Sadayoshi** (Hida no Kami Sadayoshi) and said, "The **traitors** (Mubō no Yarai) who are trying to **overthrow our family** (Tō-ke Katabuku) **fill the capital** (Kyō-chū ni Manman taru). **Inform the family members** (Ichimon no Hitobito) and **summon the warriors**." Sadayoshi **raced around and summoned them**. **Major General of the Right Munemori no Kyō**, **Middle Captain of the Third Rank Tomomori**, **Head Middle Captain Shigehira**, **General of the Left Stable Office Yukimori**, and **other people** (Ikka no Hitobito) **donned armor and helmets** (Katchū o Yoroi), **girded on bows and arrows** (Yumi Ya o Obishi), and **raced to gather**. In addition, **warriors** (Gunpyō) **gathered like clouds and mist**. It seemed that there were **six or seven thousand horsemen** at **Nishi Hachijō** **that night**. The next day was the **first day of the sixth month**. While it was still dark, the Priest-Chancellor **summoned Abe no Sukenari**, a **Police and Judicial Official** (Kebii-shi), and said, "**Go quickly to the Retired Emperor's Palace** (In no Go-sho e Mairi-re). **Summon Nobushige** (Daizen no Daibu Nobushige) and tell him this: 'The **close attendants** (Kinjū no Hitobito) have a **plot to overthrow our family** and **cause disorder in the realm** (Tenka o Midare sen to suru). We will **apprehend them all** (Ichichi ni Meshitorite) and **question them** (Tazune Sata Tsukamatsuru Beshi). **Tell him that the Emperor is not aware of this** (Kimi mo Shirimesaru Majū Sōrō).'" **Sukenari hurried there**, **summoned Nobushige**, **Vice Minister of the Grand Palace** (Daizen no Daibu), and told him this, whereupon Nobushige **turned pale**. He **went before the Emperor** and **reported this to the throne**. The **Retired Emperor** thought, "**Alas, the plot that these people secretly planned has leaked!**" and was **greatly dismayed**. Nevertheless, he only said, "**What is this?**" and **gave no clear reply**. **Sukenari hurried back** and **reported this to the Priest Grand Minister of State**, who said, "**Just as I thought!** **Yukitsuna told the truth** (Jitsu o Ii Keri). If **Yukitsuna had not informed me of this**, would **Jōkai** (Kiyomori) **be safe**?**" He **ordered Kageie**, **Governor of Hida**, and **Sadayoshi**, **Governor of Chikugo**, to **apprehend the traitors**. Consequently, **two hundred and more, three hundred and more horsemen** **attacked one place after another** and **apprehended them**.
[2.3.4] The **Priest Grand Minister of State** first sent a **servant** (Zasshoku) to **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** at his **Nakamikado Karasuma residence** and said, "**There is something to discuss. Please come immediately**." The **Major Counselor**, **completely unaware** that this concerned him, thought, "**Alas, this must be about the Retired Emperor's plan to attack Mount Hiei**. He must be trying to **persuade him to stop**. He seems to be **deeply angered** (O-ikidōri Fukage nari). It seems **impossible to achieve** (Kanau Majiki Mono o)." He **elegantly dressed** (Taoyaka ni Ki Nashite) in a **newly-ironed court robe** (Naiki-ge naru Hōi), **rode in a fresh carriage**, and, accompanied by **three or four retainers** (Samurai), **even the servants and ox-drivers** (Zasshoku Ushikai) were **dressed better than usual**. He would **only realize this was his last moment** (Saigo to wa Nochi ni Koso Omoi Shire Kere) later. When he **neared Nishi Hachijō**, he saw **warriors filling the area** for **four or five chō** (Shigochō ni Gunpyō Manman Tari). "How **numerous**! What is this?" His **heart was pounding**. He **alighted from his carriage** and **stepped inside the gate**, where he saw that the **interior was also completely filled with warriors** (Gunpyō Hima Wazama mo Naku zo Manman taru). **Frightening-looking warriors** (Kowage naru Bushi-domo) were waiting at the **entrance to the middle gate** (Chūmon no Kuchi). They **seized the Major Counselor by both arms** and said, "**We will bind you** (Shibarō Beshi)." The **Priest Grand Minister of State looked out from behind the blind** (Sudare) and said, "**That cannot be** (Aru Bō mo Nashi)." The **warriors surrounded him** (Zen-go Sayū ni Tachi Kakomi), **pulled him up onto the veranda**, and **confined him in a small room**. The **Major Counselor** felt as if he was in a **dream** (Yume no Kokochi shite) and was **completely bewildered**. The **retainers** who had accompanied him were **separated** and **scattered**. The **servants and ox-drivers turned pale** and **fled**, abandoning the **ox-carriage**.
[2.3.5] Meanwhile, **Middle Captain Ōmi no Nyūdō Renjō**, **Shunkan Sōzu**, **Executive Monk of Hōsshoji Temple**, **Motokane**, **Governor of Yamashiro**, **Masatsuna**, **Major Official of the Ministry of Ceremonial**, **Taira no Hangan Yasuyori**, **Mune no Hangan Nobufusa**, and **New Taira Hangan Sukeyuki** were **also captured** and **brought in**.
[2.3.6] When **Saikō Hōshi heard this**, perhaps thinking it concerned him, he **raised his whip** and **raced to the Retired Emperor's Palace, Hōjūji-dono**. The **Taira retainers** (Heike no Samurai-domo) **raced toward him on the road** and said, "**You are summoned to Nishi Hachijō**. **Come quickly**." He said, "**I have something to report** (Sōsu Beki Koto Arite), so I am **going to Hōjūji-dono**. I will **go later**." They said, "**What a wicked priest!** **What could you possibly report?**" They **pulled him off his horse**, **bound him in the middle**, and **dragged him to Nishi Hachijō**. Since he was a **ringleader** (Negioto no Yoriki no Mono) from the beginning, he was **tightly bound** and **left in the courtyard** (Tsubo no Uchi). The **Priest Grand Minister of State** stood on the **great veranda** and said, "**Behold the appearance of the wretch who sought to overthrow our family!** **Drag him here**." They **dragged him to the edge of the veranda**. He was **gagged** (Mono Haki) and the Priest-Chancellor **angrily trampled his cheek** (Hō o Muzumuzu to zo Fumarekeru). He said, "You are a **low-ranking, dishonest person** (Gezen no Futōnin) whom the **Emperor employed** from the start, **granted undue offices** (Nasu Majiki Kanjō o Nashi Tamai), and who, along with your son, **acted excessively** (Kabun no Furumai o Suru). You **slandered and exiled the innocent Tendai Head Abbot** (Ayamatanu Tendai Zasu) and **caused a great crisis in the realm** (Tenka no Daiji o Hiki Ide-ite). Moreover, you **joined a plot to overthrow our family** (Kono Ichimon Horobosubeki Mubō ni Kumi Shitekeru Yatsu Nari). **Tell me everything**." **Saikō**, being a **man of great courage** (Dai-gō no Mono), did **not change his expression** in the slightest and showed **no sign of fear**. He **sat up** and **scoffed**, saying, "**Indeed, my lord priest** (Nyūdō-dono) **speaks excessively**. I don't know about others, but **you should not say such things in Saikō's presence** (Saikō ga Kikan Tokoro ni Sayō no Koto o ba e Koso Notamau Majikere). Since I am a **servant in the Retired Emperor's Palace** (In-chū ni Meshitsukōruru Mi Nareba), I **could not refuse** to join the matter when **Lord Narichika, the Chief Steward** (Shitsuji no Bettō), **summoned me with an Imperial Edict** (Inzen to Te). I **did join**. However, **what a thing to say that remains in the ear!** You are the **son of the late Minister of the Bureau of Punishments, Tadamori** (Go-Gyōbukyō Tadamori), but until **fourteen or fifteen years old**, you **did not serve in the Palace** (Shutsushi mo Shi Tamawazu). When you **visited the late Middle Counselor Fujiwara no Ienari's residence** (Nakamikado Fujiwara Chūnagon Ienari no Hen ni Tachi-iri Tamawashi), the **people of the capital** called you **Taira no Kōta** (Taka Heita to Koso Iishi ka). In the **Hōen era** (1135–1141), when you were **rewarded for apprehending over thirty ringleaders of pirates** (Kaizoku no Harimoto) as a **Major General** (Daishōgun), you were granted the **Fourth Rank** (Shihon Shite) and became the **Vice Major of the Fourth Rank of the Gate Guards** (Shi-i no Hyōe no Suke). Even that was considered **excessive** by the people of the time. For the **descendant of a man who was even shunned from the Palace's inner circle** (Tenjō no Majiwari o Dani Kiraware Shi Hito no Shison nite) to **ascend to Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin) is **indeed excessive**. There are **precedents and similar cases** (Senrei Bōrei Naki ni wa Arazu) of a **warrior** (Samuraibon no Mono) becoming a **Provincial Governor** (Zuryō) and a **Police and Judicial Official** (Kebii-shi). **Why should it be excessive?**" Since he spoke **without reservation**, the Priest-Chancellor was so **enraged** (Amari ni Ikate) that he **could not say a word**. He only shouted, "**Immediately sever that wretch's head!** **Interrogate him thoroughly!**" **Matsuura Tarō Shigetoshi** (Matsuura Tarō Shigetoshi) obeyed the order and **tormented him brutally by squeezing his limbs** (Ashite o Hazami Sayō ni Tōtō). Since Saikō was **already determined to confess** (Hajime Yori Aragai Mōsan Ue), and the **interrogation was severe**, he **told everything**. He **confessed without reservation**. The confession was **recorded on four or five sheets of paper**. He was immediately **gagged by having his mouth split** (Yatsu ga Kuchi o Sake to te, Kuchi o Sakare) and was **executed at Gojō Suzaku** (Gojō Suzaku nite Kirareni Keri). His **eldest son, former Governor of Kaga Morotaka**, who had been **exiled to Idota in Owari Province**, was **executed** by **Mori Sue**, **District Administrator of Kogoma** (Kogoma no Kōri no Tsukasa), a **resident of the same province**, as ordered. His **second son, Kondō Hangan Morotsune**, who had been **imprisoned**, was **pulled out of prison** and **executed at Rokujō-Gawara** (Rokujō Kawara nite Chūse Raru). His **younger brother, Vice Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards Morihira**, and **three of his retainers** were also **beheaded**. These were **contemptible men** (Iu Gai Naki Mono) who **excelled** and **interfered in matters they should not**, **slandered and exiled the innocent Tendai Head Abbot**, and perhaps because their **good fortune was exhausted** (Kahō ya Tsukini Ken), they **immediately suffered the divine punishment and retribution of Sannō and the Great Master** (Sannō Daishi no Shinbatsu Meibatsu o Tachimachi ni Kōmuri), and **met such a fate**.
2.4. Minor Admonishment
[2.4.1] The **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) was **confined in a small room**, **sweating profusely**, and thinking, "**Alas, the plot that was being planned these days has been leaked!** **Who leaked it?** It must be one of the **Northern Retainers**." He was **lost in such anxious thoughts** when he **heard loud footsteps** (Ashi-oto no Taka-taka ni Shi-kere) from behind. He thought, "**Ah, now the warriors must be coming to take my life!**" He waited, and the **Priest-Chancellor** (Nyūdō) himself **strode loudly across the plank floor** and **suddenly opened the sliding door** (Shōji o Sato Akerareta-ri) behind where the Major Counselor was sitting. He was wearing a **shortened white silk robe** (Soken no Koromo no Mijikaka Naru ni), with a **white Ōkuchi skirt** (Shiroki Ōguchi) tucked in, and a **holy-handled sword** (Hijirie no Katana) worn loosely at his side. He appeared **extremely enraged** (I no Hoka ni Ikareru Keshiki nite) and **stared at the Major Counselor** for a moment, saying, "You were **already about to be executed in the Heiji Rebellion** (Heiji ni mo Sude ni Chū seraru bekarishi o), but the **Inner Minister** (Naifu) **pleaded for you and saved your life**. **What ingratitude!** What **grievance** (Ikon o Motte) did you have that you **plotted to overthrow our family**? A **person who knows gratitude is called a human** (On o Shiru o Hito to wa Iu zo). **A person who does not know gratitude is called a beast** (Chikushō to Koso Ie). However, since the **destiny of our family** (Tō-ke no Unmei) is **not yet exhausted**, you have been **apprehended**. I will **hear directly** (Jikini Uketamawaran) about the **details of your plot** (Go-kekkō no Shidai) these past days." The **Major Counselor** said, "**There is absolutely no such thing**. It must be **someone's slander** (Hito no Zangen nite zo Sōran). Please **investigate thoroughly**." The Priest-Chancellor **did not let him finish his words**. He called out, "**Is anyone there? Is anyone there?**" **Sadayoshi** (Hida no Kami Sadayoshi) came forward. "Bring **Saikō's confession** (Saikō me ga Hakujō Mairase yo)," he ordered. Sadayoshi **brought it**. The Priest-Chancellor **took it, read it out loud two or three times**, and said, "**Alas, how hateful! What more can you plead?**" He **angrily threw the paper at the Major Counselor's face** (O-kao ni Sato Nage Kakete), **slammed the sliding door shut**, and **departed**. The Priest-Chancellor was **still furious** and called out, "**Tsune-to, Kane-yasu!**" **Seo Tarō** (Seo Tarō) and **Nanba Jirō** (Nanba Jirō) came forward. "Seize that man (Ano Otoko Torite) and **drag him into the courtyard** (Niwa e Hiki Otose)," he ordered. The two **did not immediately obey** and said, "**How will Lord Komatsu react?**" The **Priest Grand Minister of State** was **greatly enraged** and said, "**Very well! Very well!** You **value the Inner Minister's** (Naifu) **command** and **disregard the priest's command**. This is how you are! In that case, **I can do no more**." Thinking this might lead to trouble, the **two men stood up** and **dragged the Major Counselor into the courtyard**. At that moment, the **Priest-Chancellor** looked **satisfied** and said, "**Grab him, pin him down, and make him scream** (Torite Fusete, Wameka se yo)." The **two men put their mouths to the Major Counselor's ears** and whispered, "**You must scream no matter what** (Ikanaru Yō ni mo O-koe no Izu beu Sōrō)," and **pinned him down**. The Major Counselor **screamed two or three times**. It seemed that the **torment inflicted by the demons and ogres** (Abō Rasetsu ga Kashaku Suran) on the **sinners of the human world** (Shaba Sekai no Tsumibito) in the underworld, whether by **weighing their karma** (Gō no Hakari ni Kake) or **facing them in the mirror of crystal** (Jō Harari Kagami ni Hiki Mukōte), **according to the severity of their sins**, could **not surpass this**. This was like **Xiao and Fan being imprisoned** (Shō Han Toraware), and **Han and Peng being minced and pickled** (Kan Hō Soshai Tari) (alluding to historical figures in China). It was like **Cháo Cuò being executed** (Chōsaku Ruku o Ukete) and **Zhōu Yí being punished**. For example, **Xiao He, Fan Kuai, Han Xin, and Peng Yue** were all **loyal ministers of Emperor Gaozu**, but due to the **slander of lesser men**, they suffered **disgrace and defeat**. This is what such events should be called.
[2.4.2] As the **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) suffered this fate, he **worried about his children**, especially **Tanba Minor Captain Naritsune** and the other **young ones**, wondering **what would become of them**. In the **scorching sixth month**, he could **not even loosen his clothing** (Shōzoku Dani o Kutsu-rogezu), and the **heat was unbearable**. His **chest felt constricted** (Mune Seki Agaru Kokochi shite), and **sweat and tears flowed profusely**. He thought, "**Surely, Lord Komatsu** (Komatsu-dono) **will not abandon me!**" but he **could not think of anyone to send a message** to him.
[2.4.3] **Major Minister Komatsu** (Shigemori), **much later**, **sat on the back of the carriage** with his **eldest son, Vice Commander and Minor Captain Koremori** (Gon no Shōshō), accompanied by **four or five Imperial Guard Officials** (Efu) and **two or three personal guards** (Zuishin), **without a single warrior** (Heii Hitori mo) in his entourage. He was **exceptionally composed** (Koto ni Ōyōge de Zo O-mashitari). The **Priest-Chancellor** (Nyūdō) and others were **all surprised** to see him. When he **alighted from the carriage**, **Sadayoshi** (Hida no Kami Sadayoshi) came forward and said, "**Why have you not brought a single warrior** (Gunpyō o ba Hitori mo Meshi-gu serare Sōrawanu zo) for such a **great crisis** (Kono Hodo no Go-daiji ni)?" Shigemori replied, "**A great crisis** (Daiji) is spoken of for a **national emergency** (Tenka no Daiji). Why should such a **private matter** (Kono Watakushi-goto) be called a great crisis?" The **warriors** (Heii-domo) who were carrying weapons **looked disheartened** (Sozoroite zo Miek-eru). He wondered, "**Where is the Major Counselor confined?**" He **opened the sliding doors one after another** (Shōji Hiki Ake Hiki Akete) and saw a **place where spiderwebs were woven** (Kumode Yu-taru Tokoro ari) on one of the doors. He **opened it**, thinking, "It must be here," and the **Major Counselor was sitting there**. He was **choked with tears**, **bent over**, and **could not meet his eyes**. Shigemori said, "**What is wrong?**" When the Major Counselor saw him, his **joyful expression** was **piteous**, as if a **sinner in hell** (Jigoku nite Tsumibito-domo) had **seen Jizō Bosatsu** (Jizō Bosatsu o Mi Tatema-tsururan). He said, "**For what reason** (Nanigoto nite Sōrō Yaran) **do I suffer this fate**? Now that you have come, I **rely on you** (Sari to mo to Koso Tanomi Mairasete Sōrae). In the **Heiji Rebellion**, I was **about to be executed**, but by **your favor**, my **head was saved**. I have **ascended to Junior Second Rank Major Counselor**, and my **age already exceeds forty**. Your **kindness** (Go-on) is **impossible to repay** (Hōji Tsukushi Gatō Sōrae) even in **this life and the next**. This time also, please **save this worthless life** (Kaih Naki Inochi o Tasuke Sase O-mase). If I live, I will **become a monk and enter the priesthood** (Shukke Nyūdō shite), **seclude myself in Kōya or Kōkawa** (Kōya Kōkawa ni Komori), and **devote myself to seeking salvation in the next life** (Gose Bodai no Tsutome o Itonami Sōran)." Shigemori replied, "**Surely, your life will not be taken**. Even if it were, **Shigemori is here** and **will exchange my life for yours** (Go-inochi ni mo Kawari Tatema-tsuru Beshi)." He then **departed**. He **sat before his father**, the **Priest-Chancellor** (Zenmon), and said, "The **execution of Lord Narichika** (Ano Narichika Kyō) should be **carefully considered** (Yoku Yoku O-hakari Sōrau Beshi). His **ancestor, Shuri no Daibu Akisue**, was employed by the **Retired Emperor Shirakawa** (Shirakawa-in) and he himself **ascended to Junior Second Rank Major Counselor**, a rank **unprecedented in his family**. He is the **Emperor's most beloved** (Kimi Musō no O-itowoshimi). **How could his head be immediately severed?** It would be **sufficient** if he is **expelled from the capital** (Miyako no Soto e Dasaretaran ni Koto Tari Sōnan). **Kitano Tenjin** (Sugawara no Michizane) suffered **disgrace** (Uki Na o) **borne by the waves of the four seas** due to the **slander of Minister Tokihira**. The **Minister of Nishinomiya** (Fujiwara no Takanobu) had his **resentment attached to the clouds of San'yō** (Urami o San'yō no Kumo ni Yosu) due to the **slander of Tada Mitsunaka**. Although both were **innocent**, they were **exiled**. It is said that these were the **errors of the Holy Reign of Engi** (Engi no Seidai) and the **Emperor of Anna** (An'na no Go-koto). Even in **ancient times** (Jōko) it was like this. How much more so in the **latter age** (Matsudai ni Oite o ya)? Since he is **already apprehended**, what **trouble** (Nan no Kurushimi ka Sōrau Beki) is there if he is **not executed immediately**? It is written, '**Lessen the punishment for doubtful crimes** (Kei no Utagawashiki o ba Karunze yo). **Increase the reward for doubtful merits** (Kō no Utagawashiki o ba Om-ze yo).**' It may seem strange, but I am **married to the sister of that Major Counselor**. **Koremori** is also his **son-in-law**. You may think I am pleading for him because we are **so close** (Kono Yō ni Shitashiku Narite Sōraeba). That is **not the case**. I am speaking for the **sake of the realm, the Emperor, and our family** (Yo no Tame Kimi no Tame Ie no Tame no Koto o Motte Mōsu Sōrō). Last year, when the **late Minor Counselor Priest Shinzei** was in power, it was said that his **administration was excessive** (Amari naru O-matsurigoto to Koso Oboesōrōshika) when he **first carried out an execution** (Shizai o Hajimete Shikkō-shi) that had **not been performed for twenty-five reigns** (Ni-jū Go-dai no Aida) since **Emperor Saga's** time when **Fujiwara no Nakanari**, **Head of the Right Gate Guards**, was executed, and when he **dug up the corpse of the wicked Vice Minister of the Left of Uji** (Uji no Aku Safu no Shigai o Hori Okoite) for **post-mortem inspection**. Therefore, the **people of old** said, "**If executions are performed, traitors in the realm will never cease**." Following those words, the **world was again plunged into chaos two years later** in the **Heiji Rebellion**. Shinzei's buried body was **dug up, his head was severed**, and it was **paraded through the main street**. I was **frightened**, thinking that the **deeds performed in Hōgen** had **returned to him** so soon. This man is **not such a great enemy of the court** (Saseru Chōteki ni mo Arazu). This is **surely alarming**. Since your **glory** (Go-eiga) is **already complete** (Nokoru Tokoro Nake-reba), you may **not have any desires**, but the **prosperity of your descendants** (Koshi Son-son) **should be wished for**. It is said that the **good and evil of the father and ancestor surely affect the descendants** (Fuso no Zen'aku wa Kanarazu Shison ni Oyobu to Miete Sōrō). I have heard that '**A family that accumulates good deeds will surely have abundant blessings** (Sekizen no Ie Kanarazu Yokei Ari). **A family that accumulates evil will surely have residual calamity** (Sekiaku no Mon ni wa Kanarazu Yoō Todomaru) **remain**.' In any case, it is **improper** (Shikaru Beu Sōrawazu) for his **head to be severed tonight**." The **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Nyūdō Shōkoku) perhaps **agreed**, and he **gave up the thought of execution**.
[2.4.4] Afterward, the **Minister** (Shigemori) **went out to the middle gate** and **ordered the warriors** (Samurai-domo), saying, "You **must not execute the Major Counselor easily**, just because you were **ordered to** (Ōse Nare ba to Te). If the Priest-Chancellor **acts wildly in his anger**, he will **surely regret it later**. **Do not commit a wrongful act** and **incur my resentment** (Urami-na)." The **warriors** (Heii-domo) all **trembled in fear**. Shigemori said, "**It is still strange** that **Tsune-to and Kane-yasu acted so harshly** toward the Major Counselor this morning. **Why did you not show respect** when you **knew that Shigemori would hear of it**? This is what **country people** (Kata Inaka no Mono) are like." Both **Nanba and Seo** were **terrified**. The **Minister** spoke thus and **returned to Komatsu-dono**. Meanwhile, the **retainers** who had accompanied the Major Counselor **raced back to the Nakamikado Karasuma residence** and reported this. The **Northern Lady** (Kitano Kata) and the other **court ladies** (Nyōbō-domo) **wept and cried out without restraint**. They said, "**Warriors are already approaching** (Samurai no Mukai Sōrō). I hear that the **young lords** (Kimi-dachi), starting with the **Minor Captain** (Shōshō-dono), are **also to be captured**. **Hurry and hide yourselves** (Shinobase Tamae) **wherever you can**." The Northern Lady said, "**Now that I am in this state**, what use is it to **remain safely**? I only wish to **perish like the dew of the same night** (Onaji Ichiyoru no Tsuyu to mo Ken Koto Koso Hon'i Nare)." She added, "**How sad it is that I did not know this morning would be the last!**" and **wept and wallowed on the ground**. Since it was rumored that **warriors were already approaching**, and it was **disgraceful and shameful to suffer another fate like this**, she **put her daughter**, who was **ten years old**, and her **son**, who was **eight years old**, **into a carriage** and **sent them off** to an **unknown destination**. Since it could not be helped, they went **north on Ōmiya Avenue** and **hid near Kurin-in Temple** (Unrin-in e zo O-zashikeru) on **Mount Kita** (Kita Yama no Hen). They **alighted** at a **monk's quarter** (Sōbō) nearby. The **attendants** (Okuri no Mono-domo), unwilling to **sacrifice themselves**, **asked for leave and returned**. The **Northern Lady's feelings** (Kitano Kata no Kokoro no Uchi) are **piteous to imagine**, as she was **left with only her young children**, and **no one to even talk to**. Seeing the **evening shadows deepen**, she felt that the **Major Counselor's fleeting life** (Tsuyu no Inochi) would **end this very night**, and she was **overwhelmed with grief**. Although there were **many ladies and retainers**, **not a single item was packed**, and **not a single gate was shut**. The **horses stood lined up in the stable**, but **not a single person was feeding them grass**. **Yesterday**, the **carriages lined up at the gate in the morning**, **guests filled the seats**, and they **played games and danced**, not caring about the world. **Close neighbors** (Chikaki Katawara no Hito) did **not even speak loudly** and were in **awe**. The **change overnight** showed that the **principle that the prosperous must decline** (Jōsha Hissui no Kotowari) was **manifest right before their eyes**. The **handwriting of Minister Jiang** (Kōshōkō no Fude no Ato) which wrote "**Joy ends and sorrow comes**" (Tanoshi-mi Tsukite Aishimi Kitaru) must have been **understood now**.
2.5. Minor Captain's Entreaty
[2.5.1] **Tanba Minor Captain Naritsune** (Naritsune) had **stayed and slept at the Retired Emperor's Palace, Hōjūji-dono**, that night and had **not yet departed**. The **Major Counselor's retainers** (Dainagon no Samurai-domo) **raced to the Palace**, **summoned the Minor Captain**, and **reported the situation**. The Minor Captain had **not yet finished speaking** when he was interrupted, thinking, "**Why did the Counsellor** (Saishō) **not inform me until now?**" Then a **messenger arrived** from the **Counsellor**. This **Counsellor** (Saishō) was the **Priest Grand Minister of State's younger brother**, and since his **residence** (Shukusho) was **inside the main gate of Rokuhara**, he was called the **Gate-Side Counsellor** (Kadowaki no Saishō). He was the **father-in-law of Tanba Minor Captain**. The messenger said, "**The Priest Grand Minister of State has ordered that the Tanba Minor Captain be brought to Nishi Hachijō immediately** (Kito Nishi Hachijō e Gūshi Tatema-tsure to Sōrō)." The **Minor Captain understood this** and **summoned the close court ladies** (Kinjū no Nyōbō-domo), saying, "Last night, the **world seemed restless** (Yo no Mono Sawō Sōrōshi o), and I thought it was just the **usual mountain monks descending**, but it **concerns me, Naritsune** (Waga mi no Ue nite Sōrai Keri). The **Major Counselor** is likely to be **executed tonight**, so **I will also be an accomplice** (Dōzai nite Koso Sōranzure). I wish to **visit the Palace once more and see the Emperor** (Kimi o mo Mi Mairasetō Sōrae), but since I am **already in this state**, I **hesitate to do so**." The **court ladies went before the Emperor** and **reported this to the throne**. The **Retired Emperor** was **greatly surprised**, thinking, "As I **suspected** from the Priest Grand Minister of State's messenger this morning, the **plot that those people secretly planned has leaked!**" and was **dismayed**. However, he said, "**Come here** (Kore e to)," with a **favorable expression**, so the Minor Captain **went before him**. The **Retired Emperor** also **shed tears** and **gave no instruction**. The **Minor Captain** was also **choked with tears** and **could not say a word**. After a **long silence**, since he could not remain there, the Minor Captain **pressed his sleeve to his face** and **departed weeping**. The **Retired Emperor looked after him for a long time**, thinking, "**The latter age** (Matsudai) **is truly distressing**. I wonder if I will **never see him again**." He **shed tears**, which was truly **awe-inspiring**. The **people in the Palace** (In-chū no Hitobito) **held his sleeves** and **clung to his lapels** (Tamoto ni Sugatte), regretting the parting. There was **no one who did not shed tears**.
[2.5.2] When he went to his **father-in-law the Counsellor's residence**, his **Northern Lady** (Kitano Kata) was about to **give birth** (Chikō Nasu Beki Hito nite O-zashikeru). With the **added grief** (Uchi Zōete) of this morning's events, she felt as if her **life was about to expire**. The **Minor Captain** had been **shedding endless tears** since leaving the Palace. Seeing his wife's condition, he was **even more helpless**. The **Minor Captain's nurse** (Uba) was a court lady named **Rokujō**. She said, "Since I began to **serve as your wet nurse** (O-chichi ni Mairi Hajime Sōraite), I **held you from infancy** (Ochhi no Naka Yori), and as the **months and days passed**, I **did not lament my advancing age**, but **rejoiced only in your growing up** (Seinin Shiu Narase Tamau Koto o). Although I thought it was a **passing phase**, it has been **twenty-one years**, and I have **not been separated from you for a single moment** (Katatoki mo Hanare Mairasezu). Even when you **went to the Palace** and **returned late**, I was **uneasy**. **What fate will you meet now?**" She **wept**. The **Minor Captain** comforted her, saying, "**Don't grieve so much**. Since the **Counsellor** (Saishō) **is here**, he will **surely beg for my life**." But she **wept and wailed uncontrollably**.
[2.5.3] Since **messengers kept arriving** from **Nishi Hachijō Palace**, the **Counsellor** said, "**I must go there** and **settle this somehow** (Tomokaku mo Narame)." He **departed**, and the **Minor Captain rode behind the Counsellor's carriage**. Since the **Hōgen and Heiji Rebellions**, the **Taira family** had only experienced **joy and prosperity** (Tanoshimi Sakae) and **no sorrow**, but only this **Counsellor** suffered such **grief** (Kakarur Nageki o ba Serare Kere) because of his **useless son-in-law** (Yona-ki Mukō Yue ni). When they **neared Nishi Hachijō**, they **stopped the carriage**, and the **Counsellor first announced his arrival**. The **Priest Grand Minister of State** said, "**The Tanba Minor Captain must not enter this palace** (Kono Uchi e wa Iraru Beka-razu)." The Minor Captain was **taken down** (Oroshi Oki-tsutsu) at a **nearby retainer's house**, and **only the Counsellor** (Saishō Bakari zo) **entered the gate**. **Warriors immediately surrounded** the Minor Captain and **guarded him**. He was **separated from the Counsellor** (Tanomaretsuru Saishō-dono ni wa Hanare Tamainu), whom he had relied on. The **Minor Captain's feelings** (Shōshō no Kokoro no Uchi) must have been **greatly disheartened**. The **Counsellor** sat at the **middle gate**, but the Priest-Chancellor **would not see him** (Taimen mo Shi Tamawazu). He sent **Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Suesada** (Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Suesada o Motte) to relay the message, saying, "I **regret** (Kuyashiu Sōrae) having such a **relationship with a useless person**, but it **cannot be helped** (Kai mo Sōrawazu). My wife (Sōgusese Sete Sōrō Mono no) is **suffering from a sickness** (Nayamu Koto no Sōrau Naru ga) these days, and with the **added grief** of this morning, her **life is about to expire**. What **harm** (Nanika wa Kurushiu Sōrau Beki) is there? Please **let me keep the Minor Captain** (Shōshō o ba Shibaraku Norimori ni Azukase O-mase) **for a while**. Since **Norimori is here**, **how could he commit any wrongful act** (Naji ka wa Hekigoto Sesase Sōrau Beki)?" **Suesada** went and **relayed this message**. The Priest-Chancellor thought, "**Alas, the Counsellor is still ignorant!**" and **did not reply immediately**. After a **long while**, the Priest-Chancellor said, "The **New Major Counselor Narichika** has a **plot to overthrow our family** and **cause disorder in the realm**. This **Minor Captain** (Shōshō) is **his legitimate son**. Whether he is **distant or close**, I **cannot easily forgive him** (e Koso Mōshi Yurumu Majikere). **Tell him that if this plot had succeeded, would he have been safe?**" **Suesada returned** and **reported this to the Counsellor**. The Counsellor was **truly disappointed** (Hon'i Nage nite) and **pleaded again**, saying, "Since the **Hōgen and Heiji Rebellions**, I have **vowed to give my life** (Go-inochi ni Kawari Mairasen to Koso Zonji Sōrae) for you in the **many battles**. In the future also, I will **be the first to defend you against any harsh wind** (Araki Kaze o ba Saki Fusegi Mairase Sōranzuru ni). Although **Norimori is old**, he has **many young children**, so **how can he not be a protector** (Kata En no O-katame ni wa Nado ka Nari de Sōrau Beki)? If you **refuse** to let me **keep Naritsune for a while**, it must be because you **believe Norimori is a traitor** (Ni-shin Aru Mono to Omoi Meshi ni Koso). If I am **mistrusted to this extent** (Kore Hodo Ushiro-me Tau Omoware Mairasete wa), what **use is there in remaining in the world** (Yo ni Atte mo Nanika wa Shi Sōrau Beki)? Now, I will **request my leave** (Mi no Itoma o Tamawatte), **become a monk and enter the priesthood**, **seclude myself in a mountain village** (Kata Yamato ni Komorite), and **devote myself single-mindedly to seeking salvation in the next life**. This is a **useless, sorrowful relationship** (Yona-ki Uki Yo no Majiwari). If I remain in the world, I will have **desires**, and if my desires are **not fulfilled**, I will have **resentment**. It is better to **reject this sorrowful world** (Uki Yo o Itoi) and **enter the true path** (Shin no Michi ni Iranan ni wa)." **Suesada returned** and said, "**The Counsellor has already made up his mind** (Omoi Meshi Kiri-te Sōrō zo). **Please decide this wisely** (Tomo Kaku mo Yoki Yō ni O-hakari Sōrae)." The **Priest-Chancellor** was **greatly surprised** and said, "It is **too much to become a monk and enter the priesthood!** In that case, **tell him that he can keep the Minor Captain for a while**." **Suesada returned** and **reported this to the Counsellor**. The Counsellor said, "**Alas, one should not have children!** If I were **not bound by my child's relationship**, I would **not have to suffer such distress** (Kore Hodo Kokoro o ba Kudaji Mono o)." He then **departed**.
[2.5.4] The **Minor Captain awaited his return** and asked, "**Well, what happened?**" The Counsellor replied, "The **Priest-Chancellor was too angry** and **would not even see Norimori**. He **repeatedly said it was impossible**, but perhaps because I mentioned **becoming a monk and entering the priesthood**, he said I **could keep him at my residence for a while**, but I **don't think this will be the end of it**." The Minor Captain said, "**If that is the case, Naritsune will be granted a temporary extension of life** (Shibashi no Inochi mo Inochi mo Nobi Sōranzuru ni Koso) **by your kindness**. On that note, **what did you hear about the Major Counselor's situation?**" The Counsellor said, "**I did not even think to ask about that**." The Minor Captain **shed tears profusely** and said, "**It is true that I am grateful for the temporary extension of life** (Shibashi no Inochi mo Iki Sōranzuru Koto wa Shikaru Beu Sōrae Domo) **by your kindness**, but the **reason I value my life** is that I wish to **see my father one more time** (Chichi o Ima Hito-tabi Miba ya to Omou Tame Nari). If the **Major Counselor is executed**, what **use is there for Naritsune to live this worthless life**? Couldn't you **plead** (Mōshite Tabase Tamau Beu ya Sōran) for us to be **together** and let the fate **be decided as it may** (Ika Naru Yō ni mo Naru Yō ni)?**" The **Counsellor** looked **greatly distressed** (Yo ni mo Kurushi-ge nite) and said, "**Indeed! I have only been pleading for you**. I **did not even think to ask about that**, but this morning the **Inner Minister** (Uchi no Daijin) **pleaded for the Major Counselor in various ways** (Sayō ni Mōsar-ere ba), so I heard that **his situation is also temporarily relieved**." The Minor Captain **clapped his hands weeping** and **rejoiced**. The Counsellor thought, "**If he were not my child**, who would be so **joyful about my situation**, putting aside his **own immediate plight** (Waga Mi no Ue o Sashi Oite) to this extent? The **true bond** (Jitsu no Chigiri) is **between parent and child**." He **immediately changed his mind**. Then they **returned together in the same carriage** as that morning. At the **residence**, the **court ladies** (Nyōbō-domo) felt as if a **dead person had come back to life** and **gathered together**, **weeping with joy**.
2.6. Letter of Admonishment
[2.6.1] The **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Nyūdō) had **apprehended so many people** (Hitobito Amata Shime Okite mo) and was **still not satisfied** (Nao Kokoro Yuku ya Omoware Ken). He was wearing a **scarlet brocade court robe** (Akaji no Nishiki no Hitatare) and a **black silk-laced cuirass** (Kuro Ito Odoshi no Haramaki) with a **breastplate decorated with platinum** (Shirokane Mono Uchi Taru Muna-ita Semete). The **small, silver-lacquered long sword** (Gin no Hirumaki Shitaru Konaginata) that he had **received directly from the Great Deity of Itsukushima** (Itsukushima no Daimyōjin) after receiving a **divine dream** (Reimu o Kōmuri) during a **pilgrimage** (Kami Mairi no Toki) when he was **Governor of Aki** (Aki no Kami), and which he **always kept near his pillow**, was now **tucked under his arm**. He then **went out to the middle gate corridor**. His **appearance was generally solemn** (Ōkata Yuyushiu zo Miek-eshi). He **summoned Sadayoshi** (Hida no Kami Sadayoshi). **Sadayoshi**, **Governor of Chikugo**, was wearing a **brownish-yellow court robe** (Mokuranji no Hitatare) and **scarlet-laced armor** (Hi Odoshi no Yoroi) and **knelt respectfully** (Oshikote Sōrō) before him. The Priest-Chancellor **spoke slowly** and deliberately, saying, "Sadayoshi, **what do you think of this matter?** In the **Hōgen Rebellion**, **Taira no Uma no Suke** (Taira no Uma no Suke, Tadamasa) and **more than half the family joined the New Retired Emperor's side** (Shin'in no O-kata e). Although the **First Imperial Prince** was the **foster son of the late Minister of the Bureau of Punishments** (Go-Gyōbukyō Tono no Yō-kun nite O-zaishi ka ba), and it was **difficult to completely abandon him**, I **took the lead** and was **on the Emperor's side** (Go-kata nite Saki o Kaketari ki) **according to the late Retired Emperor's will** (Kyo-in no Go-yuikai ni Makasete). This was the **greatest service** (Ichi no Hōkō). Next, in the **twelfth month of Heiji 1** (1159), **Nobuyori and Yoshitomo seized the Retired Emperor's Palace** (In-nai o Tori Tatema-tsuri), **confined themselves in the Imperial Palace** (Ōuchi ni Tate Komori), and the **realm was plunged into darkness** (Tenka Koku-an to Narishi). I **risked my life** (Mi o Sutete), **drove out the rebels** (Kyōto o Oi Otoshi), and even **apprehended Tsunemune and Korekata** (Tsunemune Korekata o Meshi Shibarishi ni Itaru Made). I have **often risked my life for the Emperor's sake**. Even if people say otherwise, **how can I abandon this family for seven generations** (Nanada made wa Kono Ichimon o ba Azade ka Sute Sase Tamau Beki)? Yet, the **Retired Emperor's plot to overthrow our family** (Hōō no Go-kekkō Koso Ikon no Shidai Nare), by being persuaded by that **useless fool Narichika** (Muyō no Tsuwamono) and that **low-ranking, dishonest person Saikō** (Gezen no Futōnin), is **truly regrettable**. If any **slanderous person** (Zanzō suru Mono) appears again, I believe an **Imperial Edict to launch a punitive expedition against our family** (Tō-ke Tsuibō no Inzen) will be issued. Once we become **enemies of the court** (Chōteki to Nate nochi wa), **regret will be useless**. To **pacify the realm** (Yo o Shizumen Hodo), should I **transfer the Retired Emperor to the Northern Palace of Toba** (Toba no Kita-dono e Utsushi Tatematsuru ka), or **summon him here** (Kore e Mare) and **let him visit this palace** (Go-kō o Nashi Mairasen to Omou wa Ikani)? If that happens, the **Northern Retainers** (Hokumen no Yarai) will **surely shoot an arrow** (Ya o mo Hitotsu Inzuran). You should **inform the warriors** (Samurai-domo) to **be prepared** (Sono Yōi seyo). I have generally **given up my loyalty** (Hōkō Omoi Kiritari) to the Retired Emperor. **Saddle the horses!** (Uma ni Kura Okase yo). **Bring out the battle robe** (Kisenaga Tori Dase)!" He **shouted** thus.
[2.6.2] **Mōrikuni**, **Hangan of the Bureau of Horse Administration**, **raced to Komatsu-dono** (Shigemori's residence) and said, "**The world is already in this state!**" The **Minister** (Shigemori) **could not bear to hear it**. He said, "**Alas, has Lord Narichika's head been severed already?**" Mōrikuni replied, "**No, but the Priest-Chancellor is wearing a battle robe** (O-kisenaga Mesare Sōrō). The **warriors** (Samurai-domo) are all **standing ready** (Uchi Tatete) to **march on Hōjūji-dono Palace**. They intend to **confine the Retired Emperor** (Hōō o ba Toba-dono e Oshi Komori Mairase u to Sōrō ga) in the **Toba Palace** (Toba-dono), and are even **planning to exile him to Kyūshū** (Chinzei no Hō e Nagashi Mairase u to Go-gisa Sōrō) privately." The **Minister** (Shigemori) thought, "How can such a thing happen?" but from the **Priest-Chancellor's behavior** (Zenmon no Keshiki) this morning, he realized that **such a mad thing was possible**. He **flew in his carriage** to **Nishi Hachijō**.
[2.6.3] He **alighted from his carriage** outside the gate. When he **entered the gate**, the **Priest-Chancellor** (Nyūdō) was wearing a **cuirass** (Haramaki). **Dozens of family court nobles and high officials** (Ichimon no Kyōshō Unkyaku) were **seated in two rows** on the middle gate corridor, each wearing **various court robes** (Iro-iro no Hitatare) and their **own armor**. In addition, **Provincial Governors and Imperial Guard Officials** (Shokoku no Zuryō Efu Shoshi) were **crowding onto the veranda**, and **packed closely together in the courtyard**. The **flagpoles** were **tucked in close**, the **horses' girths were tightened**, and the **helmet cords were shortened**. They **all looked ready to march out immediately**. The **arrival of Lord Komatsu** (Komatsu-dono), rustling in his **court hat, formal court robe** (Eboshi Nōshi ni), and **wide-patterned long hunting trousers** (Ōmon no Sashinuki no Sobatori-te) that were **tucked up at the sides**, seemed **extremely out of place**.
[2.6.4] The **Priest-Chancellor** (Nyūdō) had his **eyes half-closed** (Fushi Me ni Natte). He thought, "**Alas, the Inner Minister** (Naifu) **is acting so aloofly** (Yo o Hyōsuru Yō ni Furumai) that I would **like to severely admonish him** (Ōi ni Isame ba ya to Koso Omoware Keme Domo)." But since Shigemori was his **son**, and he was a man who **kept the Five Precepts** (Go-kai o Tamotte Jihiki o Saki to Shi) and **prioritized compassion internally**, and **outwardly upheld the Five Constants** (Gojō o Midarezu) and **maintained strict propriety** (Reigi o Tadashiu Shi Tamau), he must have **felt shame and embarrassment** (Omo wa Reken) to face him **wearing a cuirass** (Haramaki). He **opened the sliding door slightly** and **hastily wore a white silk robe** (Soken no Koromo o Haramaki no Ue ni) **over his cuirass**. He was **frequently pulling and crossing the chest of his robe** (Koromo no Mune o Hiki Chigae Hiki Chigae zo Shi Tamawari Keru) to **hide the platinum fittings** (Kanemono no Sukoshi Hazurete Miek-eru) on his breastplate. The **Minister** (Shigemori) **sat above his younger brother, Lord Munemori** (Munemori Kyō no Za Ue ni Tsukitama-u). The Priest-Chancellor **did not speak first**, nor did the Minister **speak first**.
[2.6.5] After a **long while**, the **Priest-Chancellor** said, "**Lord Narichika's plot** (Narichika Kyō ga Mubō) is **nothing to worry about** (Koto no Kazu ni mo Arazu). It was **entirely the Retired Emperor's plot** (Hōō no Go-kekkō nite Arik-eru zo ya). To **pacify the realm**, should I **transfer the Retired Emperor to the Northern Palace of Toba**, or **summon him here** and **let him visit this palace**? **What do you think?**" The **Minister** (Shigemori) **could not bear to hear it** and **wept profusely**. The Priest-Chancellor was **astonished** and said, "**What is wrong? What is wrong?**" The **Minister** (Shigemori) **suppressed his tears** and replied, "Hearing that command, I believe our **good fortune is already coming to an end** (Go-un wa Hayashi Sue ni Narinu to Oboesōrō). When a **person's destiny is about to decline**, they **surely plot wicked things** (Kanarazu Akuji o Omoi Tatsu Sōrō Nari). Your **appearance** (O-arisama) also **does not seem real** (Sara ni Utsutsu tomo Oboesōrawazu). Although our country is a **borderland of scattered millet**, the **descendants of Amaterasu Ōmikami** (Amaterasu Ōmikami no Mishison) have been the **sovereigns of the nation** (Kuni no Aruji to shite). The **descendants of Ameno Koyane no Mikoto** (Ameno Koyane no Mikoto no Sue) have **governed the Imperial Court** (Asa no Matsurigoto o Tsukasadōri Tamawishi) since that time. Is it **not a breach of propriety** (Reigi o Soni ni Arazu ya) for a person who has attained the **rank of Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Daijin no Kan ni Itaru Hito) to **don armor and helmet** (Katchū o Yorou)? Moreover, you are a **priest** (Go-shukke no Mi Nari). If you **cast aside the robes of liberation** (Gedatsu Sōzō no Hōe o Nugi Sutete) of the **Buddhas of the three worlds** (Sanze no Sho-butsu) and **immediately don armor and helmet** (Katchū o Yoroi), **gird on bows and arrows** (Yumi Ya o Obashi Masan Koto), not only will you **incur the internal sin of breaking the precepts and shamelessness** (Hakai Muzan no Tsumi o Maneku Nomi Narazu), but **outwardly** you will also **violate the law of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trustworthiness** (Jingi Reichi Shin no Hō ni mo Somaki Sōnan). Although this is a **very presumptuous thing to say**, I **must not hold back the truth in my heart**. There are the **Four Obligations** (Shi-on) of the past life. These are the **Obligation to Heaven and Earth** (Tenchi no On), the **Obligation to the Sovereign** (Ō-kō no On), the **Obligation to Parents** (Fubo no On), and the **Obligation to all Sentient Beings** (Shūjō no On). Among them, the **Imperial Obligation** (Chō-on) is the **most important** (Saimottomo Omo-ki wa). It is said that **every place under heaven is the sovereign's territory** (Futten no Shita Ōchi ni Arazu to Iu Koto Nashi). Therefore, I have heard that even **wise men** who **washed their ears in the Ying River** (Eizen no Mizu ni Mimi o Arai) and **picked ferns on Mount Shouyang** (Shuyō-zan ni Warabi o Orishi Kenjin mo) **understood the propriety of not disobeying the Imperial Command**. How much more so for you, who have **attained the rank of Grand Minister of State**, which was **unprecedented** even for your **ancestors**. Furthermore, I, **Shigemori**, with my **lack of talent and ignorance**, have **reached the position of Minister and General** (Renpu Kaimon no Kurai). In addition, **more than half the provinces** (Kokugun Han Sugite) are the **territories of our family** (Ichimon no Shoryō to Nari), and the **fields and gardens** (Den'en) are **entirely under the control of a single family** (Ikka no Shinshi). Is this **not an unprecedented Imperial Obligation**? If you **forget these immense favors** (Baidai no Go-on o Omoi Wasurete) and **wantonly overthrow the Retired Emperor** (Midarashiku Hōō o Katamuke Mairase Tamawan Koto), you will be **going against the divine will of Amaterasu Ōmikami and Hachiman Great Bodhisattva** (Amaterasu Ōmikami Shō Hachiman-gū no Shinryo ni mo Somaki Sōinan). **Japan is the Land of the Gods** (Shinkoku Nari). The **Gods do not accept disrespect** (Shin wa Hirei o Uke Tamawazu). Therefore, the **Emperor's thought** (Kimi no Omoi Tatsu Tokoro) is **not entirely unreasonable** (Dōri Han naku ni wa Arazu). Moreover, our family has **pacified successive enemies of the court** (Yoyo no Chōteki o Tairagete) and **calmed the rebellious waves of the four seas** (Shikai no Gyakuron o Shizumuru Koto wa Musō no Chū Nare Domo). However, **boasting about the reward** (Sono Shō ni Hokoru Koto wa) could be called **shameless and arrogant** (Bōjakubujin to mo Mōsu Beshi). The **Constitution of Prince Shōtoku** (Shōtoku Taishi Jūshichikajō no Go-kenpō ni) states, '**All men have hearts** (Hito Mina Kokoro Ari). **They surely have their own assertions** (Kanarazu Kaku Onozuno Shitsu Ari). **They assert his right and my wrong, and my right and his wrong** (Kare o Zeshi Ware o Hi shi, Ware o Zeshi Kare o Hi su). **Who can truly determine the right and wrong?** (Zehhi no Kotowari Dare ka Yoku Sadamu Beki). **We are all wise and foolish alike** (Ai Tomo ni Ken Gu Nari). **It is like a ring, having no end** (Wa no Gotoku shite Tan nashi). **Therefore, even if others are angry, you should instead fear your own faults** (Hito Ikaru to Iu Tomo, Kaete Waga Toga o Osore yo).**' However, since your **destiny is not yet exhausted** (Go-un Tsukizaru ni Yotte), the **plot has already been revealed**. Since the **apprehension of Lord Narichika** (Narichika Kyō o Meshi Okurenu-ru Ue wa) has been carried out, even if the **Emperor plans some unforeseen event** (Kimi Ikanaru Fushigi o Omoimeshi Tatemau tomo), **what fear is there?** After the **due punishment for the crime** (Shotō no Tsumi-ka Okonawaren Ue wa) is carried out, you should **withdraw and explain the situation to the Emperor** (Shirizokite Koto no Yosi o Chinji Mōsasare Tamau te). If you **further devote yourself to loyal service to the Emperor** (Kimi no Go-tame ni wa Iya Hōkō no Chūkin o Tsukushi) and **show even greater mercy and compassion to the people** (Tami no Tame ni wa Masu Buiku no Airen o Itasase Tamawaba), you will **receive the protection of the Gods** (Shinmei no Kago ni Azukari) and **not go against the secret will of the Buddhas** (Butsuda no Meiryō ni Somaku Beka-razu). If the **Gods and Buddhas are moved**, the **Emperor will surely change his mind** (Kimi mo Omoimeshi Naosu Koto nado ka Sōrawazaru Beki). When **comparing the sovereign and the subject**, there is **no way to distinguish between closeness and distance** (Shinso Waku Kata Nashi). When **comparing reason and error** (Dōri to Hekigoto o Naraben ni), **how can we not side with reason** (Azade ka Dōri ni Tsuzazaru Beki)?
