2.7. The Signal Fire Incident
[2.7.1] "Since this is the **Emperor's reason** (Kimi no O-kotowari nite Sōraeba), I will **go and guard the Retired Emperor's Palace, Hōjūji-dono**, even if my plea is **not granted**. The reason is that **Shigemori's promotions**, from his **initial rank** (Jojō) until now as **Major General of the Minister** (Daijin no Taishō), are **entirely due to the Emperor's favor** (Kimi no Go-on Naru) in every respect. When I consider the **heaviness of that favor**, it **surpasses a thousand or ten thousand jewels** (Sen-ka Man-ka no Tama ni mo Koe), and when I consider the **depth of that favor's color**, it is **deeper than any scarlet dye** (Hitoe Futae no Kurenai ni mo Sugitaran). Therefore, I will **enter and confine myself in the Retired Emperor's Palace** (In-chū ni Mairi Komori Sōrau Beshi). If that is the case, I have a **few retainers** (Samurai-domo Shōshō Sōran) who have **vowed to exchange their bodies and lives for mine**. If I **summon them** and **guard the Retired Emperor's Palace, Hōjūji-dono**, it would be an **unprecedented great crisis** (I no Hoka no Go-daiji de Koso Sōranzure). **Alas**, if I **render loyal service to the Emperor**, I will **immediately forget the kindness of my father**, who is **higher than the eighty thousand peaks of Sumeru** (Miro Hachiman no Itadaki Yori Nao Takaki Chichi no On), which is **lamentable** (Kanashi-i kana). **Alas**, if I seek to **avoid the sin of unfilial piety** (Fukō no Tsumi o Nogare n to Sureba), I will **immediately become a disloyal and rebellious minister to the Emperor** (Kimi no Go-tame ni Sude ni Fuchū no Gyaku-shin to Narinu Beshi). I am **at a loss** (Shintai Kore Kiwaretari). It is **difficult to distinguish between right and wrong** (Zehhi Ika ni mo Wakae Gata-shi). My **final request** is, **please take Shigemori's head** (Tada Shigemori ga Kubi o Mesare Sōrae). I **will not guard the Retired Emperor's Palace**. I **will not accompany you** to the Retired Emperor's Palace. **Xiao He**, due to his **great merit** (Taigō Kata-he ni Koshitaru ni Yotte), reached the rank of **Grand Minister of State** (Dai Sōkoku) and was **permitted to ascend to the Palace with his sword on and his shoes on** (Tsurugi o Obishi Kutsu o Haki Nagara Denjō ni Noboru Koto o Yurusare Shika Tomo). However, when he **disobeyed the Imperial Will** (Eiryō ni Somaku Koto Are ba), **Emperor Gaozu severely warned him** (Kōso Omou Kage te) and **deeply punished him**. Considering such **precedents** (Sen-shō o Omou ni mo), you have **already attained the heights** of **wealth, glory, Imperial favor, and high office** (Fuki to Ii, Eiga to Ii, Chō-on to Ii, Chōshoku to Ii). It will **not be difficult** for your **good fortune to be exhausted** (Go-un no Tsukinan Koto). How **long will I live** (Ika Made ka Inochi Ikite) to **witness the chaos of the world** (Midare n Yo o mo Mi Sōrau Beki)? **Alas**, my **karma is poor** (Kahō no Hodo Koso Tsutō Sōrae) to be **born in the latter age** (Matsudai ni Sei o Ukete) and **suffer such a miserable fate**. It would be an **easy matter** (Yasuki Hodo no Koto de Koso Sōrae) to **order a single retainer** (Samurai Hitori ni Ōse Tsukete) to **drag me out into the courtyard** and **sever Shigemori's head** (Shigemori ga Kubi no Hanen Koto). **Everyone, listen to this** (Ono Ono Kiki Tamai)." He **shed tears profusely**, so much so that he had to **wring the sleeve of his formal court robe** (Nōshi no Sode mo Shiboru Bakari ni Namida o Nagashi), and he **spoke so passionately** (Kaki Kudokare Kere ba) that the **family members**, **both those with hearts and those without**, **all wept** (Sode o zo Nureshi Keru).
[2.7.2] The **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Dajō Nyūdō) said, **helplessly**, "**The Inner Minister** (Naifu), whom I **rely on**, speaks thus!** "No, no, I **did not even think of this** (Kore Made wa Omoi Oyosazu Sōzu). I only thought that the **wicked people's words** (Akutō-domo ga Mōsu Koto ni Tsukase Tamau te) might lead to some **wrongful act** (Hekigoto nado ya Ide Komunzuran to Omou Bakari de Koso Sōrae)." The **Minister** (Shigemori) said, "**Even if some wrongful act were to happen, how could you do anything to the Emperor?** (Kimi o ba Nan to ka Shi Mairase Tamau Beki)" He **stood up** and **went out to the middle gate**, where he **ordered the retainers** (Samurai-domo), saying, "**Did you hear what Shigemori just said?** This morning, I thought I would **come here and calm things down**, but since the Priest-Chancellor seemed **too furious** (Amari ni Hitasō ni Miek-eru Ma), I **returned**. If you are to **accompany him to the Retired Emperor's Palace**, **do so only after you have seen Shigemori's head severed** (Shigemori ga Kubi no Mesaren o Mite Tsukae). Now, **let the people go** (Saraba Hito Mairi-re)." He then **returned to Komatsu-dono**. He **summoned Mōrikuni**, **Hangan of the Bureau of Horse Administration**, and said, "**Shigemori has heard of a great crisis in the realm** (Tenka no Daiji o Betsu shite Kiki Ideta-re). **Inform all who consider themselves my retainers** (Ware o Ware to Omowan Mono-domo wa) to **don their armor and race to me** (Mina Monogushite Hase Mairi-re)." Mōrikuni **relayed this message**. Everyone thought, "**Since a man who is not easily alarmed** (Oboroge nite wa Sawagas-e Tamawanu Hito) **has sent such a message, there must be a serious reason** (Betsu no Shisai no Aru ni Koso)." They **donned their armor** and **raced to him one after another**. The **warriors who were scattered** in the villages of **Yodo, Hazukashi, Uji, Okaya, Hino, Kanjūji, Daigo, Ogurisu, Umetsu, Katsura, Ōhara, Shizu-hara, and Seriō** were **some wearing armor but not yet helmets**, and **some with arrows but not yet bows**. They **raced in confusion**, some with **one stirrup on and one not** (Kata Abumi Fumi ya Fumazu nite). When they heard that there was a **commotion at Komatsu-dono**, the **thousands of warriors** at **Nishi Hachijō**, **without reporting to the Priest-Chancellor**, **shouted together** and **all raced to Komatsu-dono**. **Not a single warrior** (Hitori mo Nokosazu) who was involved with **bows and arrows** (Yumi Ya ni Tazusawaru Hodo no Mono) **remained**. The **Priest-Chancellor** was **greatly surprised** and **summoned Sadayoshi**, saying, "**What is the Inner Minister** (Naifu) **thinking, summoning these people?** Is an **attacking army** (Uchite) going to **come to the priest's palace** (Nyūdō ga Moto e) as he said?" **Sadayoshi shed tears profusely** and said, "**One should rely on a person of good character!** **How could such a thing happen?** You **must regret** the things you **said here**." The Priest-Chancellor, thinking it would be **bad to fall out with the Inner Minister** (Naifu ni Naka Chigōte wa), **gave up the thought of petitioning the Retired Emperor**. He **removed his cuirass**, **wore a white silk robe** with a **kesa scarf** draped over it, and **sat there reciting the Nenbutsu** (Nenju shite Koso Zashi Kere), though he **did not feel sincere devotion** (Motomo Kokoro ni mo Okiranu).
[2.7.3] At **Komatsu-dono**, **Mōrikuni** was in charge of **taking attendance** (Chakutō Tsukeri). The number of **horsemen** who arrived was **recorded as over ten thousand**. After **checking the attendance list**, the **Minister** (Shigemori) **went out to the middle gate** and **ordered the retainers**, saying, "It is **admirable** that you have **come without breaking your vows** (Nichibi no Keiyaku o Tagaezu shite Mairitaru Koso Jinmyō Nare). There is a **similar example in a foreign country** (Ikoku ni Saru Tameshi Ari). **King You of Zhou** (Shū no Yū-ō) had a **most beloved Empress** named **Bāosi** (Hōji). She was the **most beautiful woman in the realm**. However, she **did not smile**, which displeased King You. The **custom in that foreign country** was that when a **war** (Heikaku) arose in the realm, they would **light fires** (Hi o Agete) in various places and **beat large drums** (Dai-ko o Uchite) to **summon the soldiers** (Heii o Mesu Hakari-goto). This was called a **signal fire** (Hōnoka). One time, a **war** arose in the realm, and they **lit a signal fire**. The Empress **saw it** and said, "**How strange! There is so much fire!**" and **smiled for the first time**. When this Empress smiled once, she was **one hundred times more charming**. King You was **delighted** and would **often light the signal fire** for no reason. The **vassal lords** (Shokō) would **come when they were attacked**. When there was **no attack**, they **left immediately**. Since this **happened repeatedly**, **no one came** anymore. One time, a **fierce rebel** (Kyōzoku) arose from a **neighboring country** and **attacked King You's capital**. Although they **lit the signal fire**, the **soldiers did not come**, as they were **used to the Empress's fire**. At that time, the **capital was overthrown**, and **King You finally perished**. The **Empress** then **turned into a fox** (Yakan to Natte) and **ran away and disappeared**. This is **frightening**. Since such a thing happened, **from now on**, if you are **summoned from here**, you must **all come as you have done today**. **Shigemori** **summoned you** because he **heard of an unexpected event**. However, I have **checked the rumors** (Kiki Naoshi-tsu), and **it was a mistake** (Hekigoto nite Arik-eri). **Return immediately**." He **sent them all back**. In reality, he had **not heard of any such thing**. But he **obeyed the words he had used to admonish his father**, and he **checked the extent of his own military strength**. Also, it was **not his intention to fight his father and son**, but it was a **plot to appease the Priest Grand Minister of State's rebellious intention** (Mubō no Kokorozashi mo Wage Tamau to no Hakari-goto). It is in accordance with the words of **King Wen Xuan** (Bunsen'ō) who said, "Even if the **sovereign is not a true sovereign**, the **subject must not be a disloyal subject** (Kimi Suna-wachi Kimi Nara zu to Ie Domo, Omi wa Omi Iken to Shite wa Naru Beka-razu). Even if the **father is not a true father**, the **son must not be an unfilial son** (Chichi Suna-wachi Chichi Nara zu to Ie Domo, Ko wa Ko Iken to Shite wa Naru Beka-razu)." Be **loyal to the sovereign** and **filial to the father**. When the **Emperor heard of this**, he said, "This is **not the first time** (Ima ni Hajimenu Koto Nare Tomo), but I am **ashamed of the Inner Minister's heart** (Naifu ga Kokoro no Uchi Koso Hajikashikere)." He added, "**He repaid evil with kindness** (Ata o ba On o Motte Hōzerareta-ri)." People of the time **admired him**, saying, "**How fortunate he is!** He has **reached the rank of Major Minister and General**. **He surpasses others in appearance and bearing** (Yōgi Taihai Hito ni Sugure), and his **talent and knowledge** (Saichi Saigaku) must **also surpass the world**." It is said, "**If there is an admonishing subject in a country**, that **country is safe**. If there is an **admonishing son in a family**, that **family is surely righteous** (Sono Ie Kanarazu Tadashi)." He was a **rare Minister** (Arigatakarishi Daijin Nari) in **ancient and latter ages**.
2.8. Exile of the New Major Counselor
[2.8.1] On the **second day of the sixth month** of the same year, the **New Major Counselor Narichika no Kyō** was **brought out to the court nobles' seats** (Kugyō no Za e Dashi Tatematsuri) and was **served food** (O-mono Mairase Tari Kere domo). However, his **chest felt constrained** (Mune Seki Fusagatte), and he **could not even hold his chopsticks**. His **carriage was brought forward**, and he was told to **board immediately**. The Major Counselor **reluctantly boarded** (Kokoro Nara zu Nori Tamau). **Warriors** (Gunpyō-domo) **surrounded him** from **front, back, left, and right**. There was **not a single man from his own side**. He said, "**I wish to see Lord Komatsu one more time** (Komatsu-dono ni Mie Tatematsuraba ya to Notamae domo)," but that **could not be granted**. He muttered inside the carriage, "**Even a person suffering severe punishment and going to a distant country** (Jūka o Kōmuri En-goku e Yuku Mono mo), **is there no one to accompany him?**" The **guarding warriors** (Shugo no Bushi-domo) **all wept** (Yoroi no Sode o zo Nurashi Keru). When he went **south on Suzaku Avenue**, the **Imperial Palace** (Ōuchi-yama) seemed **distant** to him now. The **servants and ox-drivers** (Zasshoku Ushikai) he had **known for years** (Nenrai Mi Nare Tatematsuri shi) **all shed tears** and **wrung their sleeves**. How **piteous** was the **state of his Northern Lady** (Kitano Kata) and his **young children** who **remained in the capital** (Miyako ni Nokori Todomari Tamau)! As he **passed the Toba Palace** (Toba-dono), he thought, "I **never failed to accompany the Emperor** when he visited this palace," and he **saw his mountain villa, the Su-hama Palace** (Waga Yama Shō Suhama-dono to Te Arishi o mo), as **distant** (Yosoni Mite Koso Tōrare Kere) and **passed by**. He **went out of the southern gate** (Minami no Mon e Idete) and **was hurried into a boat** (Funa-ji to zo Isogas-e Keru). He cried out, "**Where are they taking me? If I am to be executed, let it be near the capital** (Miyako Chikai Kono Hen ni te mo Are Kashi)." This was his **most desperate cry**.
[2.8.2] When he **asked the warrior** (Bushi o) who was **riding close beside him**, "**Who are you?**" the warrior replied, "**Nanba Jirō Tsune-to**." The Major Counselor asked, "**Are there any of my people nearby?** I have something to **say before boarding the boat**. **Go and find them**." The warrior **raced around the area** looking for them, but **not a single person** said, "**I am a retainer of Lord Major Counselor**." The Major Counselor **wept**, saying, "**When I was prosperous**, there must have been **one or two thousand people** who **followed me**. How **sad** it is that **not a single person is here** to **even bid me farewell from afar** (Yosoni te Dani Kono Arisama o Mi Okuru Mono no Nak-erikeru Kanashisa yo)." Even the **fierce warriors** (Takeki Bushi-domo) **all wept**. The **only thing that accompanied him** (Mi ni Sou Mono to Te wa) was his **endless tears**. During his **pilgrimages to Kumano and Tennō-ji Temple**, he would **ride in a boat with two roofs and three ridges** (Futagawara no Sanmune ni Tsukuri Taru Fune ni Nori), with **twenty or thirty more boats following**. Now, he was **accompanied by unfamiliar warriors** (Mi mo Narenu Heii-domo ni Gū serare-te) in a **strange, enclosed pleasure boat** (Ayashikaru Kakisue Yakatabune ni) with a **large curtain** (Ōmaku Hiki Sete), **leaving the capital that day** and **heading for a distant sea journey** (Namiji Haruka ni Omomukare Ken). The **feelings in his heart** are **piteous to imagine**. That day, he **arrived at Ōmono-no-ura** (Ōmono-no-ura) in **Settsu Province**.
[2.8.3] The fact that the **New Major Counselor** (Narichika), who was **about to be executed**, was **pardoned to exile** was **due to the persistent pleading of Lord Komatsu** (Komatsu-dono no Yōyō ni Mōsar-ekeru ni Yotte). When this man was still a **Middle Counselor** (Chūnagon) and **governed Mino Province**, in the **winter of Kaō 1** (1169), the **Shrine priests of Hirano Estate** (Hirano Shō no Jinin) which was the **territory of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Ryō), **came to the Deputy Governor, Uemon no Jō Masatomo**, to **sell kudzu fiber**. The Deputy Governor was **drunk on sake** and **smeared ink on the kudzu**. The Shrine priests started to **speak abusively**, so the Deputy Governor shouted, "**Stop that!**" and **greatly insulted them**. Thereupon, **several hundred Shrine priests** (Jinin-domo) **forced their way into the Deputy Governor's residence**. The Deputy Governor **defended himself according to the law**, and **over ten Shrine priests were killed**. Because of this, on the **third day of the eleventh month** of the same year, the **monks of Mount Hiei** (Sanmon no Taishu) **rose up in a great number** and **petitioned the throne** that **Governor Narichika** should be **exiled** and **Deputy Governor Uemon no Jō Masatomo** should be **imprisoned**. Narichika was **about to be exiled to Bitchū Province** (Bitchū no Kuni e Nagasaru Beki nite) and was **already at Nishi Shichijō** (Nishi no Shichijō Made Dasaretari shi o). However, the **Emperor** (Kimi) perhaps **regretted this** (Omoimesare Ken) and **recalled him** (Meshi Kaesareru) after **five days**. Although it was rumored that the **monks of Mount Hiei loudly cursed him** (Ōbitadashiu Jūsosu to Kiek-eshi), on the **fifth day of the first month of Kaō 2** (1170), he was **concurrently appointed** (Ken Shite) **Head of the Right Gate Guards** (Uemon no Kami) and became the **Chief of the Police and Judicial Commissioner** (Kebii-shi no Bettō). At that time, **Lord Sukekata** (Sukekata Kyō) and **Lord Kanemasa** (Kanemasa Kyō) were **skipped** (Koe-rare Tamau). Lord Sukekata was a **veteran and senior official** (Furui Hito Otona nite O-zashiki). Lord Kanemasa was a **man of glory** (Eiga no Hito). It was **regrettable** that they, as **family heirs**, were **skipped**. This was the **reward for the construction of the Sanjō Palace** (Sanjō-dono Zōshin no Shō Nari). On the **thirteenth day of the fourth month of Kaō 3** (1171), he was **promoted to Junior Second Rank**. At that time, **Middle Counselor Munie no Kyō of Nakamikado** (Nakamikado Chūnagon Munie Kyō) was **skipped**. On the **twenty-seventh day of the tenth month of Angen 1** (1175), he was **promoted from former Middle Counselor to Vice Major Counselor**. People mocked him, saying, "**He should have been cursed by the Mount Hiei monks** (Sanmon no Taishu ni wa Norowaru Beki-keru Mono o)." However, perhaps because of that, he **suffered such a miserable fate now**. In general, the **punishment of the Gods** (Shinmei no Batsu) and the **curses of men** (Hito no Juso) are **sometimes quick and sometimes slow**, and are **not uniform**.
[2.8.4] On the **third day of the same month**, a **messenger** (Go-tsukai Ari to Te) was **hastily sent** from the **capital** (Kyō Yori) to **Ōmono-no-ura**. The **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) thought, "They must have ordered to **execute me there** (Soko nite Ushinae to ni ya)." However, the messenger said that he should be **exiled to Kojima** (Kojima e Nagasu Beshi) in **Bizen Province**. There was also a **letter from Lord Komatsu** (Komatsu-dono Yori Go-fumi Ari). It read, "I **pleaded intensely** (Sashimo Mōshi-tsure domo) to have you **kept in some mountain village near the capital** (Miyako Chikai Kata Yamato ni mo Oki Tatematsuraba ya to), but **it was not granted**. This is why **I feel that living is futile** (Yo ni Aru Kai mo Sōrawane). Nevertheless, I **begged for your life** (Go-inochi Bakari wa Shinegite Sōrō)." He also **sent a message to Nanba Jirō** (Nanba ga Moto e mo), saying, "**Be sure to serve him well** (Kamaete Yoku Yoku Miyazukae) and **do not go against his will** (Go-kokoro ni Tagau-na)." He **arranged and sent clothing and other necessities for the journey** (Tabi no Yosooi Hosoboso to Sata Shi Okurareta-ri). The **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) was **separated from the Emperor** (Kimi ni mo Hanare Mairase), whom he had **revered so deeply**, and **parted from his Northern Lady** and **young children** (Kitano Kata Sukenai Hitobito ni mo Wakare Hatete), whom he **could not bear to leave for a moment**. He cried out, "**Where am I going now?** It is **unlikely** that I will **ever return to my hometown** (Koyō ni Kaerite) and **see my wife and children again**. Last year, when I was **exiled due to the Mount Hiei petition**, the **Emperor pitied me** (Kimi Oshimase Tamai-te) and **recalled me from Nishi Shichijō**. This time, however, it is **not the Emperor's admonishment** (Kimi no O-imashime ni mo Arazu). **What have I done?**" He **looked up at the sky and bowed his head to the ground** (Ten ni Aogi Chi ni Utasubushi-te), and his **grief and weeping were in vain**. When the **boat was pushed out** the next day, he was **choked with tears the whole way**. Although he felt he **could not live long**, his **fleeting life** (Tsuyu no Inochi) **did not end**. As the **white waves behind him separated them**, the **capital gradually became distant**. As the **days passed**, the **distant province drew closer**. He was **rowed to Kojima** (Kojima ni Kogi Yose te) in **Bizen Province** and **settled in a humble thatched hut** (Asamashi-ge naru Shiba no Iori) of a **commoner's house** (Tami no Ie ni Oki Tatematsuru). It was the **custom of the island** (Shima no Narai), with the **mountain behind** and the **sea in front**. The **pine wind on the shore** (Iso no Matsukaze) and the **sound of the waves** (Nami no Oto) were **endlessly mournful**.
2.9. Akoya Pine
[2.9.1] **Many others** (Yakara Ōkari Keri) besides the **Major Counselor** were **punished** (Kei o Kōmuru). **Middle Captain Ōmi no Nyūdō Renjō** was exiled to **Sado Province**, **Motokane, Governor of Yamashiro**, to **Hōki Province**, **Masatsuna, Major Official of the Ministry of Ceremonial**, to **Harima Province**, **Mune no Hangan Nobufusa** to **Awa Province**, and **New Taira Hangan Sukeyuki** to **Mimasaka Province**.
[2.9.2] About this time, the **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Nyūdō Shōkoku) was at his **Fukuhara villa** (Fukuhara no Betsugō ni O-zashi-keru ga). On the **twentieth of the same month**, he **sent Settsu Saemon Morizumi** as a **messenger** to the **Gate-Side Counsellor** (Kadowaki no Saishō), saying, "**I have something to discuss. Have the Tanba Minor Captain come here immediately**." The **Counsellor** (Saishō) thought, "**If only this had happened when he was still here** (Arishi Toki to mo Kaku mo Nari Tari Sere ba Ika ga Sen)! It is **sad to make him worry again** (Ima Sara Mono o Omowasen Koso Kanashikere)." He **announced** that the Minor Captain should **go to Fukuhara**, and the Minor Captain **departed weeping**. The **court ladies** (Nyōbō-domo) **lamented** that **since it could not be helped**, the **Counsellor should plead again**. The **Counsellor** said, "**I have pleaded to the best of my ability**. Now, **what more can I say** (Nanigoto o ka Mōsu Beki) besides **renouncing the world** (Yo o Suteru Yori Hoka wa)? Nevertheless, **wherever he may be**, I will **visit him** (Toi Tatematsuru Beshi) as long as **I live**." The Minor Captain had a **young child** (Osanaki Hito) who was **three years old this year**. He had always been a **young man** who was **not overly concerned about his children**, but at this **final moment** (Ima wa no Toki ni Narishi ka ba), he was **surely touched by emotion** (Sasuga Kokoro ni ya Kakara Re Ken). He said, "**I wish to see this young child one more time**." The **nurse** (Uba) **held him and brought him**. The Minor Captain **placed him on his lap**, **stroked his hair**, and **shed tears profusely**, saying, "**Alas, I intended to make you a man** (Otoko ni Nashi-te) **and have you serve the Emperor** (Kimi e Mairasen) **when you reached seven years old**. But now, **it is useless**. If you **live and grow up**, **become a monk** (Hōshi ni Nari) and **pray for my salvation in the next world** (Waga Nochi no Yo Tomurae yo)." Although the **young child** could **not understand what he was saying**, he **nodded his head**. The **Minor Captain**, his **mother**, the **nurse**, and the **people sitting there**, **both with hearts and without**, **all wept**. The **messenger from Fukuhara** said that he should **depart for Toba that very night**. Although the Minor Captain said, "**Since my life will not be prolonged** (Iku Hodo mo Nobezaran Mono Yue ni), **I wish to spend just this one night in the capital** (Koyoi Bakari wa Miyako no Uchi nite Akasaba ya)," the messenger **insisted**, so he **departed for Toba that night**. The **Counsellor** (Saishō) was **too distressed** and **did not accompany him** this time.
[2.9.3] On the **twenty-second of the same month**, when he **arrived at Fukuhara**, the **Priest Grand Minister of State ordered Seo Tarō Kaneyasu** to **exile him to Bitchū Province**. **Kaneyasu**, **fearing the Counsellor's resentment** (Saishō no Kaeri Kikan Tokoro o Osorete), **comforted and soothed him** (Itari Nagusame Tatematsuru) in various ways **all along the way**. However, the **Minor Captain** (Shōshō) was **not comforted at all**. He **recited the name of the Buddha** (Hotoke no O-na o nomi Tonōte) day and night and **lamented for his father**. The **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) was **in Kojima** (Kojima ni O-zakeru o) in **Bizen Province**. **Nanba Jirō Tsune-to**, the **guarding warrior** (Azukari no Bushi), moved him to **land** (Ji e Watashi Tatematsuri), thinking it was **too close to the port** (Funatsu Chikōte Warukari nan to Te), and **settled him in a mountain temple** called **Ariki no Betsu-sho** (Ariki no Betsu-sho), in the **Niwase area** (Niwase no Gō), on the **border between Bizen and Bitchū Provinces**. Since the **distance** between **Seo in Bitchū** (Bitchū no Seo to) and **Ariki no Betsu-sho in Bizen** was **only less than fifty chō** (Wazuka Gojitchō ni Tarinu Tokoro Nare ba), the **Tanba Minor Captain** (Naritsune) perhaps **longed for the direction** (Sono Kata no Kaze mo Sasuga Natsukashiu ya Omoware Ken). He **summoned Kaneyasu** and asked, "**How far is it** (Ika Hodo no Michi zo) **to Ariki no Betsu-sho** (Ariki no Betsu-sho e wa), **where the Major Counselor is staying?**" Kaneyasu, thinking it would be **bad to tell him directly**, replied, "**It is twelve or thirteen days one way** (Kata Michi Jū-ni San Nite Sōrō)." The Minor Captain **shed tears profusely** and said, "Japan originally had **thirty-three provinces**, but in the **middle ages**, it was **divided into sixty-six provinces**. Even **Bizen, Bitchū, and Bingo** (Bizen Bitchū Bingo mo), which are **now so close**, were **originally one country**. Also, **Dewa and Mutsu Provinces** (Dewa Mutsu Ryōkoku), which are in the **east**, were **originally one country of sixty-six districts**, but **twelve districts were split off** (Jū-ni Gōri o Wari Wakate) to form **Dewa Province**. Therefore, when **Middle Captain Sanekata** (Sanekata Chūjō) was **exiled to Ōshū** (Ōshū e Nagasare Tari-keru Toki), he **traveled around the province** (Kuni Naka o Tazune Ariki Keru ga) looking for a place called the **Akoya Pine** (Akoya no Matsu), a **famous place in the province** (Tōkoku no Na-dokoro), but **could not find it**. When he **met an old man** (Rōō no Hitori Yuki Ai Tari-keru ni) on the road back, he asked, "**Sir, you look like a man of old** (Furu-i Hito to Koso Mi Tatematsure), **do you know a place called the Akoya Pine, a famous place in this province?**" The old man replied, "**It is absolutely not in this province**. It must be in **Dewa Province**." Sanekata said, "**Then you also do not know it**. The **latter age** (Yo Sue ni Natte) has arrived, and they have **already forgotten all the famous places**." As he was about to **pass by disappointed**, the **old man held his sleeve** and said, "**Alas, my lord**, is it not because of the **meaning of this poem** (Kono Uta no Kokoro o Motte) that you speak of the **Akoya Pine** (Akoya no Matsu), a **famous place in this province?**" "**Does the moon that should emerge hide among the trees of the Akoya Pine in Michinoku, unable to come out?**" You say it is a **famous place in this province** because of the **meaning of this poem**? That poem was **composed when the two provinces were one country**. After the **twelve districts were split off**, it must be in **Dewa Province**." Sanekata said, "**If that is the case**," and he **crossed into Dewa Province** and **saw the Akoya Pine**. It is said that the **messenger** (Haraaka no Tsukai) from **Dazaifu** in **Tsukushi** (Kyūshū) to the **capital** takes **fifteen days one way**. If you say it is **twelve or thirteen days**, it is as if we are **going to Kyūshū** (Chinzei e Gekō) from here! Even if it is **far**, the **distance between Bizen and Bitchū** (Bizen Bitchū no Ma) **cannot be more than two or three days**. You are **saying a near place is far** (Chikaki o Tō Mōsu wa) because you **do not want Naritsune to know the Major Counselor's location** (Dainagon-dono no O-watari Aru Tokoro o Naritsune ni Shiraseji to Te Koso Mōsurame)." After that, although he **longed for his father**, he **did not ask** about him.
2.10. Death of the Major Counselor
[2.10.1] Meanwhile, **Shunkan Sōzu**, **Executive Monk of Hōsshoji Temple**, **Taira no Hangan Yasuyori**, and this **Minor Captain** (Shōshō) were **exiled together** to **Kikai-ga-shima** in **Satsuma Bay**. That island is a place they reached by **crossing a long distance of waves** from the capital. **Boats did not easily reach there**. There were **few people on the island**. Although there were **some people**, they did **not resemble the people of this land**. They were **dark-skinned** (Iro Kurō shite) and **looked like cattle**. Their **bodies were covered with thick hair**, and they **could not understand speech** (Genshi o mo Kiki Shirazu). The **men did not wear court hats** (Eboshi mo Sezu), and the **women did not tie up their hair** (Kami mo Sagezarikeri). They **did not resemble humans** because they **had no clothing**. Since they **had no food**, they **only engaged in killing animals** (Sesshō o nomi Saki to su). Since they did **not cultivate the fields**, there were **no grains**, and since they did **not pick mulberry leaves**, there were **no silk products** (Ken-haku no Rui). There was a **high mountain** in the middle of the island. **Fire constantly burned** on it. It was **filled with sulfur** (Iō to Iu Mono Man Man te-ri). Therefore, it was **also named Iō-ga-shima** (Sulfur Island). **Thunder constantly roared up and down**, and **rain was frequent at the foot of the mountain**. It was a place where a **human life could not endure** even for a **single day or moment** (Hito no Inochi Taete Aru Beki Yō mo Nashi).
[2.10.2] Meanwhile, the **New Major Counselor** (Narichika) was **rejoicing** (Omo wa Rekeru ni) that his situation had **eased somewhat**, but when he **heard** that his **son, Tanba Minor Captain Naritsune**, had **also been exiled to Kikai-ga-shima**, he thought, "Now, there is **nothing left to hope for** (Nanigoto o ka Go-ki Subeki)." He **sent a message** to **Lord Komatsu** (Komatsu-dono) through a messenger that he **wished to become a monk** (Shukke no Kokorozashi no Sōrau Yosi). Lord Komatsu **inquired of the Retired Emperor** (Hōō ni Ukagai Mōshite), and **received permission**. He **immediately became a monk** (Sugu ni Shukke Shi Tamainu). He **pulled back the lapel of his glorious robe** (Eiga no Tamoto o Hiki Kaete) and **humbled himself** (Yatsure Tamau) in the **dyed black sleeve** (Sumizome no Sode) that signified **leaving the fleeting world** (Uki Yo o Yoso no).
[2.10.3] The **Major Counselor's Northern Lady** (Dainagon no Kitano Kata) was **secretly residing** (Shinobite zo O-zashikeru) near **Kurin-in Temple** (Unrin-in no Hen) on **Mount Kita** (Kita Yama), in the capital. It was already **distressing** (Monouki ni) to live in an **unfamiliar place**, and since she was **hiding herself**, the **passing months and days** (Sugi Yuku Tsukihi mo) were **difficult to get through**. Although there were **many ladies and retainers**, some **feared the world** (Yo o Osore), and some **were reserved** (Hito Me o Tsutsumu Hodo ni), so **no one came to visit**. However, among them, a **retainer** (Samurai Hitori) named **Minamoto Saemon no Jō Nobutoshi** (Minamoto Saemon no Jō Nobutoshi to Iu) had **exceptional devotion** (Jō Koto ni Fukakari Kere ba) and **visited her constantly**. One time, the **Northern Lady summoned Nobutoshi** and said, "**Is it true** that he was first in **Kojima** in **Bizen** (Bizen no Kojima ni to Kiek-eshi ga), but recently I heard he is in **Ariki no Betsu-sho**? (Ariki no Betsu-sho to ka ya ni O-zashi Nari). I wish to **send him a fleeting letter** (Hakanaki Fude no Ato o mo Tatematsuri) and **hear from him once more** (Go-onshin o mo Kika ba ya)." **Nobutoshi suppressed his tears** and replied, "Since I was **young** (Yōshō Yori), I have **received your pity** and **have not been separated from you for a moment**. I also wished to **accompany you** (Go-tomo Tsukuro u to Mōshi Sōraishi ga) when you **were expelled**, but the **Rokuhara Palace refused**, so I **could not do so**. Your **voice calling me** (Mesare Sōraishi Go-koe mo) **remains in my ears**, and your **words of admonishment** (Isamerare Mairaseshi O-kotoba mo) are **engraved in my liver**, and I **do not forget them for a moment**. No matter **what happens to my body** (Kono Mi wa Ikanaru Me ni mo Ai Sōrae). Please **give me the letter quickly** (Hayabaya Go-fumi Tamawatte) and I will **go and deliver it**." The **Northern Lady was extremely delighted** (Naname Narazu Yorokonde) and **immediately wrote the letter and gave it to him**. The **young children** (Sukenai Hitobito mo) also **each wrote letters**. **Nobutoshi received these** and **traveled far to Ariki no Betsu-sho** in **Bizen Province** to **find him**. He **first announced his arrival** (Annai o Ii Kere ba) to **Nanba Jirō Tsune-to**, the **guarding warrior**, who was **moved by his devotion** and **immediately allowed him to see the Major Counselor**. The **Major Counselor Priest** was **constantly speaking only of the capital** (Miyako no Koto o nomi Nori Idashi) and **sunken in grief**. When Nobutoshi was announced, saying, "**Nobutoshi has come from the capital**," the Major Counselor said, "**Is this a dream?**" He **sat up immediately** and said, "**Come here! Come here!**" Nobutoshi **went to see him**. He saw the **Major Counselor's miserable residence**, and even more so, when he saw his **dyed black sleeve** (Sumizome no O-tamoto o Mi Tatema-tsuru ni zo), Nobutoshi felt his **eyes dim and his heart fail**. He **fully relayed the Northern Lady's message** and **presented the letters**. When the Major Counselor **opened and read them**, the **handwriting** (Mizukuki no Ato wa) was **blurred by tears** (Namida ni Kaki Kurete). Although he **could not read the details** (Soko to wa Mine Tomo), it said, "**The young children are grieving so much** (Sukenai Hitobito no Amari ni Koishi Kanashimi Tamau Arisama) that **I cannot endure the thought that my life is also about to end** (Waga Mi mo Tsukinu Omoi ni Kannin Beu mo Nashi)." The Major Counselor **grieved** that his **daily longing** was **nothing compared to this**. After **four or five days**, Nobutoshi said, "**I will remain here and witness your final moments** (Go-saigo no O-arisama Mi Mairasen)." **Nanba Jirō Tsune-to**, the **guarding warrior**, **repeatedly said it was impossible**, so the Major Counselor **had no choice** and said, "**Then return to the capital**." He said, "I will **likely perish soon**. If you **hear that I am gone**, please **be sure to pray for my salvation in the next world** (Waga Gose Tomurae) with all your might." He **wrote a reply** (Go-henji Kaite) and **gave it to Nobutoshi**. Nobutoshi **received it**, asked for leave, saying, "**I will come again**," and **departed**. The Major Counselor said, "I **don't think I will live until you come again**. You are so **dear to me** (Amari ni Shitashiku Oboeru ni), **wait, wait** (Shibashi Shibashi)." He **called him back repeatedly**. Since it could not be helped, **Nobutoshi suppressed his tears** and **returned to the capital**. When he **presented the letter to the Northern Lady**, she **opened and read it**. She **noticed** that he had **already become a monk**, and there was a **lock of his hair** (O-kami no Hito Fusa) at the **end of the letter**. She **could not bear to look at it** and **wallowed and wept**. The **young children** also **wept and grieved loudly**.
[2.10.4] Meanwhile, the **Major Counselor Priest** was **finally executed** (Tsui ni Ushina-i Tatematsuru) on the **nineteenth day of the eighth month** of the same year, at a place called **Kibi-no-Nakayama** (Kibi no Nakayama), in the **Niwase area**, on the **border between Bizen and Bitchū Provinces**. The **details of his death** (Saigo no Arisama) were **variously rumored**. It was said that they **put poison in sake** (Sake ni Doku o Irete) and **offered it to him**, but when he **would not drink it**, they **planted spikes** (Hishi o Uete) **at the bottom of a cliff about twenty feet high** (Kishi no Ni-jō Hodo Arik-eru Shita ni), and **pushed him down from above**. He was **impaled on the spikes** and **died**. These were **truly horrible things**, and they seemed to be **crude methods** (Moto Sukō zo Oboek-eru). The **Major Counselor's Northern Lady** (Kitano Kata) had **not changed her appearance until today** because she wished to **see her husband's unchanged appearance one more time** if she **heard that he was gone** (Kawaranu Sugata o Mi mo Shi Mien to Te Koso Kyō Made Yō mo Kaeza-ritsure). Now she thought, "**What is the use now?**" She **entered a temple** called **Bodai-in**, **changed her appearance**, and **performed the prescribed Buddhist rites** (Kata no Gotoku no Butsuji o Itonami) to **pray for his salvation in the next world** (Gose o zo Tomurai Tamawari Keru). This **Northern Lady** was the **daughter of Motokata, Governor of Yamashiro**. She was a **surpassing beauty** (Sugaretaru Bijin nite), the **most beloved lady** (Go-sai-ai Narabi Naki Omoi Hito) of the **Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa** (Go-Shirakawa Hōō), and it was rumored that **Lord Narichika** had **received her** as a **greatly favored person** (Arigataki Chōai no Hito nite). It is **piteous** that the **young children** (Osanaki Hitobito mo) **picked flowers** and **scooped holy water** (Aka no Mizu o Ku-nde) to **pray for their father's salvation in the next world**. Meanwhile, as **time passed and events changed**, the **way the world declined** (Yo no Kawari Yuku Arisama wa) was **no different from the five signs of decay of a heavenly being** (Ten'nin no Goshū ni Inara-zu).
2.11. The Affair of Lord Tokudaiji
[2.11.1] At this time, **Major Counselor Tokudaiji Sanesada no Kyō** had been **skipped for the Major General position** (Taishō o Koe-rarete) by **Munemori no Kyō**, the **Priest Grand Minister of State's second son**, and was **temporarily in seclusion** (Shibaraku Komori-i Shi Tamawari Keri). When he **declared his intention to become a monk** (Shukke Sen to Notamae ba), his **high officials and retainers** (Morodaibu Samurai-domo) **lamented**, wondering **what to do**. Among them was a **high official** (Morodaibu Ari) named **Fujiwara Kurōdo Shigekane** (Fujiwara Kurōdo Shigekane to Iu). He was a **knowledgeable person** in all matters. One **moonlit night**, as **Lord Sanesada** had the **grating of his southern-facing room raised** (Nanmen no Go-kōshi Age Sase) and was **whistling at the moon all alone** (Tada Hitori Tsuki ni Usonde O-zaishi-keru Tokoro ni), **Fujiwara Kurōdo** came forward, perhaps to **comfort him**. "Who is there?" "Shigekane." "Why have you come?" He replied, "The **moon is especially clear tonight** (Tsuki Saete) and my **heart is calm** (Man-shin no Sumi Sōrau Mama ni), so I have come." The **Major Counselor** said, "**That was an inspired arrival** (Jinmyō ni Mairitari). It is **so lonely and tedious** (Amari ni Nanto Yaran Kokoro Bosōte Tsurezure Naru ni)." Afterward, Shigekane **spoke of various unrelated things** to **comfort him**. The **Major Counselor** said, "Observing the **state of this world**, the **Taira clan's prosperity is increasing even more**. The **Priest Grand Minister of State's eldest and second sons are Major Generals of the Left and Right**. His **third son, Tomomori**, and his **eldest grandson, Koremori**, are **also there**. If they **all rise sequentially**, it is **unlikely** that **anyone outside the family will ever be appointed Major General** (Taishō o Itsu Tori Tsukubeki to mo Oboezu). Therefore, this is the **end**. I will **become a monk**." **Shigekane shed tears profusely** and replied, "**If you become a monk**, all the **high and low in your household** (Go-uchi no Jōge) will **be bewildered** (Madowashi-mono ni Nari Sōinan). I have **come up with an unusual plan** (Mezura-shii Koto o Koso An-dashi-te Sōrae). For example, the **Taira clan deeply reveres Itsukushima** (Itsukushima o Naname Narazu Sūkei wa re Sōrau ni). **What harm is there?** Please **visit that Shrine** (Kare Miya e Go-san Ari) and **make a vow** (Go-kise-i Sōrae kashi). If you **seclude yourself there for about seven days**, there are **many elegant female attendants** (Yū naru Maibime-domo Ōku Sōrō) called **Naishi** at that Shrine. They will **be delighted** to see you and will **treat you well**. If they ask about the **reason for your seclusion and vow**, tell them **exactly as it is**. When you **depart**, they will **regret your parting**. **Summon the principal female attendants** (Mune-dono no Naishi-domo) and **bring them to the capital**. When they arrive in the capital, they will **surely visit Nishi Hachijō**. If the Priest-Chancellor asks, '**For what vow did Lord Tokudaiji visit Itsukushima?**' the attendants will **surely tell him exactly as it is**. The **Priest Grand Minister of State** (Nyūdō Shōkoku) is a man who **greatly appreciates unusual things**. He will think, 'How **admirable** that he **visited and prayed to the God I revere!**' and I believe he will **plan some favorable arrangement**." **Lord Tokudaiji** (Tokudaiji-dono) said, "**I would never have thought of this!** What an **admirable strategy** (Arigataki Saku kana)! I will **go immediately**." He **immediately began abstinence** (Sugu ni Shōjin Hajime-tsutsu) and **visited Itsukushima**.
[2.11.2] Indeed, there were **many elegant women** (Yū naru Onna-domo Ōkari Keri) called **Naishi** at that Shrine. When he **secluded himself there for seven days**, they **attended him day and night** and **treated him exceptionally well**. There were **three performances of court music and dance** (Bugaku mo San-do made arikeri) during the **seven days and nights**. They **played the lute and zither** (Biwa Koto Hiki), and performed **sacred music and songs** (Kagura Maikatai nado Asobi Kere ba). **Lord Sanesada** also found it **delightful**. For the **Buddhist offering and entertainment of the Gods** (Shinmei Hōraku no Tame ni), he performed **Imayō, Rōei** (a type of chant), **Fūzoku** (folk songs), and **Saibara** (Court Music), all **admirable musical pieces** (Arigataki Eikyoku-domo). The **female attendants** (Naishi-domo) said, "The **Taira young lords** (Heike no Kimidachi Koso) usually visit this Shrine. Your visit is **rare and greatly appreciated** (Kono O-mairi Koso Mezura-shiu Sōrae). **For what vow** (Nanigoto no Go-kisei) are you **secluding yourself here?**" He replied, "It is a **prayer for the Major Generalship** (Taishō no Go-inori no Tame) that was **given to another**." When he **completed his seven days of seclusion** and **asked leave** of the **Great Deity** (Daimyōjin) to **return to the capital**, the attendants **regretted his parting**. **Over ten principal young female attendants** (Mune-dono no Wakaki Naishi Jūyo-nin) **pushed out boats** and **escorted him for a day's journey**. Although he **asked them to return**, he said it was **too regrettable to part** (Amari ni Nagori no Oshiki ni) and pleaded for them to **accompany him for one more day's journey, then two more days' journey**, and **brought them all the way to the capital**. They **arrived at the Tokudaiji residence**. He **treated them in various ways** and **gave them various farewell gifts** (Go-hikidemono-domo Tōde Kaesareru Keri).
[2.11.3] The **female attendants** (Naishi-domo) thought, "**Since we have come this far to the capital, how can we not visit our lord, the Priest Grand Minister of State?**" and **visited Nishi Hachijō**. The **Priest Grand Minister of State immediately came out to meet them** and asked, "**Why have the female attendants** (Naishi-domo) **come here?**" They replied, "**Lord Tokudaiji visited the Shrine and was secluded for seven days**. When he **departed for the capital**, we **escorted him for a day's journey**. He said that it was **too regrettable to part**, and he **pleaded for us to accompany him for one more day, then two more days**, and **brought us all the way here**." "‘For what kind of vow or prayer did Lord Tokudaiji travel as far as Itsukushima?’" When he asked this, they replied, "‘He said it was for the General’s prayers.’" At that moment, the Lay Priest nodded and said, "How moving this is! Leaving behind so many august Buddhas and sacred shrines in the capital, he went to worship and pray before the deity whom we revere. Truly admirable." "‘If his sincerity is to such a degree…’" With that, he caused his legitimate heir, Lord Komatsu — then Minister of the Center and Left General — to resign, and promoted his second son, Munemori, then Major Counselor and Right General, elevating him above his elder brother, and thus appointed Tokudaiji as Left General. Ah, what a moving and auspicious strategy it was! The new Major Counselor, however, instead of making such wise arrangements, raised a pointless rebellion, causing his own ruin and bringing suffering even to his sons and followers — indeed, utterly deplorable.
2.12. The Affair of Lord Tokudaiji
2.12. The Battles of the Temple Attendants
[2.12.1]
Around that time, the retired emperor received the secret Shingon teachings from Archbishop Kōken of Miidera: the Mahāvairocana Sūtra, the Vajraśekhara Sūtra, and the Soshitsuji Sūtra. It was said that the abhiṣeka was to be performed at Miidera on the fourth day of the ninth month. The monks of Enryakuji grew furious: “From ancient times, abhiṣeka and ordination have always been performed at our Mountain. This is precedent!” “Above all, the guidance of the mountain deity is for the purpose of ordination and consecration.” “If the rite is performed at Miidera, we shall burn the temple to the ground!” So they said. Judging this to be fruitless strife, the retired emperor completed his preparatory practices and abandoned the plan. Still, unable to give up his true intention, he brought Archbishop Kōken of Miidera with him to Tennōji, built the Hall of Wisdom Light, took water from Kamei in five vessels as the “water of wisdom,” and there, at that sacred site where the Buddha Dharma first arose, performed the abhiṣeka.
[2.12.2]
Although the consecration was not held at Miidera to calm the uproar on Mount Hiei, trouble nevertheless arose among the temple attendants and students on the mountain, and battles occurred repeatedly. Each time, the students were defeated and driven out; it seemed as though Enryakuji would fall and the imperial house meet disaster. The so-called “temple attendants” (dōshū) were youths who had become monks after serving students, or middle attendants turned monks, who since the time of Archbishop Kakujin of Kongōju-in had been organized into the Three Towers as “summer attendants,” offering flowers to the Buddha. In recent years they had acted independently of the monks, yet now they repeatedly won the battles. Because they defied their superiors and instigated warfare, the monks reported to the court that they should be swiftly punished and notified the military houses. By imperial command, Kii province warriors — Yūasa no Gon-no-kami Muneshige and others, over two thousand mounted soldiers — were attached to the monks to assist in suppressing the temple attendants. The temple attendants, who had previously stayed at Tōyōbō, descended to the estates of Sanga in Ōmi province, gathered a large force, ascended the mountain again, and fortified themselves at Hayao-zaka.
[2.12.3]
On the twentieth day of the ninth month, at the hour of the dragon, 3,000 monks and over 2,000 government troops — more than 5,000 in total — advanced upon Hayao-zaka. Both sides believed they could win this time, but the monks wanted the government troops to go first, and the government troops wanted the monks to go first. Because each side insisted, they could not even fight properly. From within the fort, stone-bows were fired; both monks and government soldiers were slain in numbers. The “brigands who accompany the temple attendants” were thieves, robbers, bandits, and pirates from various provinces. Driven by greed and reckless toward life or death, each fought fiercely, and once again the student warriors were defeated.
2.13. The Ruin of Enryakuji
[2.13.1]
After that, Enryakuji on Mount Hiei fell ever further into ruin. Aside from the Twelve Meditation Halls, even monks who continued to reside there became scarce; the lectures held in the valleys faded away, and the rituals in the great halls declined.
The windows for study were shut, and the platforms for meditation lay empty.
The spring blossoms of the Four Teachings and Five Periods no longer gave forth fragrance, and the autumn moon of the Threefold Truth now hung dim.
No one remained to tend the Dharma lamp that had burned for over three hundred years, and even the smoke of the incense that should have risen without cease at the six daily services must surely have vanished.
Once, the halls and buildings stood tall, their triple eaves thrust into the blue heavens; their beams rose high, and their verandas stretched into the drifting white mist.
But now, offerings to the Buddha were left to the mountain winds, and golden images stood exposed to the red resin of the pines.
At night, the moonlight shone upon the lamps and leaked through the gaps in the eaves; at dawn, dewdrops hung like jewels and adorned the lotus pedestals.
Alas, as the world slid into this final age, even the Buddhist teachings of the Three Countries declined one after another.
Far away in India, if one visits the traces of the Buddha, the Bamboo Grove Monastery where the Buddha preached, and Jetavana Monastery, are now dens of foxes and jackals, leaving only foundations behind.
At White Heron Pond, the water has dried up, and only tall grass grows thickly.
Stupas left behind by the sages of the Lesser Vehicle stand moss–covered and leaning.
In China as well, Mount Tiantai, Mount Wutai, the White Horse Temple, and Yùquán Monastery have all fallen into ruin with no residents remaining; the teachings of both Greater and Lesser Vehicles must lie rotting at the bottom of chests.
In our land too, the Seven Great Temples of Nara lie desolate, the Eight and Nine Schools have left no trace. Even Atago and Takao, where once halls and pagodas stood shoulder to shoulder—after a single night’s destruction—became nothing more than dwellings of tengu.
So perhaps it is no wonder that even the illustrious Tendai teachings have, by the era of Jishō, reached their end. No person of understanding refrains from lamenting their fate.
A monk leaving the mountain wrote this poem upon a pillar of his lodge:
The sacred grove where once I prayed and felled the first trees— has it at last become a lonely peak where no one dwells?
[2.13.2]
This, they say, expresses remembrance of how Dengyō Daishi, the founder of this mountain temple in ancient times, prayed before the Buddhas of supreme enlightenment.
It sounded exceedingly moving.
Though the eighth day is the day of Yakushi, not even the chant of “Namu” could be heard.
Though the fourth month is the month of the deity’s manifestation, there was no one to offer sacred cloths.
The vermilion fence had grown ancient and divine, and only the sacred rope remained.
